Oh, and the tropical tea + lemongrass tea fused together tastes like an arnold palmer :) jus thought i'd mix both to give it a try.

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and everyone. Great service, great ambiance. Parking is a little of a pain but hey, it's the city, it's expected. 

Note to self: A million more things to try next time. Hawaiian Poke. Mahi Mahi Bowl. Etc.

excerpts: Thai Coconut Shrimp - Thai sweet-chili sauce
thai coconut shrimp.author: Kapo T.
thai coconut shrimp.review:
i m not a big asian fusion fan probably because i think asian food is traditional enough and shouldn't be made any different. i've been here 3 times and the food is OK. nothing great. the location is great if you need a snack from walking the GGP or the museums. (but there are other food to eat around there also).  

the only thing that i recommend is the happy hour here. on a nice sunny day, the bar and outside seating is packed.  happy hour is from 4p-6p so get your orders in before 6p.  

here's their HH menu: 
Hawaiian Poke - sushi-grade ahi tuna in a sesame-soy marinade & spicy seasonings with wonton crisps
Asparagus & Shiitake - asparagus tempura & shiitake mushrooms with miso dressing
Spicy Tuna - ahi tuna with sriracha mayo
Thai Coconut Shrimp - Thai sweet-chili sauce
Spicy Cabo Calamari - crispy chili & lemon with spicy chipotle sauce
Warm Edamame - Hawaiian Alaea sea salt
Basket of Fries - "signature" sweet potato, traditional or spicy 

and yup, we ordered 3 of everything on the HH menu to beat the time! get their sweet potato fries, i like that one the best

excerpts: I had the Thai Coconut Shrimp with sweet potato fries.
People rave about the sweet potato fries and they are good, but I've had better.
You can't go wrong with the Shrimp.
thai coconut shrimp.author: Babette C.
thai coconut shrimp.review:
My sister comes here a lot when she's in the avenues to hang out with her friends.  She insisted that I try it.  I was reluctant, because I hate driving out to the avenues ad I abhor street parking in San Francisco, but I trust my sister's instincts when it comes to food, because she's as particular as I am.

It's places like this that makes me trust her.  This place was pretty good.  I'd give it 4 stars, but I hate crowded places and this place is crowded.  People love this place and the wait to get in is trying.  We must have missed the height of the dinner rush, because we were seated after 20 minutes.  

I had the Thai Coconut Shrimp with sweet potato fries.  People rave about the sweet potato fries and they are good, but I've had better.  You can't go wrong with the Shrimp.  My sister is addicted to the Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl with brown rice.  It looked like health food.  Yuck!  Then I tasted it.  It's tasty.  Taking one bite made me feel healthier.  We also had some of the Dulce de leche spring rolls a la mode, which was not greasy and very good.  Can't wait to try this place again.

excerpts: Personally I ordered the Thai Coconut Shrimp.
There was nothing Thai about it, and there was too much coconut.
I really like coconut shrimp, if balanced correctly.
It was not.
It was overwhelming
and I was barely able to finish it.
thai coconut shrimp.author: Calvin L.
thai coconut shrimp.review:
When I first found out i was going here to celebrate my girlfriend's sister's  birthday, I just had to look it up on yelp. The pictures here didn't look to good, decor wise. But to be honest, the decor was really nice. Very modern and the place was pretty spacious. 

The food is moderately priced, but I somehow wound up spending $40. The group ordered two rolls of sushi and I wasn't paying attention at the time, so I didn't know what either was called. One of them was very tasty, while the other was completely bland. 

Personally I ordered the Thai Coconut Shrimp. There was nothing Thai about it, and there was too much coconut. I really like coconut shrimp, if balanced correctly. It was not. It was overwhelming and I was barely able to finish it. The sweet potato fries were nothing special. They were sweet potato fries that could be made at home with no extra seasoning and taste the same. 

The service was good. Our waitress was on top of everything and the food came out pretty fast considering how crowded it was. And if you plan on celebrating a birthday here, it's a $10 fee if you bring a cake and have them bring it out and sing happy birthday. (To me, for them to sing happy birthday was nice, but makes the restaurant all the more generic). 

This place gets the 3 stars because of the good service, the decor, price and just below average food. My expectations weren't huge of this place, and the food matched what I thought it'd be. 
Would i come back? Sure, I'll give other menu items a try, but coconut shrimp will never be an option here.

excerpts: I had the Thai coconut shrimp skewers with sweet potato fries.
The shrimp was nothing special to write home about, but the sweet potato fries were excellent!
My husband had the unagi wasabi bowl and he seemed pretty satisfied after finishing off 3/4 of it.
thai coconut shrimp.author: Kelly R.
thai coconut shrimp.review:
If Pac Catch wasn't highlighted as kid-friendly resto, I probably would not have discovered this place.

Service was quick to accommodate our party of 7 (3 kids!) and to handout appetizers - pretzel goldfish and edamame. Lucky for us, my daughter LOVES goldfish, so that was able to tide her over until her meal came.

Food was good - not outstanding, but good. I had the Thai coconut shrimp skewers with sweet potato fries. The shrimp was nothing special to write home about, but the sweet potato fries were excellent! My husband had the unagi wasabi bowl and he seemed pretty satisfied after finishing off 3/4 of it. I had a bite of my daughter's fish & chips - tasty, not too greasy.

We were all too stuffed for dessert - perhaps on the next visit.

Definitely kid friendly, but they do not provide coloring materials as other restos would.

Didn't try the sushi, but with Ebisu up the street, why would you?

excerpts: Lot of choices (sake salmon, calamari, thai coconut shrimp,
tuna tataki etc etc...) if you like your meats and fish but not if you're vegetarian.
Most places in SF by now have a section on their menu for vegetarians.
Not here.
(Btw, I asked the waiter and she didn't have a suggestion off the menu for me as well)
Frustrated, I asked for peanut butter & jelly sandwich and they didn't have that.
thai coconut shrimp.author: ITesh J.
thai coconut shrimp.review:
This is a new restaurant in what was Canvas Cafe. (With it's live music night, relatively good food and nice booths/tables to park yourself with your laptop, Canvas was one of my fav spots in the Sunset.  But I remiss...) Anyway, so I'm headed to Pacific Catch because my SO is part of an acronym friends and family group (aka AF&F) and most of them are devout meat worshipers.  I mean they really, really like their meats and fish.  And don't suggest to me that fish is vegetarian.  Hello!  If it's got a face, moves and /or you keep it as a pet, it's not vegetarian.  So Pacific Catch has an upscale look and feel to the place. Nice decor, lighting and a friendly wait staff.  But the menu is not vegetarian friendly.  Lot of choices (sake salmon, calamari, thai coconut shrimp, tuna tataki etc etc...) if you like your meats and fish but not if you're vegetarian.  Most places in SF by now have a section on their menu for vegetarians. Not here. (Btw, I asked the waiter and she didn't have a suggestion off the menu for me as well)  Frustrated, I asked for peanut butter & jelly sandwich and they didn't have that. So I ended up with some starters and sides: wakame seaweed salad (kindda fishy), pineapple fried rice (kindda bland) and sweet potato fries (ok...the fries were good especially with their special dips).  Not very satisfying for $25 (w/ tips) per person bill.

Tip for Pacfic Catch.  Have something vegetarian. Something noodly on your menu. And if you can't do that, at least have peanut butter and jelly sandwich.  Is that asking for too much?

excerpts: had the calamari and thai coconut shrimp for starters then had the sturgeon with sweet potato fries and the hawaiian style surf and turf.
for dessert had the mochi fondo and another dessert with fried caramel thingy with vanilla ice cream.
wow.
everything was soooo good.
service was one of the best and the restaurant was very nice.
it was realltybusy and our food still came out really fast.
i couldnt stop saying "mmmm yummy
" i would definately come back.
i want to go right now again!
thai coconut shrimp.author: Cory Y.
thai coconut shrimp.review: food was excellent. had the calamari and thai coconut shrimp for starters then had the sturgeon with sweet potato fries and the hawaiian style surf and turf. for dessert had the mochi fondo and another dessert with fried caramel thingy with vanilla ice cream. wow. everything was soooo good. service was one of the best and the restaurant was very nice. it was realltybusy and our food still came out really fast. i couldnt stop saying "mmmm yummy" i would definately come back. i want to go right now again!

excerpts: We started with Cabo calamari which was made perfect accompanied with Spicy aioli sauce.
cabo calamari.author: Eyal B.
cabo calamari.review:
If your dad is in town ask for sea food, this is the place to go.
Great location near the golden gate park with great selection of fresh fish.
We started with Cabo calamari which was made perfect accompanied with Spicy aioli sauce.

My dad took the coho salmon with fries and I had the kanpachi which is one of he best Hawaiian fish you can find around.

Service was quick and efficient, will come back for sure !
Thanks

excerpts: Since there were seven of us in our party we had to get appetizers and the Cabo Calamari, as always, is an easy choice with crispy calamari, lemon slices, fresno chilies and chipotle aioli were decent if somewhat lackluster.
cabo calamari.author: Jason F.
cabo calamari.review:
Pacific Catch West Coast Fish House is a solid place to get good if unspectacular seafood dishes like soft tacos, poke and rice bowls and sushi rolls. This franchise lays in the heart of San Francisco's Inner Sunset neighborhood right off the of the 9th Avenue Entrance to Golden Gate Park. Pacific Catch is a fine franchise and it's been in this location for over ten years, so despite the competition of the surrounding neighborhood this place is doing just fine. But the question is, is it worth it?

I went for a pre-planned birthday party, so we were able to make reservations for our party of seven at 7pm on a Wednesday evening in July. Although I've been this restaurant before, I haven't been in a while and I like some of the newer things they've brought to the interior, like a nice outdoor fireplace in front of the vestibule area and all of the funky artwork on the walls and hanging from the ceilings. Upon opening the menu, I did notice that the prices are high at Pacific Catch. Be prepared to get sticker shock as this place does not represent the most affordable meals for families in or from out of town. The average price is sixteen dollars per main course, but the food was dependable and an interesting blend on the traditional seafood fusion dish. 

Since there were seven of us in our party we had to get appetizers and the Cabo Calamari, as always, is an easy choice with crispy calamari, lemon slices, fresno chilies and chipotle aioli were decent if somewhat lackluster. The Original Hawaiian Poke Trio was a nice surprise because it came in three ranges of flavors with ahi tuna and sesame-soy marinade spicy seasoning, but at 19 dollars isn't the most affordable starter meal on the menu. I do give credit to Pacific Catch as everything on the menu does sound unbelievably tasty, even their fish and chips dish is described with a mouth-watering sensibility.  

After thinking and thinking (and thinking) about what I wanted to get that would be a good representation of what Pacific Catch has to offer, I decided to go with the Island Tacos Trio mainly because at 16 dollars you can mix and match three any tacos on their menu. Although they all sounded decent, the three tacos I went with were the Traditional Baja Taco with its Crispy Alaskan Cod, cabbage jalapeno tartar, and avocado tomatillo salsa, the Spiced Chicken Taco with grilled Mary's Chicken, cabbage avocado, chipotle aioli and pico de gallo, and the Pacific Steak Taco with marinated skirt steak, crispy onions, cilantro cabbage, sriracha aioli and lime cream. All three were solid pics with a little spice, a little crunch, and a decent amount of flavor. 

Pacific Catch is a decent place with a thought-provoking menu that combines Asian Fusion, Tex-Mex and fresh seafood entrees. The service, ambiance, and overall quality and presentation of the dishes were basically all on point. I asked at the top is it worth it, and I have to admit at that rate the answer remains no because of the overall type of food being offered doesn't match up with the prices. I simply wish the price points were a little more friendlier to the average tourist that tends to frequent this neighborhood. I would consider going again, maybe for Happy Hour or a late night bite. But there are other more unique and mom and pop style options out there in the Inner Sunset area that are dying to be supported by the community and newcomers alike.

excerpts: Highlights were the peruvian ceviche, thai coconut shrimp, cabo calamari, let's get saucy, and shiso fine.
We ordered double of some of these (fatties, I know), but the other hh options are definitely more normal items you can get anywhere.
This is a great place for happy hour with great prices, and I would for sure recommend it!
cabo calamari.author: Jessica L.
cabo calamari.review:
My girlfriends and I came here for happy hour M-F 4-6pm, 10pm-close only in the bar area.

Hawaiian Poke (regular menu) - SO DELICIOUS! If you come here, you need to get a poke something. The poke cubes are bigger than normal, super fresh, and is so good.

Happy hour menu was all delicious! We ordered Spicy Pacific Martinis and Agave Margaritas, both good. I would recommend the martini on the rocks!

Highlights were the peruvian ceviche, thai coconut shrimp, cabo calamari, let's get saucy, and shiso fine. We ordered double of some of these (fatties, I know), but the other hh options are definitely more normal items you can get anywhere. This is a great place for happy hour with great prices, and I would for sure recommend it!

excerpts: The Cabo Calamari is delicious -- try the fried lemon that it comes with, so good!
Love their rice bowls and the Vietnamese Steak Sandwich is amazing (I order it almost every time).
The sushi has always been great, boyfriend
cabo calamari.author: Mariah O.
cabo calamari.review:
I love coming to Pacific Catch. It's on my way home from work and takeout is always fast, although I do prefer dining in when I get the chance. 
The Cabo Calamari is delicious -- try the fried lemon that it comes with, so good! 
Love their rice bowls and the Vietnamese Steak Sandwich is amazing (I order it almost every time). The sushi has always been great, boyfriend and I frequently order the Ecstasy Roll and the Tempura Shrimp. 
Their drinks are okay. Margaritas are alright but nothing to write home about (but enough to mention on Yelp I suppose). 
Customer service has always been friendly and prompt, and they seem to legitimately know their menu.

excerpts: Also give the Cabo Calamari a go, a dish that also has a hint of heat [fresh chilies].
You can ask for it to be extra  spicy or not so spicy,
cabo calamari.author: D. S.
cabo calamari.review:
First, I highly recommend to make a reservation or you will be waiting for a long time.
I am fan of their Hawaiian Poke Trio, I enjoy a dish that you can sample a variety of fusion of flavors. The poke is fresh and tasty. Also, to spicy things up try the Spicy Pacific cocktail. The cocktail has serrano chilies that are muddled, just enough heat for those who like just a hint of it. I my self always ask for it to be extra spicy and they always deliver on my requests.

Also give the Cabo Calamari a go, a dish that also has a hint of heat [fresh chilies]. You can ask for it to be extra  spicy or not so spicy,

excerpts: Thai Coconut Shrimp (it's okay, not bad though), Cabo Calamari (meh, nothing special), and
Fries (sweet potato & normal fries, both were decent, good enough for late night munchies).
We were enjoying our beers and some of their starters from the happy hour
UNTIL we saw the table next to us
(mind you - that came and sat AFTER us) getting served with sushi.
WHAT???
How are you going to tell us that we can't order sushi
and then only to see it get served to another table?
You're not only miscommunicating to us, but we also felt like you were treating us unfairly.
We asked to speak to the waitress, and all she could say was, "Oh, I meant we ran out of white rice, and can only serve sushi with brown rice.
"  WHAT???
If you told us that from the beginning, we would've even been okay with that.
But the fact that you didn't?
Lied to us and then got caught?
cabo calamari.author: Carena N.
cabo calamari.review:
I would've liked to give them at least 3 stars for the food, but I was really, really upset by the service that I had to dock them!  

My first experience here was a pleasant one until we were about to order and the first thing the waitress told us was that sushi was not available for order because the "sushi chef walked out on them."  WHAT???  But okay, we settled for the Peruvian Ceviche (which was super nomsy), Thai Coconut Shrimp (it's okay, not bad though), Cabo Calamari (meh, nothing special), and Fries (sweet potato & normal fries, both were decent, good enough for late night munchies).  We were enjoying our beers and some of their starters from the happy hour UNTIL we saw the table next to us (mind you - that came and sat AFTER us) getting served with sushi.  WHAT???  How are you going to tell us that we can't order sushi and then only to see it get served to another table?  You're not only miscommunicating to us, but we also felt like you were treating us unfairly.  We asked to speak to the waitress, and all she could say was, "Oh, I meant we ran out of white rice, and can only serve sushi with brown rice."  WHAT???  If you told us that from the beginning, we would've even been okay with that.  But the fact that you didn't?  Lied to us and then got caught?  WHAT???

Ugh, we made a complaint to the manager of the night about our experience there, and he tried to save himself by saying they had a shortage of rice and had found some more rice later but told his servers to make up lies meanwhile.  WHAT????  To make it up, he compensated each of us with a complimentary starter ticket and I gave you one star back for doing that, but honestly after my first experience there even with the complimentary starter ticket, I don't plan on coming back.

excerpts: The cabo calamari was good but not unique or better than other calamari dishes I have tried.
cabo calamari.author: Stephanie B.
cabo calamari.review:
Eh - so much hype for this place and it really wasn't allll that. 

It's cute they give you goldfish and edamame to munch on but kinda weird they give a small amount. But then again, you don't want to eat too much!

You MUST MUST MUST order the Hawaiian poke as an appetizer. It was my favorite dish of the night. The wonton chips were perfectly crispy and well cooked (also had a bit of a sweet flavor), and the ahi-tuna was melt in your mouth DELISH! I loved it. 

After the poke though, everything else fell kinda short.

The cabo calamari was good but not unique or better than other calamari dishes I have tried. Calamari is always the standard appetizer, but I say get the Hawaiian poke instead.

I ordered the mixed catch basket, which comes with coconut shrimp, fried oysters, fish, and sweet potato fries. I thought the coconut shrimp was kinda forgettable - something about it didn't wow me. The fish was definitely fresh but like the coconut shrimp, I was "whatever" about it. I did, oddly enough, really like the fried oyster. Maybe it's because it was the only thing in my basket that had tons of flavor? And the sweet potato fries were kinda cold? Or at least, they were not warm. I love sweet potato fries and mine were just bland in a way.

They also don't give you enough sauce for your food.

I'm hoping that maybe I ordered the wrong thing? Or maybe at the wrong time? I would just come back for the Hawaiian poke!

excerpts:
+++Peruvian Ceviche
-Thai Coconut Shrimp (they were just okay)
- - Cabo Calamari (soggy, stringy, not impressive)

+Hawaiian Poke - $9.5
cabo calamari.author: Julia D.
cabo calamari.review:
Yayyyy the only kitchen that is open in the Sunset on Fridays and Saturdays! 12pm woohooo!!!

After Izakaya Sozai completely SCREWED our reservation, we were frustrated AND hungry. Not a good combo. 

So for walkin in around 11:30pm on a friday, they have some pretty good deals on their "Bar Bites" happy hour until midnight...not too shabby.

+Agave Margarita $6
+Warm Edamame $4
++++Peruvian Ceviche
-Thai Coconut Shrimp (they were just okay)
- - Cabo Calamari (soggy, stringy, not impressive)

+Hawaiian Poke - $9.5 Worth it!

Conclusion: If I ever get screwed like that again, and really hungry late at night after a ravenous night of drinkin' it's alright to make an exception.

excerpts: but since I wasn't as hungry, I settled for an appetizer, the Cabo Calamari....

CABO CALAMARI Appetizer 

Dislike: SUPER OILY and fried.
cabo calamari.author: Eileen Z.
cabo calamari.review:
GREAT service. Our waitress was super nice and has a very friendly smile!  We came here with a large group and they accommodate us pretty quick on a semi-busy Sunday. 

FOOD: 

There are SOO many options on the menu and they all sounds good! Very hard to decide on what to get but since I wasn't as hungry, I settled for an appetizer, the Cabo Calamari....but I guess having a whole appetizer plate to myself is pretty much equivalent to a meal...

CABO CALAMARI Appetizer 

Dislike: SUPER OILY and fried.
LIKE: Fried red peppers and lemon slices! The fried lemon slices are very interesting and being a fan of lemons, I LOVE IT. (yes, the skin is also edible!) 

BIRTHDAYS:

One of our friend had a birthday recently and guess what, you get a FREE mochi ice-cream from the dessert menu on your BDAY! 

SETTING:

Very comfortable and somewhat artsy with amazing paintings on the wall and ceiling lights made from blue glass bottles! I LIKE. ( makes me wanna make something like that one day)

SPLITTING a meal with a friend?

Done. They even split the meal FOR you so you and your friend get your own portion in a separate bowl/plate!! HOW NICE.

I really enjoyed this place alot.

excerpts: The Cabo calamari was delicious.
Although they do mention that there was lemon slices, we didn't realize that some of them would be breaded and deep fried.
Anyhow, they add a great deal of flavour and the bit of spiciness (thanks to the chilies) was really good.
cabo calamari.author: Shauna S.
cabo calamari.review:
We came for a quick bite to eat and overall, gotta say that I'm quite happy with this place.

The Cabo calamari was delicious. Although they do mention that there was lemon slices, we didn't realize that some of them would be breaded and deep fried. Anyhow, they add a great deal of flavour and the bit of spiciness (thanks to the chilies) was really good. The spicy chipotle aioli was also very tasty (and tastes great with the fried fish if you manage to save some for when your entree arrives).

I had the California salmon sandwich and my BF had the fish and chips. After having the sesame slaw and side salad, I was quite full. I had a bit of my BF's fish and chips (he got the cod and spicy fries) and everything tasted great. I ended up getting the sandwich to go and later on for dinner I had half and it was delicious. Light, not too heavy with the sauce and the salmon tasted great.

excerpts:
Some of the many appetizers I've tried include:

Cabo Calamari ($9): fried calamari (both rings and tentacles, lemon slices and chilies);
cabo calamari.author: Samantha L.
cabo calamari.review:
I have been to Pacific Catch a number of times (mainly due to the fact that it's pretty close to UCSF) and it's consistently pretty good/"a-ok."  I've never actually come for dinner, because I think there are plenty of better (and more student-budget-friendly restaurants) in the area, but it is a great option for happy hour or just place to catch up with friends over a drink and appetizers.

The restaurant is pretty nice looking inside, yet casual.  If you dine-in, they give you a tray of pretzel goldfish and edamame.  Some of the many appetizers I've tried include:

Cabo Calamari ($9): fried calamari (both rings and tentacles, lemon slices and chilies); taste is pretty standard and it's served with a "spicy" chipotle aioli.  During my last visit, this was free via a Foursquare check-in offer.

Sweet Potato Fries ($6):  always delicious and served with interesting dipping sauces: ginger wasabi aioli and sweet Thai chili.  I prefer ketchup.  

Baja Shrimp Ceviche ($8.50):  a fair amount of shrimp, lime, cilantro and chilies, served in a martini glass and surrounded by tortilla chips.  This was pretty tasty, but not that stand-out is.  

Hawaiian Poke ($9.50): this is probably the only appetizer that actually shines.  The tuna is marinated in a sesame-soy marinade and served with crispy wonton chips.  It can be a bit salty, but just make sure you have a nice cocktail also.

Happy hour is 4-6 p.m. Monday through Friday and also 10 p.m. to close each night.  They have a fair selection of beer for $3-4, wells for $4.50 and a selection of appetizers as well.  The service is generally pretty helpful and I think overall, it's a pretty fun place to get snacks/drinks.

excerpts: For two of us, we ordered the Hawaiian Poke, Cabo Calamari, King crab leg soup, and traditional tacos with sweet potato fries.
My favorite was Hawaiian poke, sushi-grade ahi tuna in a sesame-soy marinade & spicy seasonings with wonton crisps, and Calamari.
cabo calamari.author: Stacy L.
cabo calamari.review:
Went there on Saturday for dinner, and we got seated right before the dinner crowded came in.  Finding parking is always challenge in Irving area at night, but we were lucky to find a parking in the parking lot. The dinner was great and the services was fast. For two of us, we ordered the Hawaiian Poke, Cabo Calamari, King crab leg soup, and traditional tacos with sweet potato fries. 
My favorite was Hawaiian poke, sushi-grade ahi tuna in a sesame-soy marinade & spicy seasonings with wonton crisps, and Calamari. To me, the ahi tuna got slightly too salty near the bottom of the bowl, I think it might be the soy sauces that marinade the fish. For dinner we ordered, the Fried Dulce de Leche "Spring Rolls", which spring roll that wrap with cluster or cheese cake filling.  And served with vanilla ice cream & caramel sauce....Yummy

excerpts: Spicy Cabo Calamari:
Pretty good but nothing too spectacular.
It was interesting that they also deep-fried slices of lemon and peppers.
The peppers were really yummy and SPICY...
hehe...
cabo calamari.author: Rose J.
cabo calamari.review:
The bar area was already packed at 4:15pm on a Friday but my bf and I were quickly seated to begin our happy hour experience.  We sat at one of the tables with the tall bar stools, which was quite uncomfortable as the bottom of the table was not hollow for our legs to fit into.  My knees kept hitting the sides of the table. 

Now for the food.  I was tempted to order everything on their Bar Bites menu but opted to have just the first 5 items (minus the edamame beans and sweet potato fries) and 2 refreshing cosmos - YUM YUM.  I have been here before but for some reason the food was not as good as I remembered.  I had the following in the order of favorite to least favorite:

Asparagus & Shiitake Roll: It was an interesting vegetarian take on a sushi roll and I found the asparagus tempura and the tiny strings of mushroom and carrot to be quite lovely.

Thai Coconut Shrimp: It's funny because when I had my first bite, I was like "OMG...it feels like a Thai restaurant in my mouth."  Now looking at the menu as I write this entry, the dish's name is quite befitting. The coconut flavors are so quintessentially Thai.  I loved the crunch of the crispy coconut flakes and the juicy shrimp.  Frankly, I ended up just eating the coconut flake outer layer instead of the shrimp because it was so good.  The sweet and sour dipping sauce (that you can buy at any Asian market) was a nice complement. 

Spicy Tuna Roll: This roll was actually spicy, which I appreciated.  It was yummy with the bitterness of the daikon sprouts.  

Hawaiian Poke:  This was a disappointment as everyone had been raving about it.  Mainly because the poke tasted so gummy.  It did not simply melt in my mouth and the chopped green onions were a bit too overpowering.  I do like my poke to be marinated for a few hours so that the fish really soaks up the flavors but I just felt it had been marinated too long.  And the crispy chips started to give me a headache...which I get when I eat too much fried food.  Disappointing.

Spicy Cabo Calamari:  Pretty good but nothing too spectacular.  It was interesting that they also deep-fried slices of lemon and peppers.  The peppers were really yummy and SPICY...hehe...I attempted to eat the lemons too, but I suggest you not do that.      

The food is pretty good and very well priced. They also played good music...love Bob Marley. :) I think I hyped myself up for this dining experience as I hadn't been here in a long time.  I probably won't go for a few months.  I'm sure I will start missing the Coconut Shrimp by then.

excerpts: We liked the Cabo Calamari which was fried and spicy, $8.95.
My fried oyster basket, $13.95 was too oily and the oysters were not firm.
Hubby and BFF's hubby had the Ahi 3 ways, $17.95, which they both liked.
cabo calamari.author: Ry T.
cabo calamari.review:
For the 2nd time, our friends tried to take us to a restaurant in the neighborhood  and it was closed.  So, we ended up by chance at Pacific Catch.  Our waiter was horribly slow.  It took him forever to take our orders.  We were all speculating that he was a laid off from a previous job as he didn't seem to have a handle on things.  Hubby even witnessed a younger waitress go up and punch in her orders while our waiter was still prodding along with his order on the computer.

The signature miso is to be avoided, $2.95.  We liked the Cabo Calamari which was fried and spicy, $8.95.  My fried oyster basket, $13.95 was too oily and the oysters were not firm.  Hubby and BFF's hubby had the Ahi 3 ways, $17.95, which they both liked.  Portions are filling and BFF's hubby tried the Mochi Fondue.  It was mochi balls filled with ice cream (you can buy these at Safeway nowadays), cut into quarters and served with a ramekin of hot chocolate dipping sauce.  It was OK, $5.95.  The other odd thing the waiter did was he gave BFF & her hubby their iced teas and an additional glass of ice for "refills".  In the end, the ice all melted into water and he had to go get them a fresh glass of iced tea with fresh ice.  Go figure.

excerpts: - Cabo Calamari (What? Messican Calamari??
Odd name but

all the same pretty good thought a wee bit greasy with the deep frying)
- Fish & Chips (Can't go wrong with this one...
actually, you can!
good but not as good as Woodhouse Fish Company)
cabo calamari.author: Amit S.
cabo calamari.review:
ACK! That's Marlin, Nemo and Dory you're serving on my plate, you freak!

... just kidding! 

This place is actually not that bad at all. Even months after they reopened, I could not make myself go in for the simple fact that I was an avid fan of the Canvas Gallery that occupied the space before, and to see it close was truly sad... I am in mourning...

... OK. Sob story over... back to me now...

... checked it out on a nice and sunny Sunday (those rare ones in the Inner Sunset when you can wear shorts, a tank and flip flops) and had a great time.

I recommend:
- Warm Edamame (sea salt is umm good!)
- House-made Miso Soup (dunno who'se "house" it was made in but they make it darn good)
- Hawaiian Poke (my FAV dish here! the tuna on the wonton crisp is just something else... this Hawaiian can poke me any ole time!)
- Cabo Calamari (What? Messican Calamari?? Odd name but all the same pretty good thought a wee bit greasy with the deep frying)
- Fish & Chips (Can't go wrong with this one... actually, you can! good but not as good as Woodhouse Fish Company)
- Teriyaki Bowl ((nice especially with bok choy, sprouts and nori!)
- Macadamia Nut Brownie (DROOL! DRIP!... nuf said!)
- Bloody Mary (Sunday and Bloody Mary's?? Ya betcha!)

Nice place, crowd (tourists, neighbors, folks from other hoods), kid friendly, dog friendly (outside), waiter service outdoors can be a bit iffy until you throw in some 'tude.

excerpts:
Spicy Cabo Calamari - crispy chili & lemon with spicy chipotle sauce
Warm Edamame - Hawaiian Alaea sea salt
Basket of Fries - "signature" sweet potato, traditional or spicy 

and yup
cabo calamari.author: Kapo T.
cabo calamari.review:
i m not a big asian fusion fan probably because i think asian food is traditional enough and shouldn't be made any different. i've been here 3 times and the food is OK. nothing great. the location is great if you need a snack from walking the GGP or the museums. (but there are other food to eat around there also).  

the only thing that i recommend is the happy hour here. on a nice sunny day, the bar and outside seating is packed.  happy hour is from 4p-6p so get your orders in before 6p.  

here's their HH menu: 
Hawaiian Poke - sushi-grade ahi tuna in a sesame-soy marinade & spicy seasonings with wonton crisps
Asparagus & Shiitake - asparagus tempura & shiitake mushrooms with miso dressing
Spicy Tuna - ahi tuna with sriracha mayo
Thai Coconut Shrimp - Thai sweet-chili sauce
Spicy Cabo Calamari - crispy chili & lemon with spicy chipotle sauce
Warm Edamame - Hawaiian Alaea sea salt
Basket of Fries - "signature" sweet potato, traditional or spicy 

and yup, we ordered 3 of everything on the HH menu to beat the time! get their sweet potato fries, i like that one the best

excerpts:
Here is what we ordered:
- Spicy Cabo Calamari | fried with fresh chilis and crispy lemon, served with a chipotle dipping sauce $8.95.
This was delicious.
The sauce might be too spicy for some.
cabo calamari.author: Amelia M.
cabo calamari.review:
I was never intending on going, but decided to try something new...  I walked in and couldn't believe this was my beloved Canvas Cafe once... I miss you Canvas!  They changed everything inside... it is decorated in warm colors and the light are really nice... they look like blue bottles... hmm... they could be bottles. They have lots of booths with comfortable cushions.  We were served by Misa who was really nice and very helpful. She made sure we had our fill of tea and was very attentive.  

Here is what we ordered:
- Spicy Cabo Calamari | fried with fresh chilis and crispy lemon, served with a chipotle dipping sauce $8.95. This was delicious. The sauce might be too spicy for some. The calamari rings were cooked to perfection (nothing worse than over cooked ring!)


- Mixed Catch Basket | 2 pieces of fresh fish, 4 coconut shrimp & 3 oysters with traditional fries $13.95. I would probably just order the Shrimp.  I liked the oysters, but it is not all that... I rather not eat my oysters fried.  The tartar sauce was great. I ordered the seasoned fries with this one.  They were very tasty. Next time I will try the sweet potatoes.  

- Teriyaki Bowl - Topped with asparagus, glazed shiitake mushrooms, grilled bok choy, sesame seeds & house-made teriyaki sauce served over pineapple fried rice with Fresh Salmon $13.95. This was ordered by my friends. I had some of the rice with the sauce and it tasted YUMMMY. 

- Mochi Fondu | vanilla, chocolate & coffee mochi ice cream with warm chocolate dipping sauce $5.50 When you get this dessert... eat fast... the hot chocolate makes it a bit difficult to get the mochi out of there before it melts down.  (Suggestion for restaurant owners/chefs - Perhaps if you use spoons or little ladle like utensils it would help save the bites from getting lost in the fondue. The wooden pick slips right off when dipped in the warm chocolate fondue after a few minutes.) I really loved this dessert... YUM! 

Total bill for two was a bit over $50. 

I would go back to try some other dishes.  It turned out to be a nice place to go. It does feel a bit chain like, but either way, I still enjoyed it.  I just don't feel like it fits in with the neighborhood.  I am used to the more wall in the hole feel.  Not a bad thing... it is just an observation. =)

excerpts: - Cabo Calamari: This is another dish we usually always try if it's on the menu.
We were quite disappointed.
Usually when you eat a piece of calamari without the sauce, it should still have some flavor from the breading its coated in, but this was just so...
BLAND.
Then when we dipped it in the sauce, it completely broke apart.
cabo calamari.author: Ashley C.
cabo calamari.review:
So my boyfriend took me here for Mother's Day because a friend suggested it. And EVERYONE we knew that has been there told us to get the sweet potato fries. 

The first thing that I noticed was that out of all the booths, the hostess sat us at one where I was literally blinded by the sunlight. I ended up sitting next to my boyfriend, which is nice, but I like sitting across from him so we can talk easier. Our waiter (his name totally slipped my mind, sorry!) was nice and attentive. Took our orders and our appetizers came out in like 10 minutes! Kind of threw me off on how fast it came out. 

we ordered: 

- Sweet Potato Fries: My boyfriend is a fries fiend so he totally enjoyed this. I'm not that big on fries, but I must admit that it was pretty delish. 

- Hawaiian Poke: My absolute fave of the night. I always have to try poke if a restaurant has it on their menu and this one totally hit the spot. Not as good as homemade, but close enough! Could do without the won ton chips. Would have been great with a seaweed salad. 

- Cabo Calamari: This is another dish we usually always try if it's on the menu. We were quite disappointed. Usually when you eat a piece of calamari without the sauce, it should still have some flavor from the breading its coated in, but this was just so...BLAND. Then when we dipped it in the sauce, it completely broke apart. No good. 

- Miso Glazed Salmon: Loved the crispy outside and buttery inside. Sauce, mushroom & edamame side, was delicious. The salad on the side was not to my liking. I don't know what it was, but the flavor was horrible and the texture was really tough. 

- Korean BBQ Steak: First of all, the waiter hadn't asked my boyfriend how he wanted it cooked. It came out medium rare which was fine though. Tim loved the flavor, but the meat was TOUGH. Don't think it was the way it was cooked, just that that particular cut of meat was tough. He also didn't like the salad. 

- Lemongrass Mojito: Pretty good. Bartender made it strong, just the way I like it. 

Overall, it was alright. If I were to go back it would be for the sweet potato fries, Hawaiian poke, and maybe to try the Wasabi Bowls and fish tacos.

excerpts: We started off with the Spicy Cabo Calamari, which was really soft in texture, definitely not crispy because the breaded exterior would fall off whenever we tried to pick at one; not spicy at all, it lacked much taste until i doused the heck out of it with the dipping sauce.
cabo calamari.author: Serena W.
cabo calamari.review:
Arrived here expecting just sushi. Their menu only consisted of about 5-7(?) plain-nothing-out-of-the-original sushi rolls. Then me and my friend realized Pacific Catch was a Japanese-Mexican fusion restaurant, but we decided to give it a try anyways since we were drooling over the food on the table next to us. 

We started off with the Spicy Cabo Calamari, which was really soft in texture, definitely not crispy because the breaded exterior would fall off whenever we tried to pick at one; not spicy at all, it lacked much taste until i doused the heck out of it with the dipping sauce. Then we also figured out they also added a few other concocsions that should have just been left outta the fryer.....like the fried lemon I accidently ate.....twice. 

My friend ordered the Mixed Catch Basket. There wasn't anything special about this, except the fact that her side of Sweet Potato Fries were YUMMY!!

I ordered the Ahi Tuna Wasabi Bowl, topped with (of course) ahi tuna, wakame salad, avocado, ginger and cucumber. The sushi rice was flavored with a wasabi sauce, which was somewhat mild, but SO GOOD!! It's basically like sushi, but bigger and broken down into all its components. 

We also ordered two drinks, a Mai Tai & forgot the name of the other one, but both were pretty strong!! I like! I like!

Gotta come back to try their Mojito & Mochi Fondue!!

4 stars for their strong drinks, my Ahi Tuna Wasabi bowl and my friend's sweet potato fries!


[UPDATED: 4.26.2008]

Came here again with another friend around 8ish. Considering it was a Friday, there was a 30 min. wait for the tables inside, so we decided to dine outside, which turned out really nice...although it was butt-freezing cold at first. Thank god they had the protective sheet to block off most of the wind. 

Tried the Ahi Poke Wasabi bowl this time and it was delicious! Although I did like my Ahi Tuna from my last dining here, I would recommend the Ahi Poke over that. My Lemon Grass Mojito was refreshing as well. My friend's Gin & Tonic was pretty stiff.

Service was still attentive, friendly, consistent and quick. The bar was open till 1AM that day, but too bad we couldn't stay for another round of  drinks considering my friend had the Asian glow by the time he finished his Gin & Tonic. -sigh-

excerpts:
Cabo Calamari
Seared Ahi Bowl
Hawaiian Poke Bowl
cabo calamari.author: Jessica B.
cabo calamari.review:
I used to come here whenever I had disposable 20 and wanted to treat myself to some qual-it- A food. I've had fun happy hour times with some friends and even quick one drink hang outs. I had not eaten here in over a year and was excited when the opportunity came to indulge in a yummy lunch. After Bay to Breakers, my friends went to Gordos (YUM) and I chose to order take out from Pacific Catch. I requested the seared ahi rice bowl.  Excited to chow down, I ran to Gordos and proceeded to stuff my face. However, one thing felt wrong. The fish did not taste the same. Again, here is another place that overloads on the sodium to masque the taste of their food. Not only was the fish too salty, but there was something fishy about the fish. After a while, I decided to cease my "chow down" and wrapped the food back into the bag. There is a huge problem if I order food and do not devour the entire thing. This means I either am not hungry or the food does not taste good. Thinking that I must not have been hungry, I decided to eat the bowl later that day. From the moment I went to my bfs house to later that afternoon, my stomach was hurting. I assumed it was due to the hangover from B2B, but it did not make sense. I went to go finish the bowl and figured out my stomach was hurting from the food. Pretty sad. The bowls used to be enjoyable.

What I have eaten here: 
Baja Shrimp Ceviche
Sweet Potato Fries (Get them!)
Cabo Calamari
Seared Ahi Bowl
Hawaiian Poke Bowl

I'll keep the rating 3/5 because this could have been the one bad experience. I was always a fan of Pacific Catch, but I may need to take a permanent break from them. SORRY!

excerpts: We started out with the Cabo Calamari which was amazing.
It had just the right amount of batter on it, not greasy and came with a delicous spicy aioli sauce for dipping.
They actually bring you a side of edamame and pretzels to start with which I thought would be an odd combination but its really nice together.
I ordered the mai tai which was kind of sweet but really good.
Their service was great, fast , friendly, not over bearing or neglectful, just the right amount of attention.
My boyfriend ordered the fish and chips and I ordered the coconut shrimp..
MY shrimp was the perfect blend of sweet and crunchy and I actually used the sauce from the calamari which was delicious on the sweet shrimp.
cabo calamari.author: Chelsey L.
cabo calamari.review: I have heard mixed reviews of this restaurant from people so I finally decided to check it out last night.  We walked in around 7 and even though it looked pretty full we were seated within a few minutes.  The whole placeis very open and you can see the kitchen or bar form anywhere in the restaurant which I really like.  We started out with the Cabo Calamari which was amazing. It had just the right amount of batter on it, not greasy and came with a delicous spicy aioli sauce for dipping.  They actually bring you a side of edamame and pretzels to start with which I thought would be an odd combination but its really nice together.   I ordered the mai tai which was kind of sweet but really good.  Their service was great, fast , friendly, not over bearing or neglectful, just the right amount of attention.  My boyfriend ordered the fish and chips and I ordered the coconut shrimp..MY shrimp was the perfect blend of sweet and crunchy and I actually used the sauce from the calamari which was delicious on the sweet shrimp.  It came with sweet potato fries which also were not greasy.  His fish and chips were delicious! The fish was perfect, not the kind that tastes fishy, but a good crisp light flavor.  Also the coleslaw was awesome.  Sometimes it can be too flavorful with too much mayo.  It was just a nice light refreshing accent to the rest of the dish.   Just everything was great, the service, atmosphere and food. i would definitely check this place out!!!!

excerpts: We had the Korean Sticky Ribs and Calamari for our appetizers.
The meat on the ribs were flavorful, but a bit tough and overly sweet.
The calamari pieces were way too oily and small.
Next came our entrees:
Crispy Alaskan Cod, an ahi poke salad, an ahi poke bowl, Dungeness Crab Melt, and a 3-taco plate.
I can only vouche for the Crispy Alaskan Cod, which was not crispy at all.
The cod arrived soggy and the salad and coleslaw that accompanied
it was overly dressed.
On the plus side, the entrees were nicely presented.
korean sticky ribs.author: Aimee I.
korean sticky ribs.review: This place is just okay. The decor is contemporary and interesting, but the food is mediocre. We had the Korean Sticky Ribs and Calamari for our appetizers. The meat on the ribs were flavorful, but a bit tough and overly sweet. The calamari pieces were way too oily and small. Next came our entrees: Crispy Alaskan Cod, an ahi poke salad, an ahi poke bowl, Dungeness Crab Melt, and a 3-taco plate. I can only vouche for the Crispy Alaskan Cod, which was not crispy at all. The cod arrived soggy and the salad and coleslaw that accompanied it was overly dressed. On the plus side, the entrees were nicely presented.

excerpts: We shared the Korean sticky ribs and the sweet potato fries for appetizer.
The sweet potato fries were really good and not too greasy like I had at many other places.
The sticky ribs were marinated well, but I didn't get too much meat from it.
korean sticky ribs.author: Wendy F.
korean sticky ribs.review:
Lovely Asian-fusion diner! Love their Ahi Tuna salad!!!

FOOD: We shared the Korean sticky ribs and the sweet potato fries for appetizer. The sweet potato fries were really good and not too greasy like I had at many other places. The sticky ribs were marinated well, but I didn't get too much meat from it. For entree I got the Ahi Tuna salad. It had a good mix of greens, avocado, sauteed cabbages, and 4 big piece of Ahi Tuna. Everything tasted great when mixed all together, with the soy-wasabi vinaigrette. My friend tried the Pacific Crab Salad (with real crab meat) and it was great too!

SERVICE: We came here on a Tuesday evening and was seated immediately. Very friendly waiter and food came by within reasonable time.

SETTING: I really like how spacious it is on the inside and also its ambient lighting. They have nice interior decors and there is also an outdoor patio where you can sit and dine (heat lamp provided during the freezing SF nights). Parking is probably impossible so just take Lyft or the muni. 

OVERALL IMPRESSION: I like it! I always run past this place but never really knew how tasty the food is. Will come back again for sure!

excerpts: We've tried the Korean sticky ribs, Kona coffee ribs, fried calamari, shrimp ceviche (my favorite), the poke trio with the California, original, and white tuna, the salmon poke, and the spicy tuna sushi roll.
The Kona coffee ribs were amazing
but I think were only around for a limited time.
The sushi rolls were just mediocre, this isn't a sushi joint
so I would stay away from the rolls and stick to the poke.
The original poke is a little too salty
but it's tolerable if you pair with rice
, the white tuna poke was a little on the dry side, I would've liked more liquid/lemon on it
and it had a really "fishy" taste, the California was probably the best, and the salmon poke was good but a bit on the spicy side.
and it had a really "fishy" taste, the California was probably the best, and the salmon poke was good but a bit on the spicy side.
For entrees we've had the poke salad (amazing), the Thai curry bowl with salmon (also amazing it was one of the best salmons I've ever had), and the teriyaki bowl with steak.
To be honest I would stick to what they know best which is probably fish.
The steak was just ok
and they weren't very generous with the portions.
It was more rice and a whole lot of other stuff on it like pineapples, edamame, carrots, shiitake mushrooms, and A LOT of fried onions.
I do have to say tho that the teriyaki sauce they use is delicious, I couldn't stop eating the rice.
korean sticky ribs.author: Linz C.
korean sticky ribs.review:
I've been here a couple of times and I must say they have one of the best happy hour menus!  They even give you edamame and goldfish pretzels to snack on! 

We've tried the Korean sticky ribs, Kona coffee ribs, fried calamari, shrimp ceviche (my favorite), the poke trio with the California, original, and white tuna, the salmon poke, and the spicy tuna sushi roll.  The Kona coffee ribs were amazing but I think were only around for a limited time. The sushi rolls were just mediocre, this isn't a sushi joint so I would stay away from the rolls and stick to the poke.  The original poke is a little too salty but it's tolerable if you pair with rice, the white tuna poke was a little on the dry side, I would've liked more liquid/lemon on it and it had a really "fishy" taste, the California was probably the best, and the salmon poke was good but a bit on the spicy side.  The poke trio also comes with wonton chips, a small salad, and a delicious seaweed salad. 

For entrees we've had the poke salad (amazing), the Thai curry bowl with salmon (also amazing it was one of the best salmons I've ever had), and the teriyaki bowl with steak.  To be honest I would stick to what they know best which is probably fish.  The steak was just ok and they weren't very generous with the portions. It was more rice and a whole lot of other stuff on it like pineapples, edamame, carrots, shiitake mushrooms, and A LOT of fried onions.  I do have to say tho that the teriyaki sauce they use is delicious, I couldn't stop eating the rice.

excerpts: We started with the Korean Sticky Ribs.
That was tasty but a bit messy
(it's nice
they have napkins and wet naps to clean off your hands).
korean sticky ribs.author: Phillip D.
korean sticky ribs.review:
Finally tried this place after seeing so many friends frequent this restaurant.  I can't believe I only tried this place now. 

First of all, I love that they have a variety of "Pacific Rim" cuisine.  Everything from Hawaiian to Japanese to Korean, we actually tried a bit of all three.  We came on a Wednesday evening (just missed the Happy Hour). We started with the Korean Sticky Ribs. That was tasty but a bit messy (it's nice they have napkins and wet naps to clean off your hands).  We then ordered the Sunset Sushi Roll (which comes in 8 pieces) and Poke Fest Trio (we tried the original, California, and the Macadamia Nut).  I personally liked the Macadamia Nut and Original Poke. I think the California Poke was too citrusy (is that a word).  

I definitely want to try their happy hour (see what deals I can get). They have happy hour both from 4-6 M-F and 10-close! Great for those late night eats. Also, I have to try their rice bowl. From what I saw, they are HUGE! 

Our server (forgot her name) was real nice and pretty attentive. I don't think it was too busy but even if, good service always makes the meal (and review) even better  

They technically have a parking lot in the rear but it's usually full but at least it's an option in the busy inner sunset. 

Definitely a place to come again.

excerpts: We started with the Korean sticky ribs (yummy and finger licking good)!
I had the chicken and steak island tacos after for my meal.
The tacos were good (better flavor than I remember from last time) and were filling.
Also had a Foursquare newbie check in special for a free dessert.
korean sticky ribs.author: Miss H K.
korean sticky ribs.review:
4 1/2 years later...and I return!
Came here today to celebrate my mom's bday for lunch. Had no problem making a reservation on Opentable. 
This location is larger than some of the other PC's I've seen and has a nice, modern and casual atmosphere. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive and our dining experience was very nice overall.
We started with the Korean sticky ribs (yummy and finger licking good)! I had the chicken and steak island tacos after for my meal. The tacos were good (better flavor than I remember from last time) and were filling. Also had a Foursquare newbie check in special for a free dessert. We had the chocolate macadamia nut brownie sundae (my least favorite part of the meal...pretty dry and not very moist-but it was free).
Overall the food and service was good. I'd recommend this place for asian fusion or seafood if in the area. Nice place for small groups or a date.

excerpts: the breakdown of the 4 stars: 3 for the korean sticky ribs and 5 for the hawaiian poke half-half bowl for an average of 4. let's start with the bad...the "ribs" were tough, not melting off the bone like i had envisioned.
they looked and tasted more like pork chops than ribs.
the best part of the appetizer was the sweet sticky sauce.
not too salty with lots of flavor.
now to the gooooood...
and it's pretty damn good.
the hawaiian poke over half brown rice and half greens has become my go-to healthy meal now.
like a japanese style bibimbap, it's loaded with seaweed salad, pickled ginger, avocado slices, and big chunks of yummy poke.
are you salivating yet??
korean sticky ribs.author: Melissa Y.
korean sticky ribs.review: the breakdown of the 4 stars: 3 for the korean sticky ribs and 5 for the hawaiian poke half-half bowl for an average of 4. let's start with the bad...the "ribs" were tough, not melting off the bone like i had envisioned. they looked and tasted more like pork chops than ribs. the best part of the appetizer was the sweet sticky sauce. not too salty with lots of flavor. now to the gooooood...and it's pretty damn good. the hawaiian poke over half brown rice and half greens has become my go-to healthy meal now. like a japanese style bibimbap, it's loaded with seaweed salad, pickled ginger, avocado slices, and big chunks of yummy poke. are you salivating yet??

excerpts: A starter salad
starter salad.author: Nathan Y.
starter salad.review:
I came here for a company dinner, which mainly consisted of delicious appetizers.

For appetizers, we had:
A starter salad
The california roll: It was pretty generous for a basic roll and was very filling.
Baja shrimp ceviche: A very delicious shrimp dish. Recommended.
Ahi tuna poke: Those wonton chips were amazing, but the Ahi tuna poke was even better. The tuna was very fresh and tender. Highly-recommended.

For my entree, I had a Japanese wasabi rice bowl with seared Ahi tuna: The wasabi taste was light but definitely noticeable. It blended very well with the included salad. Similar to the Ahi tuna poke appetizer, the tuna was delicious. It had great texture and a very juicy taste.

The restaurant had good service and gave very generous portions for appetizers and entrees. (I was beyond stuffed)

I was quite impressed and look forward to returning to one of their many locations in the Bay Area.

excerpts: I noticed their original is always good.
original.author: Darlene T.
original.review:
I don't know what has been happening lately, but Pacific Catch's poke quality has been bad the past 3 visits.

I come specifically because their poke is usually fresh. I noticed their original is always good. However, the California poke use to be my favorite. The first time I actually had to get it sent back. The second and third, I sucked it up. Poke is one of my favorite food and I am 100% sure it was not fresh.

excerpts: Despite an original restaurant with a point of view being our preferred dining experience, we can give credit to a chain restaurant and even seek it out, if it's a good one.
original.author: Rachel H.
original.review:
With seven restaurants in the Bay Area, Pacific Catch can only be called a chain restaurant, with all that that moniker conveys.  I am not a fan of chains.  But what chains lack in charm they usually make up for (if they are good) in consistency of experience.  From that standpoint, Pacific Catch is on the higher end of the curve for what a chain restaurant experience can be.

This location in the Sunset is always crowded and has systems in place (a buzzer) to notify waiting guests when a table is ready. I actually hate to dine with a buzzer, but I have to admit that I do like an efficient process and getting seated, so there are trade offs certainly.

On the plus side, we were seated quickly, ordered quickly and the fresh seafood was solid. Some things were, in fact, an excellent value (the fresh Crab Melt for example) while other things arrived and we found them disappointingly small.  Their ceviche was fresh and well seasoned, but uncommonly small down what can only be described as a minuscule handful of chips.

As a local chain, Pacific Catch certainly has more upside than down.  Despite an original restaurant with a point of view being our preferred dining experience, we can give credit to a chain restaurant and even seek it out, if it's a good one.

excerpts: The original restaurant was where we ate the second time and it was not nearly as good.
The menu is smaller and it was explained that was because the kitchen is smaller.
While on the way to the restroom, I walked by a shelf in the hall that had two vats of uncovered sauce and also a square clear plastic container that held a big plastic bag of frozen fish.
I placed my hand on the side of the vat and the water was warm.
Not a good way to thaw any kind of meat.
I was also surprised that they weren't using fresh fish for all of their meals.
Our waiter was pretty good and attentive.
But the food, was just so-so.
original.author: E T.
original.review: We ate at two Pacific Catch restaurants. The newer one was pretty tasty. One in our group had the crabcakes salad and really enjoyed it. The original restaurant was where we ate the second time and it was not nearly as good. The menu is smaller and it was explained that was because the kitchen is smaller. While on the way to the restroom, I walked by a shelf in the hall that had two vats of uncovered sauce and also a square clear plastic container that held a big plastic bag of frozen fish. I placed my hand on the side of the vat and the water was warm. Not a good way to thaw any kind of meat. I was also surprised that they weren't using fresh fish for all of their meals. Our waiter was pretty good and attentive. But the food, was just so-so.

excerpts: The Original Hawaiian Poke Trio was a nice surprise because it came in three ranges of flavors with ahi tuna and sesame-soy marinade spicy seasoning, but at 19 dollars isn't the most affordable starter meal on the menu.
original.author: Jason F.
original.review:
Pacific Catch West Coast Fish House is a solid place to get good if unspectacular seafood dishes like soft tacos, poke and rice bowls and sushi rolls. This franchise lays in the heart of San Francisco's Inner Sunset neighborhood right off the of the 9th Avenue Entrance to Golden Gate Park. Pacific Catch is a fine franchise and it's been in this location for over ten years, so despite the competition of the surrounding neighborhood this place is doing just fine. But the question is, is it worth it?

I went for a pre-planned birthday party, so we were able to make reservations for our party of seven at 7pm on a Wednesday evening in July. Although I've been this restaurant before, I haven't been in a while and I like some of the newer things they've brought to the interior, like a nice outdoor fireplace in front of the vestibule area and all of the funky artwork on the walls and hanging from the ceilings. Upon opening the menu, I did notice that the prices are high at Pacific Catch. Be prepared to get sticker shock as this place does not represent the most affordable meals for families in or from out of town. The average price is sixteen dollars per main course, but the food was dependable and an interesting blend on the traditional seafood fusion dish. 

Since there were seven of us in our party we had to get appetizers and the Cabo Calamari, as always, is an easy choice with crispy calamari, lemon slices, fresno chilies and chipotle aioli were decent if somewhat lackluster. The Original Hawaiian Poke Trio was a nice surprise because it came in three ranges of flavors with ahi tuna and sesame-soy marinade spicy seasoning, but at 19 dollars isn't the most affordable starter meal on the menu. I do give credit to Pacific Catch as everything on the menu does sound unbelievably tasty, even their fish and chips dish is described with a mouth-watering sensibility.  

After thinking and thinking (and thinking) about what I wanted to get that would be a good representation of what Pacific Catch has to offer, I decided to go with the Island Tacos Trio mainly because at 16 dollars you can mix and match three any tacos on their menu. Although they all sounded decent, the three tacos I went with were the Traditional Baja Taco with its Crispy Alaskan Cod, cabbage jalapeno tartar, and avocado tomatillo salsa, the Spiced Chicken Taco with grilled Mary's Chicken, cabbage avocado, chipotle aioli and pico de gallo, and the Pacific Steak Taco with marinated skirt steak, crispy onions, cilantro cabbage, sriracha aioli and lime cream. All three were solid pics with a little spice, a little crunch, and a decent amount of flavor. 

Pacific Catch is a decent place with a thought-provoking menu that combines Asian Fusion, Tex-Mex and fresh seafood entrees. The service, ambiance, and overall quality and presentation of the dishes were basically all on point. I asked at the top is it worth it, and I have to admit at that rate the answer remains no because of the overall type of food being offered doesn't match up with the prices. I simply wish the price points were a little more friendlier to the average tourist that tends to frequent this neighborhood. I would consider going again, maybe for Happy Hour or a late night bite. But there are other more unique and mom and pop style options out there in the Inner Sunset area that are dying to be supported by the community and newcomers alike.

excerpts:
$12.50 Hawaiian Poke with wonton chips - original ahi tuna, sesame-soy marinade, spicy seasonings:
A small bowl of juicy ahi cubes covered in sesame seeds and micro greens are accompanied with some fried wontons.
original.author: Joy W.
original.review:
I've been here several times over the past few years and I've come to the conclusion that it's never a bad time to have some tasty ahi, as long as it tastes fresh. The menu features mainly California seafood dishes with some Asian fusion touches here and there. This corner venue is large and spacious with very high ceilings, but they keep the place pretty cold. There is also some cozy outdoor seating under some heaters, but keep in mind, it is right next to the bus stop. 

They start you off with some complimentary shelled edamame and pretzel goldfish, which is a cute nod to the seafood menu, but I'd still prefer bread. I also think edamame is more enjoyable with the shell on.

$16.50 Japanese Wasabi rice bowl w/ Hawaiian poke - seaweed salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds, shredded nori, soy-wasabi sauce:
The bowl has a decent portion of bite-size chunks of sweet, juicy tuna. The soy-wasabi sauce is mild and not too strong on the wasabi. It is also seasoned with green onions, chives, and sesame seeds. Everything tastes fresh including the pale slivers of creamy avocado and crunchy, crisp seaweed salad. Be sure to get a little bit of everything in each bite, otherwise you're left with a lots of rice at the bottom of the bowl. 

$15.50 Ahi Tuna Salad w/ seared ahi, greens & romaine, avocado, cucumber, daikon sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds, soy-wasabi vinaigrette:
When I want something lighter, I'll go for the salad. The ingredients are pretty much the same, but with lettuce instead of rice. But with a salad, I go for the seared tuna instead of poke, because it creates the illusion of a meatier salad. Again, try to eat a little of everything together, otherwise you're left with a ton of greens, or as my friend calls it, 'rabbit food.'

A lot of people like the sweet potato fries. They're alright, but sweet potato fries are becoming a ubiquitous offering across the board.

Happy hour deals are pretty good if you are in the area in the afternoons. Poke is about $8.

$9 Baja Shrimp Ceviche - lime, serrano chili, avocado, cilantro, tortilla chips:
These bite-size shrimp are springy, meaty and seasoned well. The verde sauce is on the runny side and is quite spicy. I could eat this on its own without tortilla chips too, but the thin, crunchy chips make a nice vehicle.

$12.50 Hawaiian Poke with wonton chips - original ahi tuna, sesame-soy marinade, spicy seasonings:
A small bowl of juicy ahi cubes covered in sesame seeds and micro greens are accompanied with some fried wontons.

$7 Mochi Fondue - vanilla, chocolate, coffee mochi balls & chocolate dipping sauce:
I've tried this out of curiosity, but if you've ever had store-bought mochi ice cream balls, I'd say skip it. The taste is pretty similar with the addition of a little bowl of chocolate sauce on the side for dipping.

The tasty rice bowls are still my go-to items to order here. If I were in the area, I'd come back to try some of the other menu items too.

excerpts: poke trio (original is my favorite)
-calamari

(it's okay)
-poke
original.author: Corinna T.
original.review:
I've been here multiple times, and enjoy this place for several reasons:

1. It's good for larger parties since the place is spacious and the wait time isn't too long.

2. Happy hour 4-6pm M-F on a variety of appetizers and drinks.

3. Wine bottles half off on Tuesdays? A server told me yesterday. It could be a temporary special.

4. Heated outdoor patio and garage.

I have tried and liked:
-the poke trio (original is my favorite)
-calamari (it's okay)
-poke rice bowls
-fish and chips 

Service is hit or miss. I had some pretty monotone servers yesterday. But, overall, you can't go wrong with Pacific Catch.

excerpts: I've tried the original and the salmon avocado.
original.author: Jenna G.
original.review:
Honestly this place is so good. I've been to both the Marina and sunset location. Their poke is so fresh and good. I've tried the original and the salmon avocado. I also tried their mahi mahi tacos with sweet potato fries. Everything was solid. 

It is a little pricey because it's seafood, but I will keep coming back here for poke.

excerpts: original Hawaiian (ahi tuna), salmon avocado Hawaiian , and the serrano Hawaiian...
I preferred the Serrano Hawaiian
original.author: Dee R.
original.review:
I guess this place is a chain restaurant. Went here for lunch . The place has a nice ambiance. Food was mediocre...

I had the fish and chips with sweet potato fries. It was an Alaskan Cod...quite greasy...lacked salt but the jalapeño sauce that it came with balanced out the blandness. 

My friend had the trio poke...original Hawaiian (ahi tuna), salmon avocado Hawaiian , and the serrano Hawaiian...I preferred the Serrano Hawaiian

excerpts: They serve a Jalapeno tartar sauce that had an original flavor, but I also had the vinegar.
original.author: Charles A.
original.review:
This is a very good seafood restaurant located on a busy intersection in the Inner-Sunset area of San Francisco. It's across the street from Golden Gate park and close to many other restaurants.

We went in around 5:30 pm on a Saturday and were given one of those electronic devices that vibrates to let you know you're ready to be seated. The odd thing was that we waited almost a half-hour, but we noticed that there were about 7 or 8 tables available. We were there almost an hour and only a few people sat at those tables, so they weren't reserved. Our only guess was that maybe they were short-staffed and were "filtering" people in, but it appeared to be a time-waste for waiting customers.

We had the fish and shrimp tacos, french fries and fried cod. The tacos were very good and the fried fish was great. They serve a Jalapeno tartar sauce that had an original flavor, but I also had the vinegar. 

The service was excellent and the atmosphere was warm and inviting. They also had sushi and ahi poke, which looked good, although we didn't try it - maybe next time.

excerpts: We've tried the Korean sticky ribs, Kona coffee ribs, fried calamari, shrimp ceviche (my favorite), the poke trio with the California, original, and white tuna, the salmon poke, and the spicy tuna sushi roll.
The Kona coffee ribs were amazing
but I think were only around for a limited time.
The sushi rolls were just mediocre, this isn't a sushi joint
so I would stay away from the rolls and stick to the poke.
The original poke is a little too salty
but it's tolerable if you pair with rice
, the white tuna poke was a little on the dry side, I would've liked more liquid/lemon on it
and it had a really "fishy" taste, the California was probably the best, and the salmon poke was good but a bit on the spicy side.
and it had a really "fishy" taste, the California was probably the best, and the salmon poke was good but a bit on the spicy side.
For entrees we've had the poke salad (amazing), the Thai curry bowl with salmon (also amazing it was one of the best salmons I've ever had), and the teriyaki bowl with steak.
To be honest I would stick to what they know best which is probably fish.
The steak was just ok
and they weren't very generous with the portions.
It was more rice and a whole lot of other stuff on it like pineapples, edamame, carrots, shiitake mushrooms, and A LOT of fried onions.
I do have to say tho that the teriyaki sauce they use is delicious, I couldn't stop eating the rice.
original.author: Linz C.
original.review:
I've been here a couple of times and I must say they have one of the best happy hour menus!  They even give you edamame and goldfish pretzels to snack on! 

We've tried the Korean sticky ribs, Kona coffee ribs, fried calamari, shrimp ceviche (my favorite), the poke trio with the California, original, and white tuna, the salmon poke, and the spicy tuna sushi roll.  The Kona coffee ribs were amazing but I think were only around for a limited time. The sushi rolls were just mediocre, this isn't a sushi joint so I would stay away from the rolls and stick to the poke.  The original poke is a little too salty but it's tolerable if you pair with rice, the white tuna poke was a little on the dry side, I would've liked more liquid/lemon on it and it had a really "fishy" taste, the California was probably the best, and the salmon poke was good but a bit on the spicy side.  The poke trio also comes with wonton chips, a small salad, and a delicious seaweed salad. 

For entrees we've had the poke salad (amazing), the Thai curry bowl with salmon (also amazing it was one of the best salmons I've ever had), and the teriyaki bowl with steak.  To be honest I would stick to what they know best which is probably fish.  The steak was just ok and they weren't very generous with the portions. It was more rice and a whole lot of other stuff on it like pineapples, edamame, carrots, shiitake mushrooms, and A LOT of fried onions.  I do have to say tho that the teriyaki sauce they use is delicious, I couldn't stop eating the rice.

excerpts: Trio poke: we ordered the original, Serrano, and macadamia nut.
The tuna was super fresh, my favorite was the Serrano which was a creamy spicy sauce.
I didn't care too much for the macadamia nut
, it was too salty/soy sauce.
original.author: Bin X.
original.review:
Ambiance: 4.5 (super spacious and not a long wait) 

Service: 4 (fast and knowledgable)

Food: 3

Trio poke: we ordered the original, Serrano, and macadamia nut. The tuna was super fresh, my favorite was the Serrano which was a creamy spicy sauce. I didn't care too much for the macadamia nut, it was too salty/soy sauce. It's a good appetizer to sample their numerous poke selections.

Wasabi bowl (ahi tuna): you have the option of choosing brown rice and 1/2 rice&1/2 veggies no extra charge. An otherwise healthy balanced dish with a good variety of veggies, protein, and carbs was drenched in too much sauce. The portion is very generous and it'd be a perfect, perfect dish if they laid off on the sauce a bit. 

I will definitely come back here again and maybe ask for sauce on the side or light sauce for the bowls and try the other poke. As you can tell by the photos, pretty much all the dishes are visually stunning (esp the wasabi bowls), I feel healthier already just by looking at it.

excerpts: I ordered an original Poke and grill salmon teriyaki rice bowl.
The poke was not so fresh, darker than the ones I ate at the Marina Store, and not as chewy.
The Salmon was alright, but the rice was too sticky and the sauce was too sour.
original.author: Yuyang Z.
original.review:
Well, not so as what I have expected. The service was fast, but servers turn away fast and not much enthusiasm serving. The whole restaurant was big and open. I ordered an original Poke and grill salmon teriyaki rice bowl. The poke was not so fresh, darker than the ones I ate at the Marina Store, and not as chewy. The Salmon was alright, but the rice was too sticky and the sauce was too sour. I ended up packing up almost the whole rice bowl and brought it home to cook it over. 

Maybe this is just individual case, but I feel like although Marina store is much smaller than here, but I'd say Marina is serving in better quality.

excerpts:
[ F O O D ]
- ORIGINAL HAWAIIAN POKE - yummmy!
must get!

I love the combination of avocado, tuna, seaweed salad, etc.
- Fish and Chip - I've had better but its not bad here...
I liked the Jalepeno tartar.
original.author: Tammy F.
original.review:
We came for a Mother's Day Dinner with my Mom and brother. We made a reservation and waited about 15 minutes for our table. 

[ S E R V I C E ] 
- Our waitress Chelsea is super friendly. She came back to check on us multiple time. GREAT SERVICE!

[ F O O D ]
- ORIGINAL HAWAIIAN POKE - yummmy!! must get! I love the combination of avocado, tuna, seaweed salad, etc.
- Fish and Chip - I've had better but its not bad here...I liked the Jalepeno tartar.
- Calfornia Salmon Sandwich - my brother said it was one of the best sandwich he ever had.
- Sweet potato fries - yummy
- Sticky Ribs Korean BBQ - I liked it! Finger-lickin' good!

[ A M B I A N C E ]
- Bar is nice with TVs so you can watch the game.
- Restaurant seemed cleaned.
- Spacious! I love the booths!

[ P A R K I N G ]
- Parking lot located right next to the restaurant but there are limited spaces and they are usually occupied. I usually look for street parking, which could be hard around that area.

[ H A P P Y H O U R ]
- Happy hour from 4:00 to 6:00 Monday through Friday and everyday from 10pm to closing. Will definitely come back and try the HH.

excerpts: My wife and I like to meet after work and sit at the bar and have drinks and eat bar bites--calamari, original Poke, California roll, and
Korean ribs are all great!
The bar features hand built drinks...
I love the Mai Tai's they are best that I have ever had and the Negroni is also top notch.
Good service and good prices.
A neighborhood gem
original.author: David K.
original.review: love this place. The food is good, a fusion of Asian, Pacific Islander and American. Great bar and a great happy hour. My wife and I like to meet after work and sit at the bar and have drinks and eat bar bites--calamari, original Poke, California roll, and Korean ribs are all great! The bar features hand built drinks... I love the Mai Tai's they are best that I have ever had and the Negroni is also top notch. Good service and good prices. A neighborhood gem

excerpts: Every Time I'm around inner sunset area, I would try my best to come here and get the original poke.
I also tried several of their pokes and the original is definitely my favorite.
original.author: Ruxin H.
original.review:
My default place to go when I need a Hawaiian poke fix. Every Time I'm around inner sunset area, I would try my best to come here and get the original poke. I also tried several of their pokes and the original is definitely my favorite. It is kinda marinated ahi tuna chunks with soy sauce and onions. The tuna is fresh and high grade. I wouldn't say it is the highest quality of ahi tuna, but I think it is very good for the price point.

I would recommend getting the appetizer of tuna poke as opposed to wasabi bowls. I feel the portion of fish is a little smaller in the bowls and wonton chips in the appetizer go well with the poke. 

Sometimes I got the take out order of the poke appetizer and they gave a soup cup size of poke. 

I also came here for dinner before and their salmon/catch of day is pretty good too. Very huge portion.

Plus, service is incredible here. They served edamame when you are seated

excerpts: We waited 15 minutes for our original server to come by and ask for the check again.
She brought the check after another 10 minutes.
original.author: Cameron L.
original.review:
Really great and fresh food.  I always crave pacific catch.  They give good servings and aren't stingy on the fish.  I usually get their ahi wasabi poke bowl and recommend it to everyone. 

However, the service is disappointing.  Every time I've been here I've either had to send something back because they either miscommunicate with the back of the house or forget the order.  Almost all times I've been here, the service was slow and neglected their guests.
