But holy crap, let me note just for a moment -- how fucking GROWN UP does this dinner sound? A far cry from my usual "grab a quick meal with whomever is around" approach.

Anyway, I should note that Pacific Catch was working against a bit of a disadvantage, since I'd been a pretty big fan of the Canvas Gallery. In all honesty, though? The space works a lot better as a restaurant. Now that I've eaten at Pacific Catch, I can see that fully. It's big, expansive & almost cavernous. All those attributes work in favor of a big dining establishment. The high ceilings & warm lighting made it feel like the kind of place an exec from The Cheesecake Factory might model their next restaurant after (but with more mable columns).

Unintentional backhanded compliments aside, it's the type of place that's appealing on a large scale. The service was friendly & attentive, & we were all very satisfied with our respective meals (I got the Tokyo Salmon w/sweet potato fries, & it was delicious!).

It's a low key place for dinner (what we were looking for), & the kind of restaurant you can go when you feel like eatin' good in the neighborhood.

excerpts: Also we ordered 2 a la carte tacos, the BBQ Salmon and the Tropical Shrimp which were very good.
salmon.author: Janet H.
salmon.review:
Wandering around Golden Gate Park and DeYoung Museum, we realized we were close by the many restaurants in the Inner Sunset.  We walked into Pacific Catch on a beautiful day.

For starters we each got the Signature Miso and Shiitake Miso.  I thought the miso could have had a little bit more flavor in the broth, but it was still good.  The shiitake miso had veggies (mushrooms & asparagus) which made it also good.

Our entrees were the Sesame Crusted Ahi and the Crispy Catch of the Day.  I chose the Ahi as a healthy alternative and it was seared perfectly.  The catch was fresh rock cod served with sweet potato fries.  Although the rock cod was battered, it didn't taste to overly deep fried like what you would expect.  Also we ordered 2 a la carte tacos, the BBQ Salmon and the Tropical Shrimp which were very good.

We noticed there was loud music playing overhead (why?).  We also noticed that Pacific Catch is kid friendly.  This is a plus for parents who are looking for a healthier choice than a diner or greasy spoon.  Pacific Catch is a good midday meal!

excerpts: - Teriyaki Bowl - Topped with asparagus, glazed shiitake mushrooms, grilled bok choy, sesame seeds & house-made teriyaki sauce served over pineapple fried rice with Fresh Salmon $13.95.
This was ordered by my friends.
salmon.author: Amelia M.
salmon.review:
I was never intending on going, but decided to try something new...  I walked in and couldn't believe this was my beloved Canvas Cafe once... I miss you Canvas!  They changed everything inside... it is decorated in warm colors and the light are really nice... they look like blue bottles... hmm... they could be bottles. They have lots of booths with comfortable cushions.  We were served by Misa who was really nice and very helpful. She made sure we had our fill of tea and was very attentive.  

Here is what we ordered:
- Spicy Cabo Calamari | fried with fresh chilis and crispy lemon, served with a chipotle dipping sauce $8.95. This was delicious. The sauce might be too spicy for some. The calamari rings were cooked to perfection (nothing worse than over cooked ring!)


- Mixed Catch Basket | 2 pieces of fresh fish, 4 coconut shrimp & 3 oysters with traditional fries $13.95. I would probably just order the Shrimp.  I liked the oysters, but it is not all that... I rather not eat my oysters fried.  The tartar sauce was great. I ordered the seasoned fries with this one.  They were very tasty. Next time I will try the sweet potatoes.  

- Teriyaki Bowl - Topped with asparagus, glazed shiitake mushrooms, grilled bok choy, sesame seeds & house-made teriyaki sauce served over pineapple fried rice with Fresh Salmon $13.95. This was ordered by my friends. I had some of the rice with the sauce and it tasted YUMMMY. 

- Mochi Fondu | vanilla, chocolate & coffee mochi ice cream with warm chocolate dipping sauce $5.50 When you get this dessert... eat fast... the hot chocolate makes it a bit difficult to get the mochi out of there before it melts down.  (Suggestion for restaurant owners/chefs - Perhaps if you use spoons or little ladle like utensils it would help save the bites from getting lost in the fondue. The wooden pick slips right off when dipped in the warm chocolate fondue after a few minutes.) I really loved this dessert... YUM! 

Total bill for two was a bit over $50. 

I would go back to try some other dishes.  It turned out to be a nice place to go. It does feel a bit chain like, but either way, I still enjoyed it.  I just don't feel like it fits in with the neighborhood.  I am used to the more wall in the hole feel.  Not a bad thing... it is just an observation. =)

excerpts: We started with the house cured sake salmon with nori rice cakes, wasabi creme fraiche, and black tobiko ($9.95), which was out-of-this-world delicious.
For my entree I had the Tokyo salmon fish and chips with ginger-wasabi aioli and lemon ponzu ($13.95).
Again my only criticism here was the sauces.
The ponzu wasn't as tart as I would have liked and the aioli definitely could have been punched up a couple of notches.
The most important part of the dish- the fish- was spot on.
Crispy on the inside and moist on the inside, just the way it should be.
salmon.author: Brian H.
salmon.review:
Well, after yelping our unfortunate experience on our first visit to Pacific Catch, the wife and I were contacted by PC's marketing manager, who apologized and offered us a $50 credit if we would give PC another try.

Needless to say, we took him up on the offer, and went back a week after our initial visit. The manager working that night was very apologetic about out previous visit and went to great pains to make sure we were taken care of.

This time, I'm pleased to report that PC lived up to the expectations we'd initially gone in with.  No shards of glass this time. Of course, that's sort of to be expected, but I think our second visit was probably more representative of the typical PC experience and the 4 stars were definitely well-deserved. It was even close to 5 star territory, but again I was hit with a little bout of post-meal queasiness. Not as bad as the first time around but enough that I couldn't in fairness give 5 stars. Still, our meal on this evening was very, very good.

We started with the house cured sake salmon with nori rice cakes, wasabi creme fraiche, and black tobiko ($9.95), which was out-of-this-world delicious. The craime fraiche could have used a bit more of a wasabi kick, but that's a very quibbling critique of what was a very well executed and beautifully presented dish.

For my entree I had the Tokyo salmon fish and chips with ginger-wasabi aioli and lemon ponzu ($13.95). Again my only criticism here was the sauces. The ponzu wasn't as tart as I would have liked and the aioli definitely could have been punched up a couple of notches. The most important part of the dish- the fish- was spot on. Crispy on the inside and moist on the inside, just the way it should be. The sweet potato fries were also very tasty.

Katie had one of the specials- hawaiian opah with pineapple fried rice and bok choy ($20ish?). Aside from the bok choy which was very al dente and very difficult to eat (it should have been pre-cut or served with a steak knife- it was very hard to cut with a butter knife and too large and stringy to just take a bite), her meal was excellent. The fish and rice went together beautifully and he bok choy would have been a nice complement if it had been less cumbersome to eat. Katie also had a couple of pomegranate cocktails of some sort which were yummy.

All in all, an excellent meal and a nice gesture on the part of PC's management to redeem itself and earn back some good will.

We will definitely be back for more!

excerpts: I ordered the salmon teriyaki bowl with brown rice subbed in for the pineapple fried rice.
The latter didn't sound very appealing to me; plus, my wife is always telling me about the healthy benefits of brown rice!
Their bowls are HUGE, btw.
The size of my bowl reminded me of something I would get at the Cheesecake Factory.
The size of the grilled salmon could have certainly been larger, and the quantity of rice could have been far less.
salmon.author: B. Earl K.
salmon.review:
Very easy to make a same day (Sunday) lunch reservation via OpenTable.com.

They started us with a small two-compartment dish of fresh edamame and some little Pepperidge Farm-esque pretzel nuggets. 

Extremely fast service for our "appetizer", Hawaiian Poke. The ahi cubes were very soft and the sesame soy marinade was perfect. This dish was a great value at $8.50...the ahi was piled high alongside and on top of several tasty wonton crisps.

My wife ordered the fried oysters with sweet potato fries subbed in for their traditional fries...both DEE-licious. I ordered the salmon teriyaki bowl with brown rice subbed in for the pineapple fried rice. The latter didn't sound very appealing to me; plus, my wife is always telling me about the healthy benefits of brown rice! Their bowls are HUGE, btw. The size of my bowl reminded me of something I would get at the Cheesecake Factory. The size of the grilled salmon could have certainly been larger, and the quantity of rice could have been far less. Otherwise, it was just okay.

Friendly, speedy service. Nice variety on their menu(s). We'll definitely return to try some more of what they have to offer!

excerpts:
Starter:
Firecracker roll - a spicy tempura salmon roll
Entrees:
1.

Grilled Salmon with artichoke and a layer of tomatos
Dessert:
Mochi ice cream fondue with vanilla, coffee and chocolate flavored ice cream
My husband had the salmon and said he wished he picked something else.
Salmon is salmon - nothing special, but cooked really nicely - not overcooked, just right.
Dessert was really good.
I love chocolate and I like mochi ice cream on a stick.
This was just right.
The wine was definitely not the best.
I think with our chosen food, the wine just ended up tasting sour.
salmon.author: Stacey C.
salmon.review:
I just came back from my Valentine's Day dinner and I'm all alone and yelping already.  I was really excited to try this place because the reviews are pretty decent so far.  So we went for the Valentine's Day special for $65.  Everything on there I believe you can order through the chalkboard special menu or regular dinner menu.  

Decor was nice and the place looks a lot bigger than it does from the outside.  I guess I never noticed Canvas was that big inside.  The beech wood on the ceiling brightens up the place while still looking a little romantic, and even the bathroom walls/doors have the little bamboo inside plexiglass look which is nice to look at when you have to pee.

Starter:
Firecracker roll - a spicy tempura salmon roll
Entrees:
1. Ahi Tuna 3 way - poke, sesame seared and another kind of seared with rice, seaweed salad, some terryaki mushroom edamame mix and another mixed salad that could've been one of those japanese mixes with turnip.
2. Grilled Salmon with artichoke and a layer of tomatos
Dessert:
Mochi ice cream fondue with vanilla, coffee and chocolate flavored ice cream
Drinks: Sparkling white wine

The portions were pretty good sized for $65 for 2 people.  The firecracker roll was rather large, but if you look closely, it's a lot of rice wrapped in them.  It still tasted good though and didn't come out looking all sloppy like some restaurants make their sushi.  I really liked the ahi 3-way.  The seared kinds were better and more buttery than the poke, which to me was kind of chewy.  Not exactly the way I pictured poke.  But every other piece was fine.  My husband had the salmon and said he wished he picked something else.  Salmon is salmon - nothing special, but cooked really nicely - not overcooked, just right.  
Dessert was really good.  I love chocolate and I like mochi ice cream on a stick.  This was just right.  
The wine was definitely not the best.  I think with our chosen food, the wine just ended up tasting sour.  But I love sweet white wines and that's just my preference.

The service was really good for such a crowded night.  We had a really upbeat and polite waitress and they served us our food quickly enough.  A nice place to eat overall with a lot more to try.  I love sweet potato fries so that will be part of my next meal there.  They have what, 5 parking spaces there, but there's plenty of parking across the street and in the park.

excerpts: My friend got salmon fish tacos
(she's such a SoCal girl) and Fat Tire's Mothership.
She very much enjoyed her food...and mine as well!
salmon.author: stefany f.
salmon.review:
I've been here several times and I've always left extremely happy and full. How could you go wrong with fried fish and sweet potato fries? Exactly, you can't!

Today, I went here with a good friend after venturing through the Academy of Sciences. We worked up quite the appetite and were ready to chow. 

I tend to get the same thing every time...Catch of the Day. Sometimes I get the Hawaiian Poki Bowl, which is also awesome and super tasty. But I like to change it up with the drink. Today our server, who was awesome as well, suggested I try this spicy yet sweet cocktail. I cannot remember its name, but it was on the second page of the drink menu on the top of the page. Trust me, I will order this again...and again...and again! It was a nice sweetness from passion fruit juice, but had a nice hit of spice and heat with serrano peppers. Amazing! I know, it sounds like a crazy mix, but it was amazing and very different.

My friend got salmon fish tacos (she's such a SoCal girl) and Fat Tire's Mothership. She very much enjoyed her food...and mine as well! She also agreed well with my drink.

So yah, when you're in the area, I'd definitely suggest making a stop at Pacific Catch for a nice meal. There's everything you could want: fried fish, sweet potato fries with jalapeno tartar sauce, sushi, poki, alcohol in crazy concoctions, sandwiches, etc. Just try it out! And even if you're not in the area...Pacific Catch would be a great place to make your way to for a totally worth it meal.

excerpts: " For some reason I thought this was strictly an American Fish restaurant - you know, salmon with wild rice and choice of vegetable kinda place, because that is what it looks like on the outside - but it turned out was a Japanese fusion restaurant.
salmon.author: Elsa C.
salmon.review:
I went here on a Friday night sometime a few weeks ago. It was pretty filled up but it didnt look like there was anyone waiting. I had always driven by it and wanted to try it since it was converted from being "The Canvas" For some reason I thought this was strictly an American Fish restaurant - you know, salmon with wild rice and choice of vegetable kinda place, because that is what it looks like on the outside - but it turned out was a Japanese fusion restaurant. 

We started off with some sushi appetizers. If you don't like wasabi, you should ask them to hold it on the sushi, because you wouldn't know it just by looking at the rolls that they a pretty generous amount in there. I myself, love wasabi, but had I known that there was so much in it, I would not have dipped it so much in my super wasabi/soy sauce combo. I admit it, it made me tear. And usually I can handle alot of wasabi.

Then I had the ahi turn wasabi bowl - with tobiko. It came out as a generous portion of rice, ahi tuna, sprouts, teriyaki sauce - or was it sriracha?, and a plethora of different vegetables. Despite how good it was, I could not finish it. It defeated me =(

It was a birthday celebration so they gave us free dessert. It was mochi in a chocolate fondue. YUMMY. I am a sucker for fondue. And fondue and ice cream? What could be better?

I would come back again.

excerpts: - Miso Glazed Salmon
: Loved the crispy outside and buttery inside.
Sauce, mushroom & edamame side, was delicious.
The salad on the side was not to my liking.
salmon.author: Ashley C.
salmon.review:
So my boyfriend took me here for Mother's Day because a friend suggested it. And EVERYONE we knew that has been there told us to get the sweet potato fries. 

The first thing that I noticed was that out of all the booths, the hostess sat us at one where I was literally blinded by the sunlight. I ended up sitting next to my boyfriend, which is nice, but I like sitting across from him so we can talk easier. Our waiter (his name totally slipped my mind, sorry!) was nice and attentive. Took our orders and our appetizers came out in like 10 minutes! Kind of threw me off on how fast it came out. 

we ordered: 

- Sweet Potato Fries: My boyfriend is a fries fiend so he totally enjoyed this. I'm not that big on fries, but I must admit that it was pretty delish. 

- Hawaiian Poke: My absolute fave of the night. I always have to try poke if a restaurant has it on their menu and this one totally hit the spot. Not as good as homemade, but close enough! Could do without the won ton chips. Would have been great with a seaweed salad. 

- Cabo Calamari: This is another dish we usually always try if it's on the menu. We were quite disappointed. Usually when you eat a piece of calamari without the sauce, it should still have some flavor from the breading its coated in, but this was just so...BLAND. Then when we dipped it in the sauce, it completely broke apart. No good. 

- Miso Glazed Salmon: Loved the crispy outside and buttery inside. Sauce, mushroom & edamame side, was delicious. The salad on the side was not to my liking. I don't know what it was, but the flavor was horrible and the texture was really tough. 

- Korean BBQ Steak: First of all, the waiter hadn't asked my boyfriend how he wanted it cooked. It came out medium rare which was fine though. Tim loved the flavor, but the meat was TOUGH. Don't think it was the way it was cooked, just that that particular cut of meat was tough. He also didn't like the salad. 

- Lemongrass Mojito: Pretty good. Bartender made it strong, just the way I like it. 

Overall, it was alright. If I were to go back it would be for the sweet potato fries, Hawaiian poke, and maybe to try the Wasabi Bowls and fish tacos.

excerpts: We ordered the salmon rice bowls which were outstanding!

I highly recommend this place for gatherings with friends, to take parents to a safe place where they won't question potential health and safety code violations (like so many little holes in the wall in SF), and for families with children.
salmon.author: Marina S.
salmon.review: I took my parents who were visiting out of town here on a Tuesday evening. Parking was convenient, and we didn't have to wait at all to be seated right away. I have to say I was really pleasantly surprised by the selection of menu items, service, and the delicious/creative foods they serve! We ordered the salmon rice bowls which were outstanding! I highly recommend this place for gatherings with friends, to take parents to a safe place where they won't question potential health and safety code violations (like so many little holes in the wall in SF), and for families with children.

excerpts: Salmon Wasabi Bowl:
I thought it was going to be raw salmon
but it turned out to be grilled.

Even though I was in the mood for raw fish the salmon was a great compliment to the brown rice covered with a wasabi miso sauce, radish sprouts, seaweed salad, cucumber salad, pickled ginger and avocado.
It was all the ingredients to a honkin sushi roll but in a bowl.
For about $15, the portions were huge, fresh, and tastey.
I think I was a little disappointed that the salmon was cooked, obviously my fault, but I still enjoyed my meal.
Looking around at the other tables and their selections, the wasabi bowl was probably the best priced dish.
The menu will definitely bring me back to finalize their rating.
I cant wait to try all the other delicious goodies....crispy oysters....
mmmm...
cant wait!!!
salmon.author: Tammy H.
salmon.review:
Still not off the Hawaii tip =p  Wanted something close to the spicy tuna bowl I had at Aloha Sushi in Honolulu....rice, 2 scoops of spicy tuna, and all the fixins in a bowl.  The bf suggested Pacific Catch for the comparable taste.  
Parking was a (%&# as usual around 9th/Irving on a beautiful Sunday afternoon right next to GG park.  All good...beauiful day in the sunset...cant beat those!!  Walked past the cute little tables in their patio and was seated right away and attended to.  The entire menu looked super yum!  I seriously had to narrow it down from sweet potato fries, crispy oysters, teriyaki bowls, macademia crusted seabass, catfish sandwich, sushi....it was rather extensive!!  We finally narrowed it down to....

Spicy Fries:  Normal fries just tossed with a cajun seasoning I think.  I LOVE fries so it was a great version...especially since they were "skinny" fries that were super crispy.  The dipping sauces were a nice touch: sweet chili sauce (the one for lumpia!!...I blended that combo LONG before I came here!!  I like their thinking here) and a creamy miso dip!!  yum!!  Mix them together...its perfect!

Salmon Wasabi Bowl:  I thought it was going to be raw salmon but it turned out to be grilled. Apparently the raw stuff is the Hawaiian Poke?  How the hell was I suppose to know that??!!  I wish there was a description on the menu.  Boooo!!  Even though I was in the mood for raw fish the salmon was a great compliment to the brown rice covered with a wasabi miso sauce, radish sprouts, seaweed salad, cucumber salad, pickled ginger and avocado.  It was all the ingredients to a honkin sushi roll but in a bowl.  For about $15, the portions were huge, fresh, and tastey.  I probably ate a little less than half and was STUFFED!  

Tuna Wasabi Bowl: Same condiments in the bowl just with lighly seared tuna.

I think I was a little disappointed that the salmon was cooked, obviously my fault, but I still enjoyed my meal.  Looking around at the other tables and their selections, the wasabi bowl was probably the best priced dish.  The menu will definitely bring me back to finalize their rating.  I cant wait to try all the other delicious goodies....crispy oysters....mmmm...cant wait!!!

excerpts: Dishes that we ordered: California roll / Hawaiian surf and turf / grilled salmon with Gluten-free tortilla chips, artichoke, tomatoes / Tofu teriyaki bowl /  and fixed 3 course meal Costa-Rican (limited time only).
The grilled salmon was moist and tasty.
The grilled salmon was moist and tasty.
My 5 year old daughter polished off the California roll with real crab meat.
My mom's Tofu Bowl was very good.
I like the firmness of the tofu.
My dad's 3 course fixed price meal was very tasty.
It looked like a quesadilla with all the fixings, but without the quesadilla.
Oh, and the brown rice is a must have
salmon.author: Marcus Y.
salmon.review:
Came here after a drive back from Fresno. If it wasn't for a lucky parking spot within 50 feet, I would've eaten elsewhere, but my kids were hungry and since 1 of my daughter has a food allergy, this was a better place to go. I've heard so much about this place and thru my mom, that I was excited coming here, even after a 4 hour drive.

Dishes that we ordered: California roll / Hawaiian surf and turf / grilled salmon with Gluten-free tortilla chips, artichoke, tomatoes / Tofu teriyaki bowl /  and fixed 3 course meal Costa-Rican (limited time only).

All the food was delicious! I ordered the Hawaiian Surf & Turf. The skirt steak was very tender and so good. It also came with 2 skewers of shrimps, along with pineapple fried rice and asparagus. The grilled salmon was moist and tasty. My 5 year old daughter polished off the California roll with real crab meat. My mom's Tofu Bowl was very good. I like the firmness of the tofu. My dad's 3 course fixed price meal was very tasty. It looked like a quesadilla with all the fixings, but without the quesadilla. Oh, and the brown rice is a must have, otherwise you'll get the sushi rice, which is still good. 

It was kinda pricey, but was worth it for the delicious meal.

excerpts:
To summarize what our party ordered

- Wasabi bowl: ahi poki and vegatables over japanese rice
- Fish n chips: salmon strips with crispy sweet potato fries
- Terriyaki beef: with shrimp, rice and thinly sliced crispy onion rings

crispy spring roll with icecream and carmel sauce

All were good except for the salmon.
salmon.author: Oanh N.
salmon.review:
I was unsure of how the food would turn out because of it's chainy environment. In fact, it's a unique one because it serves japanese cuisine with an american touch. To summarize what our party ordered

- Wasabi bowl: ahi poki and vegatables over japanese rice
- Fish n chips: salmon strips with crispy sweet potato fries
- Terriyaki beef: with shrimp, rice and thinly sliced crispy onion rings
- Dessert: crispy spring roll with icecream and carmel sauce

All were good except for the salmon. It was tasteless unless drowned in the malt/vinegar sauce or horseradish sauce. 

I definitely want to come back because of their wide range of really healthy meals like their wasabi salads!

excerpts:
My meal:
"Firecracker Salmon" roll - $9.95: not a big fan of the over-induced daikon sprouts.
Didn't know I was ordering cooked-salmon
til
I got it.
Shouldn't have overlooked the 'tempura-salmon' description.
I'll try something else next time.
salmon.author: Diwata B.
salmon.review:
Fried Oysters. Poke Roll.  It's not "to-die-for" food but I'd eat there again none the less.  Service was un-noticeably good (not too bad, nothing spectacular).  They have a mini parking lot in the back, which is good considering the parking in the nearby streets.  

Appetizer: 
"Crispy Oysters" - $9.50: about 10 on the plate.  Fried.  would order it again

My meal:
"Firecracker Salmon" roll - $9.95: not a big fan of the over-induced daikon sprouts.  Didn't know I was ordering cooked-salmon til I got it.  Shouldn't have overlooked the 'tempura-salmon' description.  I'll try something else next time.
"Hawaiian Poke" roll - $8.95:  Giant cubed ahi in a roll (which I like)   I was diggin' the sesame-soy marinade.    

Got a taste of:
"Mixed Catch Basket" - $13.95
2 pieces of fish, 4 coconut shrimp & 3 crispy oysters with jalapeno tartar
No taste of coconut in my coconut shrimp.  The side of sweet potato fries were awesome.  I'd order that on it's own.

excerpts: Had the special chowder to start which was great, and then the Island Tacos (Baja, BBQ Salmon and Cajun Shrimp), with sweet potato fries.
Was very good.
There is a lot of food for not a huge amount of money, I think the chowder was about $6 and the Tacos were $14.
salmon.author: Paul G.
salmon.review:
Dropped in on Pacific Catch on 9th on New Year's Day following a wander round the Botanical Gardens and had a great late lunch. I had tried Pacific Catch's booth at Outside Lands Festival and really liked the food.

Had the special chowder to start which was great, and then the Island Tacos (Baja, BBQ Salmon and Cajun Shrimp), with sweet potato fries. Was very good. There is a lot of food for not a huge amount of money, I think the chowder was about $6 and the Tacos were $14. Not cheap, but by no means expensive, especially for fresh fish.

The wait staff was very friendly and the place is very clean and has great decor. Definitely a recommended spot if you're over near 9th and Irving....

excerpts: We got the calamari, the spicy salmon roll, and the crab & avocado salad.
Both the sushi and the salad we BIG, but we managed to polish everything off!
The service was top notch.
Our server checked back with us several times during the meal and was way on the ball.
salmon.author: Shannon R.
salmon.review:
So I finally don't have to schlep it to the marina anymore when I'm craving some Pacific Catch! I'll raise a glass or two of Ozeki nigori sake to that, hell yeah! (which is exactly what I did tonight!) 

Housed in the old Canvas Cafe spot, this Pacific Catch is at least ten times larger than the one on Chestnut. And, dude, get this: you can make reservations on open table!!! How rad is that?!? I got on open table at around 5:30 pm and made a reservation for two for 6:45 pm, same night! It didn't look like there would have been a wait in any case, even if we had just walked in off the street (this was on a tuesday). 

We got the calamari, the spicy salmon roll, and the crab & avocado salad. Both the sushi and the salad we BIG, but we managed to polish everything off! The service was top notch. Our server checked back with us several times during the meal and was way on the ball. Nice. 

The prices are great for the type of food they serve and for the quality and freshness, but stuff adds up. You can drop fifty, no prob, especially if you have a drink or two. Well, I don't get over to the sunset much, but it sure beats the marina! Parking was even easy...there were tons of spots across the way in GG park. Sweet!

excerpts: The popular sweet potato fries were not bad, but when it came to my Tokyo salmon, it felt like mall food.
salmon.author: Fotos C.
salmon.review:
Some one year ago, this place used to be the Canvas Gallery - a bar, cafe, art gallery, and live music performance space all in one! I always thought the location and design felt in tune back then.

Welp, fast forward to today and you have Pacific Catch, where they serve infused Japanese-American food, slightly overpriced and unexciting.  The actual space is bigger and more utilized, but it felt noisy during my sitting. The kitchen was exposed, the wall art was uninteresting, the food and service was sub par.  Upon looking at the menu, almost everything is either grilled or fried. The popular sweet potato fries were not bad, but when it came to my Tokyo salmon, it felt like mall food. The rice bowls did not look like anything special either. 

Maybe I need to order something more American and less Japanese here, to go with the fries? I don't know.

excerpts: We've had the ceviche which was stellar and the salmon salad.
salmon.author: Max A.
salmon.review:
I've now been in here twice for lunch, and both times I've spent far more then I'd intended but left extremely happy. 

It's very hard to resist trying their sushi rolls - oversized and fresh. The Rock and Roll is great, the Rising Sun is decent.

We've had the ceviche which was stellar and the salmon salad. The ahi salad, the mixed catch plate. Overall, everyone has always been happy with their dish. We've had no problems with service or waits, food quality or experience.

The Kamikaze Bloody Mary is fine - the wasabi is a nice way to change it up a bit, but I almost wish there was a bit more bite to the drink. Wasabi shouldn't taste tamed.

excerpts: Waited forever for the food then both salmon sandwiches were served cold instead of hot.
The waitress brought us back "new" sandwiches that were still cold and she neglected to replace the cole slaw she took away the first time.
The manager came over to apologize with the lame excuse that they had a big table to serve before ours and it was especially busy that day, but the restaurant was only half full.
Won't ever eat here again.
salmon.author: Debra J.
salmon.review: Waited forever for the food then both salmon sandwiches were served cold instead of hot. The waitress brought us back "new" sandwiches that were still cold and she neglected to replace the cole slaw she took away the first time. The manager came over to apologize with the lame excuse that they had a big table to serve before ours and it was especially busy that day, but the restaurant was only half full. Won't ever eat here again.

excerpts: I had the crispy fried salmon with sweet potato fries.
Never had fried salmon before, so it sounded interesting.
I've also never liked sweet potato fries.
The fried salmon was great (or maybe I liked it more because salmon season was canceled this year), and the sweet potato fries were also great.
The fried salmon was great (or maybe I liked it more because salmon season was canceled this year), and the sweet potato fries were also great.
salmon.author: Rob T.
salmon.review:
I wasn't that hungry when I came here for dinner - perfect attitude for a critical review.

Started out with a Kamikaze Bloody Mary. Tastes like a Bloody Mary, hits like a Kamikaze.

Ahi poke wasabi bowl with tobiko was delicious - almost like a sashimi bowl, with lots of seaweed. The poke wasn't that seasoned, but the ahi was good enough to make up for the lack of spice.

I had the crispy fried salmon with sweet potato fries. Never had fried salmon before, so it sounded interesting. I've also never liked sweet potato fries. The fried salmon was great (or maybe I liked it more because salmon season was canceled this year), and the sweet potato fries were also great.

All the fried stuff did not taste that greasy.

Had some mochi fondu for dessert. A little thick for mochi (I expect it to be delicate), but tasty all the same.

excerpts: The tokyo salmon was great but the calamari was not so great.
salmon.author: Amy A.
salmon.review:
My boyfriend HATES fish. As long as I've known him he has refused to eat fish. I, however, am a crafty and creative girl and I SWORE that ONE DAY I would get him to enjoy fish!
So...
One day we both had a sweet potato craving and I casually mentioned that there was a place near the park where we could eat and take a casual stroll. It was a nice day so he agreed. Ah ha! After 4 years, my plan was working..

We came in and sat down but we were sat in these super uncomfortable tall akward wicker chairs. "Surprise Boyfriend! We're at a fish place!"
Then we were served edamame and cute fishy crackers which was awesome because we were starving and made up for the crappy seating. I ordered some kind of ginger-tini and the boyfriend ordered a dark and stormy. Both were fabulous! The drinks were top notch! 
The two of us split a sweet potato basket of fries and loved it. Great dipping sauces!
I ordered the mahi mahi teriyaki bowl with pineapple fried rice and really enjoyed it. The boyfriend ordered the fish and chips. AH? Fish you say?! YES FISH!! And guess what? He LIKED it! 
For dessert, we had the Dulce de leche Spring rolls. MM MM GOOD!! If your thinking of going, make reservations.

***Update: The boyfriend took me here for Valentines day and it was one of the best dates ever! We had a cute corner table with candle light and it was very romantic. Waitress was sweet and attentive while still giving us plenty of time to stare deeply in each others eyes. The tokyo salmon was great but the calamari was not so great. Still love the sweet potato fries and next time I will try the sushi which looks yummy. ****

excerpts: When we finally got a table, we ordered the salmon tempura roll, the salmon sandwich, and the catch of the day basket.
All of the food was delicious, but I figured out that I don't really like fried musssles (I don't blame the food,
just my taste buds).
I also ordered the lime in the coconut drink, but it just kind of tasted like water.
salmon.author: Candiace A.
salmon.review:
I had a different experience than the first time I went.  I came here last Friday for my 21st birthday.  As I expected, it is really crowded for dinner, but I didn't mind.  We waited about 20 min. for a table, so Garren and I ordered a beer and a mai tai.  The mai tai was small but very strong.  I was buzzed after drinking a third of it.  When we finally got a table, we ordered the salmon tempura roll, the salmon sandwich, and the catch of the day basket.  All of the food was delicious, but I figured out that I don't really like fried musssles (I don't blame the food, just my taste buds).  I also ordered the lime in the coconut drink, but it just kind of tasted like water.  I don't think I'd order it again.  

After we were done eating the waitress told us that that I get a free birthday dessert.  We told her that we were so full, and couldn't eat anymore.  Then she said, "Oh, not even a scoop of ice cream?"  Soooo, we said, "Alright then, thank you."  When we got the bill, she ended up charging us for the "free birthday dessert."  I don't even think that a scoop of ice cream was supposed to be the "free birthday dessert."  There were many other people getting these fancy-looking desserts, with candles, and they were not on the dessert menu.  I am assuming that those were supposed to be the free birthday dessert.  I don't know.  

I like the food from here, but I did not like how we got charged for a "free" not even birthday dessert.  I was also pissed that the people next to us had a different waiter, and they got free mochi balls for no reason.  I think the waiter was hitting on them, but still....  It was my damn birthday.  Overall during the day, I didn't have a very good birthday (lack of sleep, lab from 7 am- 1:30, homework, don't know anyone in this city, spent my birthday basically alone), and by the end of the night, it was topped off with this... Even though a restaurant may have great food, it is really the customer service that can make or break a good experience.

excerpts: Husband ordered the 2 taco plate - one salmon and one mahi.
I didn't try the mahi - I guess it was good cause he ate the whole thing!
The salmon I tried and was yummy.
Not too much sauce,
salmon.author: Paulette L.
salmon.review:
Came here on a whim after a trip to the Academy of Science.  The menu looked good (lots of seafood, which we love) and reasonable prices.  We decided to sit out on the patio and enjoy the rare sun.

Started with the shrimp ceviche - YUM! Not too spicy, and tons of shrimp.  We ran out of chips, thank goodness - I would have gotten full off that alone.
I ordered the Ahi Poki Wasabi bowl, with brown rice, half rice half salad.  Complicated, huh?!  Wasabi/soy over rice was... different.  Had a little wasabi kick, but not too bad.  Though next time I'll order that sauce on the side.  Careful of the salad too - they drown it with dressing, though the dressing was pretty good.  Poke was ok - huge cuts of tuna, but lots of chewy parts (are those tendons??)  I think if they were cut properly, it would have tasted much better.  
Husband ordered the 2 taco plate - one salmon and one mahi.  I didn't try the mahi - I guess it was good cause he ate the whole thing!  The salmon I tried and was yummy.  Not too much sauce, just right.  

Have to admit, eating my asian dish, followed by a taste of his spanish dish was kinda weird.  But both were very tasty.  Just not at the same time...

Love the variety of dishes on the menu.  We wouldn't mind coming back to try new dishes.

excerpts: My faves: salmon or ahi tuna wasabi bowl with brown rice, or the taco combo with sweet potato fries.
salmon.author: Misha F.
salmon.review:
Without a blink, 4 stars. 

I seriously love this place. I love the menu, the ambiance, the wicked happy hour deals. 

Sign up for the Pacfic Catch newsletters...there is always a monthly "deal." In October, it was 'buy one entree, get the 2nd free!' 

My faves: salmon or ahi tuna wasabi bowl with brown rice, or the taco combo with sweet potato fries.

I love coming here with girlfriends, esp because you can get opentable.com reservation points--win-win baby!

excerpts: My other friend ordered the salmon sashimi.
It wasn't good and unlike the heaping portions of salad and wasabi bowl - it was lacking.
She ended up eating from our plates.
The meal came out to $80 with tax and tips.
A little pricey, but considering what we ate and the occasion, it was pretty good.
salmon.author: Adrianna C.
salmon.review:
I took my friends here as a late Christmas dinner, subsitute present after my other friend told me how delicious this place was. After confirming the fact on Yelp, I decided to make a reservation. As my friend and I sat and waited for our other friends to arrive, the waiter was kind and attentive. He asked us if we wanted anything to eat as we waited, filled our water cups, and gave us our complentary plate of edamame and pretzel gold fishes. 

To start we ordered Rock & Roll and also sweet potatoe fries. The sweet potatoe fries were really good and the sauce was delicious. Rock & Roll, not so much - it's not that it was bad, rolls are just not a good choice for this restaurant. Anywho, my friend and I ordered the wasabi bowl with ahi tuna and crab salad to share. The bowl was really good and had huge portions. The salad had a lot of crab, but not much flavor. The Thai salad on the other hand I liked. My other friend ordered the salmon sashimi. It wasn't good and unlike the heaping portions of salad and wasabi bowl - it was lacking. She ended up eating from our plates. The meal came out to $80 with tax and tips. A little pricey, but considering what we ate and the occasion, it was pretty good. I would come back, when my wallet permits it. 

The interior design and the high ceiling of the restaurant felt warm and cozy, and definitely made me feel like I was out of the Sunset. This is definitely a romantic restaurant and would be a great place to take a girl on a date. Maybe not a first date though, cause the noise level kills that.

excerpts: My friend definitely ordered the wrong thing, salmon fish and chips which stated "lightly breaded and fried" and it showed up over breaded, over fried and room temperature.
Not even close to being edible.
I had the wasabi sandwich and it was just ok, pretty bland.
By the time the staff came back to see how our food was going so much time had passed that we didn't want to send the salmon back and wait for something else, we just wanted the check.
salmon.author: William R.
salmon.review:
The location is great and it looks nice on the inside, they put a lot of effort into it and the menu looks fantastic. I just wish that they put the same effort into the service and food. The bar seemed pricey for what it was and didn't seem to have a great selection. My friend definitely ordered the wrong thing, salmon fish and chips which stated "lightly breaded and fried" and it showed up over breaded, over fried and room temperature. Not even close to being edible. I had the wasabi sandwich and it was just ok, pretty bland. By the time the staff came back to see how our food was going so much time had passed that we didn't want to send the salmon back and wait for something else, we just wanted the check.

Menu looks great but maybe be more adventurous than I was, I am sorry I didn't try more here before deciding not to come back. The location is nice and convenient.

excerpts: I ordered two sushi rolls, the spicy tuna roll and the sake sake roll (salmon, avocado, sprouts, and lemon zest).
The rolls tasted good, but the tuna roll felt a little rubbery to me.
salmon.author: Storm T.
salmon.review:
Pacific Catch was okay. It was good but not especially good. I ordered two sushi rolls, the spicy tuna roll and the sake sake roll (salmon, avocado, sprouts, and lemon zest). The rolls tasted good, but the tuna roll felt a little rubbery to me. Also, I wasn't expecting the center of the sake sake roll to be just avocado, as opposed having some sort of meat in the middle, but I like avocado, so it was alright.

The service, however, was good. My server was friendly, and I got my food quickly even though the restaurant was crowded. If you are willing to spend about $22 on two average-tasting sushi rolls, you can go. If you're like me, though, and find that to be a lot of money to spend on food that isn't that great, I'd pass.

excerpts: My daughter got the salmon teriyaki bowl.
salmon.review:
I was invited for the complimentary lunch today. When we walked in, there was like 4 employees who greeted us at the door. They all had a sincere smile on their face. 

I brought my husband and daughter. The invite was for "me and a friend". My daughter was just going to share with us since she doesn't eat a lot. Our waitress said that if my daughter wanted something, they'd accommodate us. How cool is that?

They brought out a small dish with edamame beans and salted goldfish crackers. 

For appetizers, we ordered the fried oysters which came with a jalapeno tartar sauce. MMMMM!!!!

For my entree, I ordered the teriyaki bowl with Grilled Skirt Steak. The beef was tender and very tasty. Sitting on top of the pineapple fried rice was slices of mushrooms and bok choy. I LOVED the fried rice!!!

My husband ordered the Crispy Oyster & Chips Basket. It came with crispy battered Oregon Coast oysters with traditional fries, sesame slaw & jalapeno tarter. That was good too.

My daughter got the salmon teriyaki bowl. 

I loved everything about this place. Prices aren't bad at all. The staff was super friendly and very attentive. They have one staff assigned to each table. Who can ask for more? I don't have even one single complaint or disappointment about this place. I suggest you go eat here yourselves and see what I'm raving about. Check out their website too!

excerpts: I ordered the special - organic chinook salmon, tomatillo salsa, grilled veggies and sweet potato fries.
The fish was perfectly cooked, not underdone but not dry or tough.
The spice rub on it was AHMAZING!
The salsa was pretty good, not my favorite part of the dish, but was nice.
The grilled veggies were fully cooked, maybe even a little overcooked, but since I was feeding them to my toddler, I didn't mind.
The sweet potato fries, totally awesome.
Toddler LOVED them.
salmon.author: Laura G.
salmon.review:
I am so sold on this place. I came in with a clean slate, having never tried Pacific Catch anywhere. First impressed by how clean, fresh everything was. The high ceilings make the place feel even more spacious. The wait staff and hostesses were all very friendly. HUGE bonus points for the fact that they're super kid friendly and even have "stroller parking" back by the restrooms. I ordered the special - organic chinook salmon, tomatillo salsa, grilled veggies and sweet potato fries. The fish was perfectly cooked, not underdone but not dry or tough. The spice rub on it was AHMAZING! The salsa was pretty good, not my favorite part of the dish, but was nice. The grilled veggies were fully cooked, maybe even a little overcooked, but since I was feeding them to my toddler, I didn't mind. The sweet potato fries, totally awesome. Toddler LOVED them. I loved them!

The only thing was that I was a bit disappointed by the portions, which felt on the small side. But, I don't need any encouragement to overeat so I don't feel too bad about the portions. 

I definitely recommend if you get a salad, ask for the miso dressing. My mother-in-law tried it and we were dipping everything in it. Totally delicious.

excerpts: The firecracker salmon roll, filed with  tempura salmon, chili sauce, avocado, cucumber, daikon sprouts and crispy shallots, was another winner.
There are eight pieces, so definitely a plate to split.
salmon.author: brewgirl b.
salmon.review:
I really liked Canvass, but this seafood place is a surprisingly tasty replacement.  Great cocktails.  I had a wonderful pisco sour, with the egg whites so, so mild.  My friend had the yuzo drop, with Hangar One vodka, the Japanes citrus fruit and a sugared rim--mmmmm.  

Food portions are huge, so expect to take something home at the end of meal.  Loved the crispy oysters appetizer--very crisp and batter-fried with tender oyster meat on the inside.  The firecracker salmon roll, filed with  tempura salmon, chili sauce, avocado, cucumber, daikon sprouts and crispy shallots, was another winner.  There are eight pieces, so definitely a plate to split.  For the entree, I had one of the "chalkboard specials," which was a simple grilled opah served with a halved artichoke, brown rice, and a chunky tomato and lemon sauce.  It was very flavorful, and I had enough for lunch the next day.  Really liked the cold edamame and fish-shapped crackers they serve instead of boring, table bread and butter.  

No room for dessert, so I dont know how good they are.  Wouldnt mind coming back to find out.

excerpts: I had the Salmon Teriyaki bowl and it was huge, nice to bring home leftovers for lunch!
My friend had the thai salmon and really enjoyed her dish as well.
Her two kids had the salmon sandwhich and mahi mahi and both were very happy with their dishes as well.
We hadn't seen each other in years and we were left to sit and talk and catch up after dinner, not rushed out at all (it was a slow night, plenty of open tables).
I'm glad I gave this place another shot.

After my last review I doubt I would, and the manager messaged me to help try and rectify the situation, which I appreciated (although I couldn't help her with any more info to pinpoint my lousy server).
She was eager to not have it happen again, so hopefully everyone got a reminder on how to be a great server.
All I know is that I certainly enjoyed ours last night, so thanks!
salmon.author: Jen K.
salmon.review:
Ok, I came her again last night.  Despite what my earlier review said.  Some friends from out of town were visiting and wanted seafood.  Since I live in Inner Sunset, Pacific Catch is really the only option.  So, what the hell, give it another try.

OMG, SUCH a better experience.

We had a very friendly waiter who was very helpful with suggestions and attentive but not obtrusive.  The food the second time around was MUCH better as well.  The seafood was fresh, cooked just right and served very quickly.  I had the Salmon Teriyaki bowl and it was huge, nice to bring home leftovers for lunch!  My friend had the thai salmon and really enjoyed her dish as well.  Her two kids had the salmon sandwhich and mahi mahi and both were very happy with their dishes as well.  We hadn't seen each other in years and we were left to sit and talk and catch up after dinner, not rushed out at all (it was a slow night, plenty of open tables).  I'm glad I gave this place another shot.  After my last review I doubt I would, and the manager messaged me to help try and rectify the situation, which I appreciated (although I couldn't help her with any more info to pinpoint my lousy server).  She was eager to not have it happen again, so hopefully everyone got a reminder on how to be a great server.  All I know is that I certainly enjoyed ours last night, so thanks!

excerpts: Also have tried the coconut shrimp (nice and crispy) and the firecracker salmon roll (it was only ok).
salmon.author: Christine C.
salmon.review:
3.5 stars really.

Great happy hour options (one in the evening and one from 10pm to closing), very nice and accomodating staff and the food is good too.

This is where I was first introduced to sweet potato fries! The menu said that one could choose between traditional or spicy fries.... so I asked the waiter if we could have spicy sweet potato fries. The waiter thought I was strange but he did it anyway! And they were delish!

Also have tried the coconut shrimp (nice and crispy) and the firecracker salmon roll (it was only ok). Fish tacos are pretty tasty, too(several options of fish). 

The lemongrass mojitio is a delightfully interesting combination. 

All in all, a good place to have a small bite to eat. It gets busy during dinner time.

excerpts: What I love about Pacific Catch is that when I am feeling taco-y, the salmon tacos are the bomb.
When I am hunkering for a fish sandwich, the spicy ahi is just killer.
Feeling like a rice bowl, the ahi wasabi rice bowl is sushi-grade goodness.
salmon.author: Mark S.
salmon.review:
Good tasting, reasonably priced seafood is hard to find.  Variety in terms of the different ways it is prepared is often pretty limited in most places.

What I love about Pacific Catch is that when I am feeling taco-y, the salmon tacos are the bomb. When I am hunkering for a fish sandwich, the spicy ahi is just killer.  Feeling like a rice bowl, the ahi wasabi rice bowl is sushi-grade goodness.  Heck, my wife and kids even eat there enthusiastically.

We have been long time customers at Chestnut location and were thrilled when 9th avenue opened.  Why?  Bigger menu (try the crab salad with yellowtail appetizer, yum to the vietnamese beef sandwich, crispy calamari, grrr!), nice, warm space and drink-worthy bar (tasty strong drinks).

Highly recommended.  Family friendly too.

excerpts: I have had the Wasabi Ahi sandwich and the Salmon Sandwich, both were amazing!
salmon.author: Maureen R.
salmon.review: Have been to the new Campbell location a couple times now and LOVE this place. I have had the Wasabi Ahi sandwich and the Salmon Sandwich, both were amazing! I have tried all three fries and the original are my fav but my husband likes the sweet potato. The wait staff has been very helpful and there when you need them, but not overbearing. They even had a chalk board and chalk for my son to play with while we waited. It is a little messy but a great way to pass the time until his food arrives. A new favorite place!

excerpts: I still love the salmon sandwich.
salmon.author: Maggie L.
salmon.review:
One would think that going to the bigger Pacific Catch, one would be seated in timely manner but this is not the case. People definitely tend to linger around this one a lot longer than at the Chestnut St. location. Again, sweet potato fries can do no wrong but the service here can definitely do with some speeding up. 

Pretty good sushi rolls and ceviche. Not a big fan of the tacos because they all seem to taste the same, i.e. drenched in the same avocado sauce. I still love the salmon sandwich.

excerpts: The salmon bowl and thai steak salads are particularly good.
Prices are, well, pricey (for a fairly casual place at least), but portions are huge.
Share, or if it's not raw and you can take a second portion home, you've got yourself a deal.
Plus, if you sign up for their newsletter they run monthly promos.
salmon.author: Shoshana D.
salmon.review:
This is one of my favorite places to eat in my hood. You can pretty much please anywhere here since there's a wide array of healthy and not so healthy, a bar, a restaurant area, fishy stuff and not so fishy, ethnic, American, etc... plus, there's even parking (a small lot behind and easier street parking close by in the park). 

I love their sushi bowls and salads since they're flavorful and healthy. The salmon bowl and thai steak salads are particularly good. Prices are, well, pricey (for a fairly casual place at least), but portions are huge. Share, or if it's not raw and you can take a second portion home, you've got yourself a deal. Plus, if you sign up for their newsletter they run monthly promos. I'm not surprised they're doing well and now have multiple locations. 

(Don't read past this if you want to stick to eating healthy) 
Unfortunately, I've also tried their dulce de leche spring roll dessert and it's now one of my favorite desserts (maybe in a three way tie with Bellanico's cheesecake and BiRite creamery ice cream). Soooo good.

excerpts: The grilled salmon salad was nice except that the fish was lacking in flavor, but we were pleasantly surprised by the California Crab & Avocado salad which was just right!
salmon.author: OfLit G.
salmon.review:
We were looking for inexpensive seafood and that's what we got.
The place was clean and the service was friendly and attentive.
We started with the miso soup which was nice and a little fishy (in a good way), the Hawaiian Poke which was fresh enough but really not very well cut - it had unchewable bits, which is a big no-no in raw fish. The Mahi Mahi was overly seasoned and the fish got lost in the dish. The grilled salmon salad was nice except that the fish was lacking in flavor, but we were pleasantly surprised by the California Crab & Avocado salad which was just right! Everybody LOVED the sweet potato fries - yum!
All in all, a decent value for your money in the seafood scene.

excerpts: My friend ordered a salmon sandwich, which came with their awesome sweet potato fries.
salmon.author: Evelyn K.
salmon.review:
The first time that I experienced Pacific Catch was at the original location on Chestnut... but on a busy and blustery Thursday night, we tried for Irving location because we were starved and figured that we had a better chance of getting served and fed more quickly.  

We were told that the wait was 15-20 minutes, which was definitely reasonable...but even better than that, we found a comfortable table in the bar area and was able to plop ourselves down almost immediately.  

I was craving the Ahi Poke Rice Bowl, and it didn't disappoint.  There were piles of spicy poke, with seaweed salad, and heaps of rice to keep me very satiated.  My friend ordered a salmon sandwich, which came with their awesome sweet potato fries.  I think the fries are better as an appetizer because then you get a larger serving and yummy sauces to boot!

I'm tempted to rate PC 5 stars, but I think I need to experience it a few more times and try some more dishes to qualify the rating.

excerpts: Lani is a great server, and Robin gave us great recommendations-- the salmon on cedar , grilled asparagus, mashed red potatoes and corn on the cob
are utterly perfect.
salmon.author: Joan O.
salmon.review:
Fabulous meal; we came here tonight for the 1st time. We definitely wanted warm, yummy food... love the fog but hate the cold! 
Lani is a great server, and Robin gave us great recommendations-- the salmon on cedar , grilled asparagus, mashed red potatoes and corn on the cob are utterly perfect. The macadamia nut borwnie with ice cream and fudge sauce is about as decadent as desserts get. 

Courteous, friendly people. We definitely plan to come back.

We'll bring friends too.  A bit loud, but it helped to be in a booth.

excerpts: The grilled salmon was dried up and burnt.
The waitress seemed quite proud of them being organic salmon, though.
salmon.author: Robert L.
salmon.review:
I thought this would be a good place. Seafood in San Francisco? Sounds like a sure bet.

Not so.  Scallops, while fresh and big, were tasteless and merely lightly grilled.  The grilled salmon was dried up and burnt.  The waitress seemed quite proud of them being organic salmon, though.  They did have some big rice bowls, but you might as well go to the Serramonte Mall's food court if you want to eat rice bowls.

The only saving grace is the sweet potato fries.  And only because not a lot of restaurants have sweet potato fries.  

Two stars because I'm not coming back here and won't recommend anyone else to.

excerpts: 1 BBQ salmon with corn salsa and lime crema, 1 tropical grilled shrimp with mango salsa, and 1 spice-rubbed grilled mahi mahi with avocado tomatilla salsa.
Now let me first say that I am a little biased when it comes to fish tacos.
I've been a long time advocate for Wahoo's fish tacos and nothing has ever compared to their tacos.
Pacific catch however served me some really tasty fish tacos, which can definitely compete with Wahoo's.
I really appreciated the nice quality of salsas and toppings that went into the tacos.
They worked well and tasted great with the various fish and shrimp pairings.
salmon.author: Timothy C.
salmon.review:
Pacific Catch just recently opened on 9t Street and we decided to go try it for a mellow weekend lunch.  We weren't sure what to expect because it was new, but the online menu sure looked great.

The decor is modern and clean, providing a rather trendy atmosphere.  The place wasn't crowded when we came so we didn't have to wait for a table, which is always nice.  We saw one table had ordered the Baja Shrimp Ceviche so we decided to start with that.   The presentation was really cool.  The ceviche, stuffed full of shrimp and avocado, was served in a tall martini glass with a pile of tortilla chips sprawled around the base.  The best thing about this dish was how much shrimp they gave us!  It's always annoying when you pay a premium for a shrimp entre and get 3 shrimp.  We counted each shrimp as we were going through the ceviche, they were good sized shrimp mind you, and ended up with almost 20! The chef was overly generous with the shrimp for the price we payed.

For my entre, I went with 3 tacos; 1 BBQ salmon with corn salsa and lime crema, 1 tropical grilled shrimp with mango salsa, and 1 spice-rubbed grilled mahi mahi with avocado tomatilla salsa.  Now let me first say that I am a little biased when it comes to fish tacos.  I've been a long time advocate for Wahoo's fish tacos and nothing has ever compared to their tacos.  Pacific catch however served me some really tasty fish tacos, which can definitely compete with Wahoo's.  I really appreciated the nice quality of salsas and toppings that went into the tacos.  They worked well and tasted great with the various fish and shrimp pairings.  I took down these bad boys so fast and had to restrain myself from ordering more!

We also ordered sweet potato fries which were good.  I tend to find any type of french fry that offers a spin off the traditional French fry (different potatoes, etc) very satisfying.

Pacific Catch is definitely a decent restaurant and we will for sure go there again.  They had other dishes, such as sushi and fancy deserts that I would also like to try.  I also noticed they had a pretty nice full bar with comfy seats and a decent happy hour.  This would be a good place to come have some drinks and a nice dinner with some friends or even a date.

excerpts: Most recently I tried the chinook salmon, which was very fresh and tasty, but the presentation did not warrant its $19.95 price.
salmon.author: Blake E.
salmon.review:
These guys did a great job with the new space. The basic layout is the same as when it was the Canvas, but they removed the center counter.

Their Japanese rice bowls are awesome. I prefer the udon. Most recently I tried the chinook salmon, which was very fresh and tasty, but the presentation did not warrant its $19.95 price.

I'd go again, but get some of the more budget items. Read: fish and chips.

excerpts: Even though we ordered the Firecracker Salmon Roll and Spicy Tuna Roll, I don't recommend trying the sushi here.
It lacks flavor, authenticity, and freshness..but I didn't expect it to be good
so I wasn't surprised.
salmon.author: Jen Y.
salmon.review:
I was excited to try the Pacific Catch on 9th because I've heard great things about the space and it's kind of a hassle to go all the way to Chestnut. The look of the restaurant is beautifully casual and comfortable with plenty of seating. For that, I give this restaurant big ups. 

Our waitress on the other hand was just blah. It looked like she cared more about socializing and dancing with her co-worker friends more than earning her tip from us. The whole time she seemed insincere from the moment she brought us our drinks to handing us the check. 

I always liked Pacific Catch's food, even though it's slightly over-priced.  The food is the same in terms of taste and the sweet potato fries (which I love w/ the wasabi aeoli) were consistantly yummy. Even though we ordered the Firecracker Salmon Roll and Spicy Tuna Roll, I don't recommend trying the sushi here. It lacks flavor, authenticity, and freshness..but I didn't expect it to be good so I wasn't surprised. The fish tacos are always delicious; especially the Mahi Mahi Fish Taco which is one of my favorites. 

The atmosphere, location, and food is great. However, the waitress we had and the sushi are not. Something else was just lacking as a whole but I can't put my finger on it. But, I will be back to this location..

Service: 2
Food: 4
Atmosphere: 4
Overall: 3.5

excerpts: I went to Pacific Catch this evening for dinner and while I like the concept of the menu I wasn't overly impressed with my salmon teriyaki bowl.
Yes it was fresh, but the rice had a bit too much sauce on it for my taste.
I'm not sure if this was the reason, but I was extremely thirsty after having a few bites of my entree.
Even when I got home
I was thirsty.
salmon.author: Kevin L.
salmon.review:
I went to Pacific Catch this evening for dinner and while I like the concept of the menu I wasn't overly impressed with my salmon teriyaki bowl. Yes it was fresh, but the rice had a bit too much sauce on it for my taste. I'm not sure if this was the reason, but I was extremely thirsty after having a few bites of my entree. Even when I got home I was thirsty. My friend had the grilled mahi mahi which I tasted and thought it was good. We got the sweet potato fries as an appetizer. While they were good I've had them elsewhere so it wasn't that exciting. The sweet potato fries don't hold their temperature long so you need to enjoy them fast.

The decor of the restaurant is eco-friendly and asian themed. They used quite a bit of bamboo throughout the restaurant and use environmentally friendly products per the insert in the menu. Overall I liked the decor and the openess of the restaurant which is a result of the high ceilings. Regardless it's nice to be able to have room when you're dining. 

Service was decent but nothing really spectacular. A manager did come by and greet us and thank us for making a reservation on OpenTable. I'm not too sure if this has anything to do with being an OpenTable VIP member. For those wondering I haven't noticed anything different when dining since being designated a VIP user.

excerpts: I ordered the Hawaiian poke bowl while my female counterpart ordered the miso salmon.
My girlfriend's miso salmon was good however, nothing of the taste made it stand out as a Pacific Catch dish.
salmon.author: Brian V.
salmon.review:
Pacific Catch is a fusion Japanese/seafood place that I've had my eye on for a while.  It sure is gaudy and lures you with the baubles and trinkets however, fails to live up to the expectations.  It is like a beautiful yet underwhelming performer of a car.  Walking in, it is very ample in size.  The ambiance is very cozy and there is a nautical theme.  Our hostess led us to our table and accommodated us when we wanted to sit in the booth.  The back support of soft cushions beats those of hard wooden backings any day.  Our waiter was a very nice chap, a water sprite of some sort...calm and collected on the surface but a giggler I am sure underneath.  

We were given goldfish/unsalted beans to start of the night.  Never was served goldfish as a starter but I can't complain.  I love goldfish.  Alas, it was the nasty pretzel flavored ones.  I ordered the Hawaiian poke bowl while my female counterpart ordered the miso salmon.  We also ordered sweet potato fries.  This was the first time I have ever tried sweet potato fries and I became a believer.  I always thought it was for females for some reason....excuse my ignorant rationale.  It was so good that I hogged the whole basket.  The only thing I was not fond of was the wasabi sauce.  They give you this asian dipping sauce also which is the secret to King of Thai #31...wadDUUUP.  I eat my fries with 2 things...ranch or ketchup.  I grabbed the ketchup bottle, squirted a gob and was good.  While sweet potatoe fries were good, regular french fries still capture the majority of my thump thump.  My poke bowl came out and it looked very good.  They were not scrouges on the poke.  Everything was neatly proportioned...a couple slivers of avacado, wakame salad, radish, a lotta poke, etc.  When I took my first bite, I nearly grimaced.  I forgot to request no wasabe sauce.  While the taste wasn't overly strong, it was still lingering enough to make me quite sad.  My girlfriend's miso salmon was good however, nothing of the taste made it stand out as a Pacific Catch dish.  It tasted like something I could get at any Jap restaurant.  

Pacific Catch is very generous in portions and the price is not too bad.  However, the food, while nice in presentation, was only that...superficial...the way I like my girls...jk jk.  You will leave this place full, no doubt about that, but it is the type of full that leaves you hungering for more tasteful experience.

excerpts: If that doesn't sell you on Pacific Catch, I don't know what will - but their fish salads are pretty awesome, too, Their sushi-grade raw salad is amazing, and the salmon salad with the skin "croutons" is one of the best meals I've ever had.
I'm not really a fan of their appetizers, though, and while the servers are REALLY great, it seems like they're a little understaffed
so sometimes things are slow.
salmon.author: Sydney A.
salmon.review: This place has bottomless Thai ice tea.  If that doesn't sell you on Pacific Catch, I don't know what will - but their fish salads are pretty awesome, too, Their sushi-grade raw salad is amazing, and the salmon salad with the skin "croutons" is one of the best meals I've ever had.  I'm not really a fan of their appetizers, though, and while the servers are REALLY great, it seems like they're a little understaffed so sometimes things are slow.

excerpts: We ordered the sake salmon sashimi, spicy tuna roll, grilled ahi tuna salad and ahi poke wasabi bowl.
The spicy tuna roll had plump pieces of tuna and rolled into a pretty good size roll.
The sake salmon sashimi however was a flop.
When the dish came, it was razor thin.
It tasted like kirkland smoked salmon from costco and the sauce was like watered down cream cheese, we had no clue where the sake infused part was.
Totally not worth the $9.
The salad and the rice bowl were delicious and a lot of food.
The ahi poke was flavorful with a wasabi-ginger sauce over warm rice, wakame and pickled veggies.
salmon.author: Yun W.
salmon.review:
Couple friends took us here to dinner on a Tuesday night.

I really like the decor of this place.  Love the modern look and they have nice outdoor seating with heat lamps.  

Service was great.  The guy was super friendly and attentive.  Once we sat down we got a nice little muchies of edamame and pretzels (I guess a little fusion there too).

We ordered the sake salmon sashimi, spicy tuna roll, grilled ahi tuna salad and ahi poke wasabi bowl.  The spicy tuna roll had plump pieces of tuna and rolled into a pretty good size roll.  The sake salmon sashimi however was a flop.  When the dish came, it was razor thin.  It tasted like kirkland smoked salmon from costco and the sauce was like watered down cream cheese, we had no clue where the sake infused part was.   Totally not worth the $9.  The salad and the rice bowl were delicious and a lot of food.  The ahi poke was flavorful with a wasabi-ginger sauce over warm rice, wakame and pickled veggies.  I will definitely order that again.

This place is a good sit down place with friends and we will come back here next time.

excerpts: I order the spicy tuna roll and this wasabi salmon salad thing, and I was IMPRESSED!
The fish was unbelievably fresh, tasty and flavorful, and overall one of the best fishes I had in a while (both the spicy tuna and the salmon).
Have already gone back a second time and I love it!
But, beware of waitresses that won't come to your table for a whiiillleee.
The fish was unbelievably fresh, tasty and flavorful, and overall one of the best fishes I had in a while (both the spicy tuna and the salmon).
Have already gone back a second time and I love it!
But, beware of waitresses that won't come to your table for a whiiillleee.
salmon.author: Lauren G.
salmon.review:
WOW!!

When I walked into this place, didn't have very high expectations. Although there were a lot of people, the place was a little tacky. We sat down at the table lead by a host who wasn't friendly nor rude. But, when they served us their substitute for bread and butter, my expectations went way further down: their substitute was edamame beans and pretzel goldfish!! Although it's a cute idea to have goldfish at a place called pacific catch, it's a little cheap considering there are $8.95 sushi rolls!

I order the spicy tuna roll and this wasabi salmon salad thing, and I was IMPRESSED! The fish was unbelievably fresh, tasty and flavorful, and overall one of the best fishes I had in a while (both the spicy tuna and the salmon). Have already gone back a second time and I love it! But, beware of waitresses that won't come to your table for a whiiillleee.

excerpts: The bbq salmon taco was amazing.
Same with the crispy shrimp one.
Sandwich was what I expected-
salmon.author: Staci M.
salmon.review:
I have had two really good experiences here.  The first was during their happy hour.  The poke was delicious and they did not skimp.  

A few nights ago, our (well, my) lazy ass decided on take-out.  We had the spicy tuna sandwich and 3 tacos.  The bbq salmon taco was amazing.  Same with the crispy shrimp one.  Sandwich was what I expected- very yum.  

And what was really cool was the care they took in getting the order together.  Sides of two sauces- sweet chili and aioli- for the sweet potato fries.  

I guess they had my boyfriend waiting pretty long for the order, so the bartender bought him a beer.  V cool of them- especially since the bf is not the bitching type and was prob sweetly surprised by the freebie.  THAT'S the stuff people remember.

excerpts: I had the salmon sandwich with a side of sweet potato fries and my pals had 2 salads.
Salmon was just right for my sandwich and the roll it came on was pretty good as well, definitely makes the sandwich better than just any ordinary bread.
The sweet potato fries were great as well, and they came with some sort of tasty honey mustard dipping sauce.
salmon.author: Vilen G.
salmon.review:
Went here for the first time a few days ago and was pretty satisfied. I had the salmon sandwich with a side of sweet potato fries and my pals had 2 salads. Salmon was just right for my sandwich and the roll it came on was pretty good as well, definitely makes the sandwich better than just any ordinary bread. The sweet potato fries were great as well, and they came with some sort of tasty honey mustard dipping sauce.

The salads my friends had looked pretty tasty as well, I will probably have one myself next time I return here. Another great point is the bottomless Thai Iced tea they serve here, I drank so much of it I was sweating thai iced tea later that day.

excerpts: The wasabi bowl comes with sushi rice, avocado, wakame salad, fresh ginger and wasabi, all kinds of other stuff...and beautiful salmon and tobiko.
It was sooo good i stuffed myself to the brim.
salmon.author: Hella M.
salmon.review:
Hell yeah, this food was delicious!  The wasabi bowl comes with sushi rice, avocado, wakame salad, fresh ginger and wasabi, all kinds of other stuff...and beautiful salmon and tobiko.  It was sooo good i stuffed myself to the brim. And the Island Mint cocktail had fresh guava juice, so so refreshing!

The price is fair, appropriate for the food.  I only gave it four stars because it is a bit of a family style place trying to be trendy.  I don't got family out here so wasn't necessarily my cuppa tea...but all in all I loved it and am definitely going back soon!

excerpts: The same dishes are available with salmon, but I prefer mahi mahi.
Nice grilled vegetables go with the plates to ease your health consciousness.
salmon.author: Evelyn B.
salmon.review: Plenty of seating, quick waitstaff, and tasty food. What isn't to like about Pacific Catch? This restaurant gets the job done when it comes to seafood. My go-to items are the mahi mahi terriyaki rice bowl or the mahi mahi sandwich. The same dishes are available with salmon, but I prefer mahi mahi. Nice grilled vegetables go with the plates to ease your health consciousness.

excerpts: -Alaskan 3-course meal w/ halibut skewers, salmon entree, and merengue & berries
: They have a special 3-course meal highlighting the cuisine of places around the Pacific, so when I went, it was Alaska.
I liked the skewers, especially the sauce.
Even though it was battered & fried, it felt really light.
The salmon was just ok -- nothing special.
Didn't like the liquor-soaked ligonberries.
The dessert was PERFECTION!
Great balance of textures & flavors.
-Alaskan Stout
: I hate dark beers, so of course, I wasn't too fond of this.
salmon.author: Miss H.
salmon.review:
Came here without a reservation for Mother's Day dinner. Only a 20 minute wait! Not bad.

Food:
-California Crab & Avocado salad: Pretty good. It tastes like it sounds -- a salad version of a california roll. I probably wouldn't eat the WHOLE thing as a meal though because it's too much of the same thing.
-Korean BBQ Steak: YUM I love beef! This was my choice, so I liked it. If you're looking for the real deal when it comes to Korean BBQ, then obviously it doesn't size up, but the beef was perfection.
-Alaskan 3-course meal w/ halibut skewers, salmon entree, and merengue & berries: They have a special 3-course meal highlighting the cuisine of places around the Pacific, so when I went, it was Alaska. I liked the skewers, especially the sauce. Even though it was battered & fried, it felt really light. The salmon was just ok -- nothing special. Didn't like the liquor-soaked ligonberries. The dessert was PERFECTION! Great balance of textures & flavors.
-Alaskan Stout: I hate dark beers, so of course, I wasn't too fond of this. My parents liked it though.

One of the nicer, bigger places to eat at in the Sunset but if you're looking for a date place, I wouldn't go here. It gets really loud! That could be due to the number of families w/ young kids dining there on Mother's Day though.

excerpts: for entrees, i do recommend the korean bbq skirt steak and  the unagi wasabi bowl - we added grilled fresh salmon to it.
i had the giant scallops which had a jerk chicken like seasoning.
so if you aren't into kicky spices, then this is not the dish for you.
salmon.author: Anh V.
salmon.review:
hmmm, i do love their pomegranate martinis...

the mood is open and casual.  it's unassuming and friendly to families and big groups with choices of seating at the bar, tables and chairs or comfy booths.  

well, since i was not on a liquid diet yet, i had to sample their menu.

thanks to yelpers, i did read up a bit on what to order.

the grilled artichoke was good but yes, do order the sweet potato fries.  i couldn't choose between the two dipping sauces so i compromised on dipping into both.  
the hawaiian poke sashimi was a close second to the fries.

for entrees, i do recommend the korean bbq skirt steak and  the unagi wasabi bowl - we added grilled fresh salmon to it.
i had the giant scallops which had a jerk chicken like seasoning.  so if you aren't into kicky spices, then this is not the dish for you.  the menu is pretty extensive so there is something for everyone.

we ended the evening with the fried dulce de leche spring rolls which were delish.  next time, i'll have to come back and order the passion mango cheesecake.

parking is tough in the neighborhood but there is a lot a block away.  frankly, i rather pony up for the parking and be sipping on their yummy martinis than circling the block.

excerpts: I got the salmon wasabi bowl (be warned the salmon is cooked).
My husband got the tuna wasabi bowl (that was raw).
I didn't particularly like mine
, I guess I should have gotten the tuna.
However, since the meal was called wasabi bowl, I expected wasabi up the ying yang.
I didn't get much of any wasabi kick
so I was disappointed.
salmon.author: Lang T.
salmon.review: Came here for dinner last night because my husband keeps talking how great their Wasabi bowls are. I got the salmon wasabi bowl (be warned the salmon is cooked). My husband got the tuna wasabi bowl (that was raw). I didn't particularly like mine, I guess I should have gotten the tuna.
