++++Peruvian Ceviche
-Thai Coconut Shrimp (they were just okay)
- - Cabo Calamari (soggy, stringy, not impressive)

+Hawaiian Poke - $9.5 Worth it!

Conclusion: If I ever get screwed like that again, and really hungry late at night after a ravenous night of drinkin' it's alright to make an exception.

excerpts: Anyway, it was not a pleasant experience and wished we had gone to the other tons of restaurants in the Inner Sunset.
I guess the lesson learned here is to explicitly ask if the ingredients in a salad are raw or coated in something...
sunset.author: Lucy C.
sunset.review:
I had high expectations for this place after perusing the menu online.  Since I am on a strict clean eating diet to determine some food allergies, I thought this would be a good place to go.

I ordered the Grilled Salmon salad which said it had these ingredients - salmon, green beans, shiitake mushrooms, tomatoes, crispy salmon skin "croutons", citrus-miso dressing. I had the dressing on the side and removed the fried salmon skins (there was way too much...) so it would just be veggies and salmon.  However, after I started eating it, something felt off.  The mushrooms and green beans tasted as if they have been coated in some slick oil.  Somehow there was salad dressing in my salad even though I asked for it to be on the side. The salmon was grilled with the same slick oil that made my digestive system act up for the remainder of the night.  

My husband also had the grilled salmon special. And guess what. He also had his tummy act up for the night as well.

Anyway, it was not a pleasant experience and wished we had gone to the other tons of restaurants in the Inner Sunset. I guess the lesson learned here is to explicitly ask if the ingredients in a salad are raw or coated in something... (Usually when I get a salad the ingredients are raw veggies unless they specifically say its not!)

Pros - 
- Service was great with a very attentive server 
- The restaurant is spacious and good for groups
- There was no wait to be seated even though the place was getting crowded

Cons -
- Parking is tough on the weekends around this area.  We parked a few blocks away
- Food is not super high quality for seafood

excerpts: You can reserve a table which makes the stress of finding a place on a Sunday in the sunset disappear.
Of course you have to park--
sunset.author: Dani K.
sunset.review:
California roll salad. Ceviche.

Thats my lunch after a day at Golden Gate park.

Lots of Asian rice bowls with tons of choices in case I want something warm.

You can reserve a table which makes the stress of finding a place on a Sunday in the sunset disappear. Of course you have to park-- but we usually find something relatively close if we pray to the parking goddesses.

Excellent service. Fair prices.

excerpts: We live in the Inner Sunset and have passed this place by a hundred times and didn't think much of it.
I am so
, so glad we came here for dinner finally!
The Ceviche Trio was amazing, the sushi was great, and the steak tacos were awesome.
Service by our waitress Alyssa was also super friendly and efficient.
She even ran after us a block up 9th to return my husband's sunglasses that he had left on the table.
We will definitely be back!
sunset.author: Celeste R.
sunset.review:
I can't believe we haven't been here sooner! We live in the Inner Sunset and have passed this place by a hundred times and didn't think much of it. I am so, so glad we came here for dinner finally! The Ceviche Trio was amazing, the sushi was great, and the steak tacos were awesome. Service by our waitress Alyssa was also super friendly and efficient. She even ran after us a block up 9th to return my husband's sunglasses that he had left on the table. We will definitely be back! (I also hear they have great happy hour specials!)

One last thing - don't be turned off by the place because it's corporate. The food is really delicious!

excerpts: While I desperately miss the Canvas Gallery, this place is a lovely new addition to one of my favorite neighborhoods, the Inner Sunset.

The food is good while offering many healthy options, the prices mostly reasonable, the feel is spacious, clean and stylish, and there's even a small parking lot by the side of the building with free parking for patrons...

Still, the presentation of the bowl, which arrived covered and was quickly de-topped by the server at the table, gives at least some clue as to what your money buys here:  a higher end experience, even if it's at a chain restaurant, even if the menu looks like a mash-up of Sushi-Bar-Meets-Fish'n'Chips-Joint, even if it's a Monday night in the Inner Sunset.
sunset.author: Amy L.
sunset.review:
While I desperately miss the Canvas Gallery, this place is a lovely new addition to one of my favorite neighborhoods, the Inner Sunset.  The food is good while offering many healthy options, the prices mostly reasonable, the feel is spacious, clean and stylish, and there's even a small parking lot by the side of the building with free parking for patrons...it's hard not to love this place!

This place doesn't add anything special to the neighborhood from a culinary standpoint, since it's another Asian Fusion place on the same block with three (yes, THREE!!!) other Japanese restaurants and within a block or two of several more sushi bars and fish restaurants...and arguably there's something formulaic and trite about the intentional hipness of the decor...

But there's also something to be said for dining in comfort, which is exactly what whoever designed and decorated this restaurant seemed to have in mind:  the lighting is mild and pleasant, the ceiling vaulted, giving the overall feeling of weightlessness, and the chairs and booths are mostly comfortable...although the booths will feel slightly cramped if you are very tall or have a big butt or tummy, since the tables are low and there's a non-removeable 1/2-height cushion behind your back that takes up about 5-6" of your rump room.  If you are under 6' tall and on the slender side, you'll be just fine.

The servers are very friendly and attentive, which is a pleasant departure from many restaurants in San Francisco, where courteous service sometimes seems to have been otherwise forgotten in the shuffle.  Pacific Catch seems to operate the way many serious, highly rated professional restaurant environments do, with a highly trained staff, attention to detail overall, and a menu that reflects modern trends.  For example, this menu offers not only foodie versions of Miso soup, but also a brown rice substitution option for those of us watching our waistlines or simply attempting to eat a more healthy diet.  

I recommend the coconut skewered shrimp and ordering anything that will get you some of their delicious sweet potato fries (healthier than regular fries, at least!)!  Be warned that you won't be able to eat just one...

I also thoroughly enjoyed their salmon teriyaki bowl which came with shitake mushrooms, asparagus cut into the perfect size bites, and bok choy which was cooked to perfection, served over brown rice that's been dosed with some more of their flavorful teriyaki sauce (normally it's served with pineapple fried rice, but I opted for their complimentary brown rice substitution instead).

Their traditional miso soup is average at best, and at twice the price that other Japanese restaurants in the neighborhood will charge for the same size bowl, it's nothing special and you get the feeling it's pricier because everything on the menu is priced a little higher, not because of an increase in quality.  Still, the presentation of the bowl, which arrived covered and was quickly de-topped by the server at the table, gives at least some clue as to what your money buys here:  a higher end experience, even if it's at a chain restaurant, even if the menu looks like a mash-up of Sushi-Bar-Meets-Fish'n'Chips-Joint, even if it's a Monday night in the Inner Sunset.  

There's something to be said for a restaurant that does what it does well.

excerpts: The prices were definisly SF/Sunset-tastic.
sunset.author: Victor C.
sunset.review:
Sunday Lunch Review.

Came here with my coworkers after the AIDS Walk. (On the company), everybody ordered way more than they could handle (except for me).

I got one of the daily catches... and like always, I forgot the name. It was a halibut-like fish from a random country in S.America. It had a bbq dry rub, over (or under?) a green something+cilantro sauce. I give up any further description of my entree.

Appetizers ordered to share included: poke, calimari, and a rock n roll, and maybe something else not worth remembering?

All the appetizers were good, the rock n roll probably wasn't as flavorful and eel-tastic as I would've liked, but still tasty. My entree was fantastic. I had a lemongrass-infused ice tea... that tasted like... lemon ice tea. But it was refreshing after my 6+mile stroll through GG Park.

The prices were definisly SF/Sunset-tastic. (their terriyaki bowls -- which a few of the ladies ordered but none finished, were ~$15).

But, it was good food though. 4-star worthy.

excerpts: This is a great choice for seafood in the Inner Sunset.
They do a few things that basically nobody else manages to pull off, and it always impresses me.
sunset.author: Aaron G.
sunset.review:
This is a great choice for seafood in the Inner Sunset. They do a few things that basically nobody else manages to pull off, and it always impresses me. It's a solid four-star dining experience, but the fact that they can go the extra mile earns them the 5th star.

First, don't get put off by the look. The decor is sort of corporate/franchise-y, but it's definitely not a dressed up TGI Friday's or BJ's or anything of that nature. The ingredients are fresh and high quality, and the food is prepared by people who care and know what they're doing.

Almost everything on the menu is seafood, but they manage to do fusion food better than anywhere else I can think of. Usually most places have a few good dishes in a particular style and if they stray too far, it comes out mediocre.

Here, they do American, Mexican, Japanese, and Korean fusion dishes at about an equally high level. None of the dishes is "like mom used to make", they've all got a unique twist that makes them Pacific Catch dishes. But these twists are all good choices, it's not like a lot of restaurants where they put their version on a classic and end up butchering it in the process.

So basically, the careful attention to the quality of ingredients, the obvious skill in developing the menu, and the ability to do so many diverse things well keeps me coming back.

excerpts: I worked in the inner sunset area today and was excited to try some new lunch spots.
sunset.author: Resa N.
sunset.review:
I worked in the inner sunset area today and was excited to try some new lunch spots.  I ended up yelping a few  places but Pacific Catch caught my attention with the reviews and pictures of their Poke and Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls.

I sat at the bar and ordered my food to go to enjoy it directly across the street from Golden Gate Park.  I ordered:

Poke Appetizer - It really was ono (dee-lish). I mean it wasn't like the real stuff in Hawaii but it was pretty good.  The sushi grade Ahi was cut perfectly and the color was bright (meaning fresh) with just the right amount of marinade.  It did lack the seaweed flavor but the crispy wontons they serve with it was the perfect combination of textures.

Vietnamese Steak Sandwich - Yummy!  It's not your average Bun Mi.  First of all, it's square shaped.  And the bread is soft!!! It still has the same marinated steak, seasoned veggies and heat flavor.  Sandwich came with Sweet Potato fries and a wasabi aioli which was also really good.

Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls - I was so full from the poke and half a sandwich that I didn't really get to enjoy this as fresh as I wanted to, therefore this was just OK to me.  I probably need to try it again to enjoy it more.  It kind of reminded me a skinny chimi cheesecake with vanilla ice cream.  

Regardless, I really enjoyed my food and I'd def be back if in the near vicinity.

excerpts: However, upon entering this huge restaurant at the Inner Sunset location, I don't think I'll ever be going to the Marina location anytime soon.
Though the real reason for that is because I now live in the Inner Sunset.
Anyway, this location has the same great food but with a lot of breathing space.
sunset.author: Rylan C.
sunset.review:
I have the tendency to order the same thing over and over again despite seeing great plates at the neighboring table. But like clockwork, I always order my unlimited Thai Iced tea and my Hawaiian Ahi Poke Rice Bowl. 

This place also has great salads, great fish and chips, and great sushi rolls.

Anyway, I've only ever been to the Marina location of this restaurant (which is EXTREMELY tiny) and I've been a fan. However, upon entering this huge restaurant at the Inner Sunset location, I don't think I'll ever be going to the Marina location anytime soon. Though the real reason for that is because I now live in the Inner Sunset. Anyway, this location has the same great food but with a lot of breathing space. One thing to warn people about is that parking here is just about as hard to find as in the Marina.

I highly recommend this place. Especially if you like seafood.

excerpts: I used to grub at the Marina location once a month, but since they established the Sunset location, I was ecstatic as there is parking lot, more spacious, and no long lines.
sunset.author: Dee T.
sunset.review:
I used to grub at the Marina location once a month, but since they established the Sunset location, I was ecstatic as there is parking lot, more spacious, and no long lines.  

The highlights are the Wasabi Brown Rice Bowls (Usually get the Hawaiian Poke), the Fish Tacos (whatever is the special fish of the day), and the Sweet Potato Fries. The dipping sauces are such a great complement. 

Ambiance is definitely more airy than the Marina joint and the decor has a contemporary feel. 

Prices are reasonable for its generous portions. 

Staff is always friendly and don't make you wait to long to place an order, ask for stuff, or get you the bill. 

Can't wait for my next trip here...

excerpts: Maybe the rouge rough uncouth uncultured student in me has no idea that what they are really serving is the most delectable wine known to the inner sunset.
And if I can't tell, neither can my wallet.
Or my loan debts.
sunset.author: Christina C.
sunset.review:
The miser-li-est combination in the world might be what is happening to me now.  One, I cannot help.  The other, I brought upon myself.

Being Asian (Chinese) and a Student.  Not just a fresh-faced co-ed.  Graduate school.  Professional.  Which means my metabolism can't run on ketchup packets and instant ramen anymore.  Neither can I pull all-nighters and still be coherent enough to be in public the next day.  

The Asian in me loves a good deal.  That's not so bad.  Until you find yourself at home, after a "great" shopping spree with 5 mismatched shoes, none of which are your size.  Just because it was on sale.  And SOMEONE you know must have that size feet.  Then, I look around to make sure that no one is looking.

The Student in me, hates it more and more each day.  Just last week, one of my classmates looked at her loan debt.  HOLY CRAP-O-LA, the amount we have to pay back is like a mortgage!  It's more than a mortgage!  This affirms my current trend of not going on the interwebs for anything productive.

And all this verbal garbage finally brings us to Pacific Catch.  They have a happy hour, which pleases me greatly.  They have food on their happy hour which pleases me even more.  The food includes hawaiian poke (yay raw raw raw fish!), california rolls (real crab, fake sushi), and fried calamari (i just can't get enough of this squiggly stuff).

However, the alcohols are still expensive.  I'm expecting something in the $5 a glass range.  But I think they are more along the $7/glass.  Maybe the rouge rough uncouth uncultured student in me has no idea that what they are really serving is the most delectable wine known to the inner sunset.  And if I can't tell, neither can my wallet.  Or my loan debts.  Oh god.  

To summarize, I would come here for the happy hour, and focus more on the food.  The portions are very generous, there is nothing dainty about it.  Because if you think about it, a roll still uses about 1/2 a cup of rice, which is as much rice as you should be eating in one sitting, you fatty globby sweaty smelly library-hugger.  I like to keep it high in protein with the hawaiian poke.  

Maybe I'll finally learn my lesson and just be content with 2 bar bites.  Do not let the judgmental eye of the waitress guilt you into ordering alcohol.  No, no, no!  You must pass your classes.  

Now, go.  And eat something.

excerpts: This was the only place that fit our specs and fancy that night in the Inner Sunset.
I thought the food was good.
Not spectacular but definitely yummy.
I like that many cuisines styles are available: noodles, sushi rolls, seafood, Hawaiian, Americana.
The sauces are a little heavy
but i'd eat there again w/o hesitation.
Pricing was reasonable.
sunset.author: debbie r.
sunset.review:
Like other reviewers have said, it took me a long while to try this restaurant. It does look like a big ol' chain-style seafood place from the outside and i still miss Canvas, the cafe that used to be in this location but took a deep dive in the dot com bust. The inside is nicely decorated and the layout is good considering how odd the floor plan is. (Canvas always seemed a little... lopsided.)

The bf and i wound up here because we wanted a restaurant that had both decent tequilla and small tapas-like plates. This was the only place that fit our specs and fancy that night in the Inner Sunset. I thought the food was good. Not spectacular but definitely yummy. I like that many cuisines styles are available: noodles, sushi rolls, seafood, Hawaiian, Americana. The sauces are a little heavy but i'd eat there again w/o hesitation. Pricing was reasonable. Probably better if you hit a happy hour.  

I'm giving this review 4 Stars instead of 3 Stars because I liked that the place looked very family friendly; a lot of the groups waiting to be seated had three generations. Also the dining area was roomy enough to space tables appropriately for families with young (= loud) kids. I don't have kids and we sat in the bar area but it's nice to see restaurants in SF that can accommodate families with kids. I guess having chain-style proportions has its pluses.

excerpts: Let me just start by saying that this used to be my favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset, but over the last few months things have changed.
sunset.author: Tati M.
sunset.review: Let me just start by saying that this used to be my favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset, but over the last few months things have changed. I used to LOVE the Hawaiian Poke. it was always fresh, had cucumber pieces and was simply delicious. The last 4-6 times I ordered it, it was a disappointment. The Tuna was not fresh, and one time the waitress said that "its just a different kind of tuna". I eat a lot of Poke, and  I just got back from Maui a few days ago so I know exactly how fresh tuna looks. Not sure if the chef changed, but the quality of this poke has definitely gone down. Maybe its the days I go when the tuna is not fresh? I dont know, but it doesn't make me want to go back as often and when I do I definitely dont order the poke anymore. the cucumber pieces really added flavor, and now its just plain. would love to see the quality improve so I can enjoy it again!

excerpts: I used to come here all the time when I lived in the Inner Sunset, particularly for the late night happy hour, which I loved.
sunset.author: William S.
sunset.review:
Can't believe I haven't written a review on this place.  I used to come here all the time when I lived in the Inner Sunset, particularly for the late night happy hour, which I loved.  Their bar bites include the asparagus roll, spicy tuna roll, and spicy calamari, all for about 5-6 bucks each.  Beers are standard and 3 bucks, well drinks are 4.    

I do sometimes come here as a safe dinnertime option, and it's fine, but I have admittedly waited 4 hours to eat dinner just so I can come here after 10 pm for the happy hour deals.

Sometimes they're inconsistent with their late night HH because one time I went at 10 and they were like closing shop already, so don't get mad at me if that happens to you!

excerpts: it's in the Marina and 2. because it's smaller, but the service there eclipses the service at this inner sunset location.
The staff here are amateurs.
Let's see...
Seat me in the bar area, then bring me water after a 10 minute wait,
then don't return to get my order?
Amateurs.
It's not my first time with this place.
Get rid of the waitstaff, barstaff plus management and start from scratch.
I won't be returning here.
There's nothing here to convince me that I need to spend money to endure the pretentiousness and incompetence of the people who work here.
sunset.author: Jen A.
sunset.review: The Pacific Catch location in the Marina may have some minuses because 1. it's in the Marina and 2. because it's smaller, but the service there eclipses the service at this inner sunset location. The staff here are amateurs. Let's see... Seat me in the bar area, then bring me water after a 10 minute wait, then don't return to get my order? Amateurs. It's not my first time with this place. Get rid of the waitstaff, barstaff plus management and start from scratch. I won't be returning here. There's nothing here to convince me that I need to spend money to endure the pretentiousness and incompetence of the people who work here.

excerpts:
Sob story over... back to me now...

... checked it out on a nice and sunny Sunday (those rare ones in the Inner Sunset when you can wear shorts, a tank and flip flops) and had a great time.
sunset.author: Amit S.
sunset.review:
ACK! That's Marlin, Nemo and Dory you're serving on my plate, you freak!

... just kidding! 

This place is actually not that bad at all. Even months after they reopened, I could not make myself go in for the simple fact that I was an avid fan of the Canvas Gallery that occupied the space before, and to see it close was truly sad... I am in mourning...

... OK. Sob story over... back to me now...

... checked it out on a nice and sunny Sunday (those rare ones in the Inner Sunset when you can wear shorts, a tank and flip flops) and had a great time.

I recommend:
- Warm Edamame (sea salt is umm good!)
- House-made Miso Soup (dunno who'se "house" it was made in but they make it darn good)
- Hawaiian Poke (my FAV dish here! the tuna on the wonton crisp is just something else... this Hawaiian can poke me any ole time!)
- Cabo Calamari (What? Messican Calamari?? Odd name but all the same pretty good thought a wee bit greasy with the deep frying)
- Fish & Chips (Can't go wrong with this one... actually, you can! good but not as good as Woodhouse Fish Company)
- Teriyaki Bowl ((nice especially with bok choy, sprouts and nori!)
- Macadamia Nut Brownie (DROOL! DRIP!... nuf said!)
- Bloody Mary (Sunday and Bloody Mary's?? Ya betcha!)

Nice place, crowd (tourists, neighbors, folks from other hoods), kid friendly, dog friendly (outside), waiter service outdoors can be a bit iffy until you throw in some 'tude.

excerpts: Best Happy Hour in Inner Sunset -- be sure to get the poke.
sunset.author: Sean K.
sunset.review:
Best Happy Hour in Inner Sunset -- be sure to get the poke.

I wish it were possible to rate a restaurant twice on different types of meals. Like, one for breakfast and one for lunch... because this place would get five stars for the bar and four on dinner. But failing that, I'm breaking out the elusive fifth star on the bar alone.

First up, this place serves Flor de Cana as its house rum. If you've never had Flor de Cana then you are missing out. Made in Nicaragua, I have yet to see it for sale direct to consumers outside of its native country. But in Nicaragua, you can't swing a dead cat without hitting a bottle. States side, it's a rare treat... except not anymore, because I can get it any day I want, especially between the hours of 4-6 M-F and after 10 every day, when well drinks are just four dollars.

But no review is complete without a mention of their poke. In my mind Pacific Catch serves the archetypical poke. Healthy chunks of well marinated tuna with crispy won-ton-eqsue things. Seriously, I could eat it every day. And during happy hour, it's only like $5+ (usually $8-9). Paired with a rum and coke, I can't imagine a better way to relax after work.

Truth is, as much as I love the food and drink, I think what really makes the Pacific Catch bar great is ambiance. From the little group tables, to the high table for two, the whole place is just built for relaxation. Most bars I find to be on either too grungy or too snooty. For me, Pacific Catch is just perfect, and I'm looking forwards to getting to know the bartenders as I develop "regular" status.

excerpts: My new favorite place in the Inner Sunset for sure
sunset.author: Lance B.
sunset.review:
I don't know why this place has any less than 5 stars

- Food, insanely tasty and healthy to boot
- Service, prompt and nice - free refills on soda!
- Atmosphere, clean, stylish
- Price, very reasonable 

My new favorite place in the Inner Sunset for sure

excerpts: and I think Pacific Catch adds a lot to the Inner Sunset restaurant selection.
sunset.author: Kerry D.
sunset.review:
Under the sea
Under the sea
Nobody beat us
Fry us and eat us
In fricassee
We what the land folks loves to cook
Under the sea we off the hook
We got no troubles
Life is the bubbles
Under the sea!

I feel really bad for people who don't eat seafood.  I love me some fish! 
 
I know a lot of feathers were ruffled when Pacific Catch took the place of Canvas.  One less hipster coffee shop in SF, boo-freakin-hoo.  I really like what they did with the space here and I think Pacific Catch adds a lot to the Inner Sunset restaurant selection.  
The Hawaiian poke is my personal favorite (that's what SHE said), on top o' rice bowl or a salad.  The Baja Shrimp Ceviche starter is a another highlight, arriving in a classy martini glass with tortilla chips.  Island tacos, fresh sushi rolls, stews and fish and chips (with sweet potato fries!)  are also scrumptious choices and help diversify the menu.  There really is a little something for everyone.  This location next to the park is ideal and the limited outdoor seating is lovely.  

I've had consistently spotty service here, with the place both packed and empty.  But even so, luckily the food itself is consistently delicious and fresh.  If you have the patience to endure being ignored by the waitstaff and a large space CRAWLING with young kids (Hey -I love 'em, but I know some people don't....) Pacific Catch is a solid casual dining spot.

excerpts: and since I live in the Sunset this is sad.
sunset.author: Heidi B.
sunset.review: Ate there last week and it was bad-sweet potato fries were very oily and soggy the coconut shrimp were not well cooked the artichoke was hardly done and we couldn't eat it.Sorry but this is the worst meal I ever ate there and since I live in the Sunset this is sad.

excerpts: It was the best cafe in all of sunset.
Sad that it closed.
sunset.author: Xiaoyin W.
sunset.review:
This space is just fabulous. It's on the corner of 9th and Lincoln. I loved this space when it was Canvas Cafe. It was the best cafe in all of sunset. Sad that it closed. But anyway, enough nostalgia.

The restaurant is very spacious. The way they set up the tables gives you a lot of privacy. Reason we came here was because my friend loved their sweet potato fries. It didn't disappoint. Sushi here is good too. They used to make a roll with mango that was(and I quote) "like orgasm in my mouth". We didn't see it on the menu anymore so ordered sake sake roll (salmon soaked in sake) instead. It wasn't fancy but it was damn good.

Now the entrees, I got the miso salmon and my friends got ahi three way and korean bbq beef. I was already half full at this point so I didn't enjoy my entree as much as I could have had I been famished.  Overall pretty tasty still. The rice is sushi rice (slighty sour), kinda neat.  All 3 ways of the ahi were raw. I had a bite and liked it. But I don't know about eating a whole entree of raw fish and sushi rice. Korean bbq beef was sweet and fatty and juicy and all that good stuff.

Dinner for three=$87 plus tips.

Would come back again, but this time will be mentally prepared to dish out some cash.

excerpts: But the sweet potato fries and calamari that I nicked from my comrades-in-sunset-drinking were impressive, and they even have that sauce, known to me only as "crack sauce" (and which I previously thought endemic to Seattle breweries) that leaves an indelible mark on the buds of all who taste it.
sunset.author: Wes M.
sunset.review:
Must...boycott...trendy seafood place that replaced Canvas...

What's that you say?  They have a bar?  With Coconut Porter?  Part of the Microcanning Revolution?  Well, maybe just a quick gander then.

Sure enough, the blond ceiling and red walls have a suburban sheen that's as overly-polished as Tom Scholz' production on the Boston songs coming from their 100% classic-rock speakers.  And the giant plastic bottles of chinese hot sauce on every table sort of belie the trendiness factor.

But the sweet potato fries and calamari that I nicked from my comrades-in-sunset-drinking were impressive, and they even have that sauce, known to me only as "crack sauce" (and which I previously thought endemic to Seattle breweries) that leaves an indelible mark on the buds of all who taste it.  So I'm just saying.

But guys, seriously, turn the lights down after 9, would ya?  You'll save the earth and your potential for booze-friendly ambiance.

excerpts: Wandering around Golden Gate Park and DeYoung Museum, we realized we were close by the many restaurants in the Inner Sunset.
sunset.author: Janet H.
sunset.review:
Wandering around Golden Gate Park and DeYoung Museum, we realized we were close by the many restaurants in the Inner Sunset.  We walked into Pacific Catch on a beautiful day.

For starters we each got the Signature Miso and Shiitake Miso.  I thought the miso could have had a little bit more flavor in the broth, but it was still good.  The shiitake miso had veggies (mushrooms & asparagus) which made it also good.

Our entrees were the Sesame Crusted Ahi and the Crispy Catch of the Day.  I chose the Ahi as a healthy alternative and it was seared perfectly.  The catch was fresh rock cod served with sweet potato fries.  Although the rock cod was battered, it didn't taste to overly deep fried like what you would expect.  Also we ordered 2 a la carte tacos, the BBQ Salmon and the Tropical Shrimp which were very good.

We noticed there was loud music playing overhead (why?).  We also noticed that Pacific Catch is kid friendly.  This is a plus for parents who are looking for a healthier choice than a diner or greasy spoon.  Pacific Catch is a good midday meal!

excerpts: I've been more than a couple of times and was really glad when this location opened up, closer to me in the Sunset!
sunset.author: Nebula H.
sunset.review:
I have to say that I am in general a meat-eater. I love meat. Lots and lots of it. So imagine my surprise when I went to Pacific Catch and loooved it. I've been more than a couple of times and was really glad when this location opened up, closer to me in the Sunset! 

I must be a closet salad/healthy-food eater because I can not get enough of the wasabi bowls... Hawailian Poki Wasabi Bowl = jaw-droppingly good. I even like the salads too. Their sushi rolls are also HUGE and delicious. I will always be willing to come back here if I need a dose of good but also fairly healthy food. 

This was really memorable: One time I took a friend here for the first time. She really likes salad. She nearly had happy tears streaming down her face after taking the first bite of her wasabi bowl. And I was just chomping down on a pretty good fish taco. Good times.

excerpts: All good...beauiful day in the sunset...cant beat those!!
Walked past the cute little tables in their patio and was seated right away and attended to.
The entire menu looked super yum!
sunset.author: Tammy H.
sunset.review:
Still not off the Hawaii tip =p  Wanted something close to the spicy tuna bowl I had at Aloha Sushi in Honolulu....rice, 2 scoops of spicy tuna, and all the fixins in a bowl.  The bf suggested Pacific Catch for the comparable taste.  
Parking was a (%&# as usual around 9th/Irving on a beautiful Sunday afternoon right next to GG park.  All good...beauiful day in the sunset...cant beat those!!  Walked past the cute little tables in their patio and was seated right away and attended to.  The entire menu looked super yum!  I seriously had to narrow it down from sweet potato fries, crispy oysters, teriyaki bowls, macademia crusted seabass, catfish sandwich, sushi....it was rather extensive!!  We finally narrowed it down to....

Spicy Fries:  Normal fries just tossed with a cajun seasoning I think.  I LOVE fries so it was a great version...especially since they were "skinny" fries that were super crispy.  The dipping sauces were a nice touch: sweet chili sauce (the one for lumpia!!...I blended that combo LONG before I came here!!  I like their thinking here) and a creamy miso dip!!  yum!!  Mix them together...its perfect!

Salmon Wasabi Bowl:  I thought it was going to be raw salmon but it turned out to be grilled. Apparently the raw stuff is the Hawaiian Poke?  How the hell was I suppose to know that??!!  I wish there was a description on the menu.  Boooo!!  Even though I was in the mood for raw fish the salmon was a great compliment to the brown rice covered with a wasabi miso sauce, radish sprouts, seaweed salad, cucumber salad, pickled ginger and avocado.  It was all the ingredients to a honkin sushi roll but in a bowl.  For about $15, the portions were huge, fresh, and tastey.  I probably ate a little less than half and was STUFFED!  

Tuna Wasabi Bowl: Same condiments in the bowl just with lighly seared tuna.

I think I was a little disappointed that the salmon was cooked, obviously my fault, but I still enjoyed my meal.  Looking around at the other tables and their selections, the wasabi bowl was probably the best priced dish.  The menu will definitely bring me back to finalize their rating.  I cant wait to try all the other delicious goodies....crispy oysters....mmmm...cant wait!!!

excerpts: I had gone to the Pacific Catch in the Marina earlier this month and whined on Yelp about how they should open one in Inner Sunset
(see review on 6/3/2007).
Lo and behold, tonight I walked past where the Canvas Gallery used to be and there are signs plastered advertising that Pacific Catch will soon be opening
it's third outpost here on 9th and Lincoln.
sunset.author: Pelle Y.
sunset.review:
12/1/2007
My friends and I are huge Pacific Catch fans and we attended the complimentary lunch service today.  Pacific Catch on 9th lived up to and exceeded our expectations based on our experiences at the Corte Madera and Marina locations.

We like our poke bowls and didn't stray from our typical ordering.  The poke bowls arrived and were perfectly made.  The poke was fresh, abundant, and authentic (confirmed by the Hawaiian at our table).  It went well with the accompanying seaweed salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, shredded cucumber, and pickled ginger.  The sweet potato fries also hit the spot.  We had some wine and beer but it was too early to have a hard drink from the full bar.  I do look forward to trying their cocktail menu though.

It seems to be a huge staff.  The waiters seemed a tad nervous but the hostesses, general manager, and head chef were pros.  Overall, service was nice, happy, friendly and attentive.  But granted, it's an opening and to be expected.  We hope they can maintain it.

It was nice to see that they made good use of the enormous Canvas Gallery space.  There are plenty of comfy booths and tables all around and many counter seats are also available by the kitchen.  The bar is set off and mostly faces Lincoln and the park, which will help to siphon off the expected noise and buzz.  There is also a section by the 9th Street side, which can probably be closed off and booked for private parties.

The design is warm and inviting, similar to the Corte Madera location.  We liked all the bamboo too.  Good feng shui.

Welcome to the neighborhood, Pacific Catch.

P.S. And to everyone that got annoyed I reviewed this location before it opened, well, hey, tough.  Chalk it up to my rational exuberance.  And c'mon, there are more things in life to have snits about.

6/20/2007
How funny.  I had gone to the Pacific Catch in the Marina earlier this month and whined on Yelp about how they should open one in Inner Sunset  (see review on 6/3/2007).  Lo and behold, tonight I walked past where the Canvas Gallery used to be and there are signs plastered advertising that Pacific Catch will soon be opening it's third outpost here on 9th and Lincoln.  Although the owner planned this months before my Yelp whine, score for me!

And yes, although I haven't tried the food yet since it hasn't opened (expect late summer), I already give it one more star than the review I gave the Marina Pacific Catch because it will be in my beloved hood and it will have a full bar.

You can read more here: 
http://www.pacificcatch.com/press_sunsetbeacon.html

excerpts: It's Sunset.. and it's always gonna be cold n shiz.
sunset.author: S L.
sunset.review:
I don't know.. this place isn't all that and a bag of chips to me-- maybe everyone I know just played it up, and I expected too much from it.  Sorry Pacific Catch, it's not your fault.

The decor is nice and cute.  I really love the outdoor seating area, but let's face it:  It's Sunset.. and it's always gonna be cold n shiz.  The inside is cute too-- perfect little first date place.

The food is.. uhh.. meh?  We ordered the tacos (honestly, I've had better tacos at baja fresh)... and the california salad with the wasabi dressing? (forgot the exact name).  Both were blah... very very blah.  Even my friend, a loyal customer to the other Pacific Catch location, commented on the lack of quality at this particular location.

I heard that the other location is way better, and I probably just came during an off day.  

2 stars anyway cuz of the cute decor and bowl of complimentary snacks.  
FYI: I'm not one to give bad reviews (check my other reviews).. but for the price I'm paying, the food here really sucks !!!

excerpts: I was pretty excited to hear Pacific Catch was coming to the Inner Sunset.
Prior to their opening, I had only visited the Chestnut location.
Pacific Catch offers my favorite salad in the city, Sushi-Grade Ahi.
I branched off once, ordering the fish tacos.
sunset.author: alexa c.
sunset.review:
I was pretty excited to hear Pacific Catch was coming to the Inner Sunset. Prior to their opening, I had only visited the Chestnut location. Pacific Catch offers my favorite salad in the city, Sushi-Grade Ahi. I branched off once, ordering the fish tacos. Alright, but definitely not worthy of replacing my salad, it's why I go here!

It was New Year's Eve. It was cold and dark so I wasn't really in a salad mood so I opted for the Sushi-Grade Ahi rice bowl. Same ingredients as the salad, just warm rice instead. It was good, but it most definitely still didn't compare to my favorite salad IN THE WORLD! 

This place has a lot more to offer as far as seating and ambiance are concerned. I love the ambiance and decor. Seating includes tables, booths, sushi bar and bar/lounge seating. There's also a full bar. It's a great place for dinner or apps with a few drinks. I know I'll be frequenting this place plenty. And I look forward to it.

Oh yeah, service was nice too. Kyle took care of us, good guy!

excerpts: Well, I don't get over to the sunset much, but it sure beats the marina!
Parking was even easy...there were tons of spots across the way in GG park.
Sweet!
sunset.author: Shannon R.
sunset.review:
So I finally don't have to schlep it to the marina anymore when I'm craving some Pacific Catch! I'll raise a glass or two of Ozeki nigori sake to that, hell yeah! (which is exactly what I did tonight!) 

Housed in the old Canvas Cafe spot, this Pacific Catch is at least ten times larger than the one on Chestnut. And, dude, get this: you can make reservations on open table!!! How rad is that?!? I got on open table at around 5:30 pm and made a reservation for two for 6:45 pm, same night! It didn't look like there would have been a wait in any case, even if we had just walked in off the street (this was on a tuesday). 

We got the calamari, the spicy salmon roll, and the crab & avocado salad. Both the sushi and the salad we BIG, but we managed to polish everything off! The service was top notch. Our server checked back with us several times during the meal and was way on the ball. Nice. 

The prices are great for the type of food they serve and for the quality and freshness, but stuff adds up. You can drop fifty, no prob, especially if you have a drink or two. Well, I don't get over to the sunset much, but it sure beats the marina! Parking was even easy...there were tons of spots across the way in GG park. Sweet!

excerpts: Good prompt service, tasty food and great drink options make Pacific Catch the darling of the inter Sunset.
sunset.author: J A.
sunset.review:
I'm really happy that my hood has attracted a great new restaurants like Pacific Catch. They serve an assortment of seafood in a variety of styles in a very modern setting. 

I had an order of the California Rolls, crab salad and Shrimp Teriyaki bowl. All were over sized portions and delicious. This was way too much food to order. The service was beyond my expectation. A full bar added to overall experience. 

No buts, I recommend going there. Good prompt service, tasty food and great drink options make Pacific Catch the darling of the inter Sunset.

excerpts: This is one of my favorite places in the Inner Sunset to take friends out to when I want to show them that the Inner Sunset is NOT just a sleepy suburb attached to a major metropolis.
sunset.author: Jordan Y.
sunset.review:
This is one of my favorite places in the Inner Sunset to take friends out to when I want to show them that the Inner Sunset is NOT just a sleepy suburb attached to a major metropolis. 

The food is fantastic, well presented, thoughtful, and just down right tasty. 

The staff is helpful, friendly, and all sorts of adjectives that say that they do their job well. 

Overall, I have to say that this is just a favorite pick on Golden Gate Park and a great spot for seafood lovers (and really, who dosnt love seafood in SF)

excerpts: Parking, always a bitch in this part of the Sunset wasn't too bad.
By that I mean that we got lucky and actually found a spot on 9th.
We walked in and were greeted by the hostess and advised that we would have to wait for a table unless we didn't mind eating in the bar.
Cool.
I don't really care.
The hostess lead us to the bar where we were seated at the most awkward table that I have ever sat at.
The table doesn't give you room for your legs causing you to sit back and lean forward in an awkward position when eating.
sunset.author: Mike M.
sunset.review:
Very nice. With all the restaurants that come and go in San Francisco, how many of them actually specialize in Seafood? I must say that I waited quite a while to check this place out since I thought it was just another new and trendy place. My biannual dinner with Dad day came around and we decided to check this place out. 

Parking, always a bitch in this part of the Sunset wasn't too bad. By that I mean that we got lucky and actually found a spot on 9th. We walked in and were greeted by the hostess and advised that we would have to wait for a table unless we didn't mind eating in the bar. Cool. I don't really care. The hostess lead us to the bar where we were seated at the most awkward table that I have ever sat at. The table doesn't give you room for your legs causing you to sit back and lean forward in an awkward position when eating. It appears that the owner never sat at these tables prior to buying them. 

It then came time to order drinks and I was pleasantly surprised with their beer selection. I had a Tahitian beer that I really enjoyed. 

I can't remember exactly what we ordered bu know that the Ahi Poki was the most memorable. This place is fresh, fresh fresh! The food was truly outstanding and refreshing. I walked out of there thinking that I actually ate pretty healthy. 

Good job guys, just replace those freakin tables!

excerpts: The interior design and the high ceiling of the restaurant felt warm and cozy, and definitely made me feel like I was out of the Sunset.
This is definitely a romantic restaurant and would be a great place to take a girl on a date.
Maybe not a first date though, cause the noise level kills that.
sunset.author: Adrianna C.
sunset.review:
I took my friends here as a late Christmas dinner, subsitute present after my other friend told me how delicious this place was. After confirming the fact on Yelp, I decided to make a reservation. As my friend and I sat and waited for our other friends to arrive, the waiter was kind and attentive. He asked us if we wanted anything to eat as we waited, filled our water cups, and gave us our complentary plate of edamame and pretzel gold fishes. 

To start we ordered Rock & Roll and also sweet potatoe fries. The sweet potatoe fries were really good and the sauce was delicious. Rock & Roll, not so much - it's not that it was bad, rolls are just not a good choice for this restaurant. Anywho, my friend and I ordered the wasabi bowl with ahi tuna and crab salad to share. The bowl was really good and had huge portions. The salad had a lot of crab, but not much flavor. The Thai salad on the other hand I liked. My other friend ordered the salmon sashimi. It wasn't good and unlike the heaping portions of salad and wasabi bowl - it was lacking. She ended up eating from our plates. The meal came out to $80 with tax and tips. A little pricey, but considering what we ate and the occasion, it was pretty good. I would come back, when my wallet permits it. 

The interior design and the high ceiling of the restaurant felt warm and cozy, and definitely made me feel like I was out of the Sunset. This is definitely a romantic restaurant and would be a great place to take a girl on a date. Maybe not a first date though, cause the noise level kills that.

excerpts: Although limited, still very convenient, especially in the sunset district.
sunset.author: Anne K.
sunset.review:
1 star for their accommodating parking spaces in the back of restaurant. Although limited, still very convenient, especially in the sunset district.

1 star for their prime customer service. The entire staff was very friendly. From the start of our experience with the host, to the end of the meal when the manager approached our table for comments.

1 star for their food. What an array of interesting selections. I enjoyed the sweet potato fries with the flavorful aioli. The fish tacos were also yummy.
A few other items that were a hit for my party were the california rolls, spiced cajun fries and wasabii chicken bowl.

Last star for the spacious floor plan. The tables and chairs weren't so crowded around each other and the place was very family friendly. 

The only reason they were shy of 5 stars were the prices. Some items were a bit overpriced for the quantity of food given.

excerpts: I'm so glad that they opened up a Pacific Catch in Inner Sunset...
sunset.author: Diane L.
sunset.review:
I'm so glad that they opened up a Pacific Catch in Inner Sunset... the Marina one is just WAY WAY WAY too small and difficult to get to with parking issues too.  

Pacific Catch is in no way supposed to be close to being authentic japanese food.  Instead of serving you bread, they give you a small plate of fish pretzels and edamame beans.  

They have a large variety of dishes to try.  I like their wasabi bowls.  It comes with seaweed, fish (depending on what kind, I get the Ahi Tuna or Poke Tuna), guacamole, and some other ingredients I don't remember.  The bowl itself is pretty big, and will definitely fill you up!  It costs about $15 for this bowl.  Their sweet potato fries are also very delicious, served with sweet and sour sauce.  Their sushi rolls are average, and nothing spectacular...

I tried their soup special one day... I forget the actual name of it, but it was similar to a ciopinno.  It was a tomato based soup with seafood.  The broth was very flavorful!  There was plenty of content in the soup too.  I was actually surprised by how much I enjoyed it!!  The soup cost about $12 though.  But very delicious.  It's something not always on their menu.

Their fish and chips were very good, comes with about 3-4 pieces depending on what combo you get...  The fish was fresh.  I also got a fish special of the day.  The fish was cooked nicely, and not overcooked.  I don't remember what was in it, but it was reallygood over all.

Overall, if you go here, get their fish dishes.  It's not as cheap as the other restaurants on Irving, but it's worth it for what they give you.  They also can take large groups with reservations... we had a group of 14 or so and the service wasn't bad or lagging at all.

excerpts: Was disappointed they didn't have hot sake (only cold), to thaw out from the especially bitter Sunset chill.
sunset.author: Cathy K.
sunset.review:
Maybe it was because it was kinda late for a Monday night supper, but I had the fish tacos and they were pretty bland.  

Was disappointed they didn't have hot sake (only cold), to thaw out from the especially bitter Sunset chill.

However, their yam fries were hot + crispy, with scrumptious inner ~ most excellent :)

The service + space are also fantastic.  I'd go back to try some of their other dishes.  For now, 3.5.

excerpts: , I was a bit apprehensive to try out the new place in the Sunset.
sunset.author: Jen P.
sunset.review:
In a nutshell: Yummy! Good service, great location, nice & casual ambiance.

Having had an AWFUL experience at their ugly stepsister restaurant on Chestnut, I was a bit apprehensive to try out the new place in the Sunset. Given that it's a new location & the staff is still fairly new, I had a fabulous lunch here today!

The location can't be beat, across the street from GG park. Much closer for me to get to, living in the Richmond. They did a great job with the space. This location is far more comfortable than the Chestnut PC. Lots of space and casual dining means parents with babies. LOTS of them. However, this actually wasn't too bad at all since the acoustics of this PC just makes everyone's noises blend in to the overall sound of dining.

I ordered my usual, the crab salad wasabi rice bowl. It came out promptly and was delicious!!! Lots of crab salad and toppings. 

Our server was obviously new but did a great job nonetheless. Our waters and soda didn't ever stay empty for long and he came by regularly to check how we were doing. 

Overall, this location is FAR better than the one on Chestnut. Pac Catch has finally redeemed itself, I'll be back for sure.

excerpts: I think this place will continue to be an important part of the inner sunset scene for years to come because it reeks of good vibes.
sunset.author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.
sunset.review:
If you ever have a chance to purchase the oatmeal stout at this restaurant I would highly recommend it. The oatmeal stout is a very sophisticated beverage that really defines what's possible if you get creative with your brewing processes. 

The location of this place (on the lively corner of Lincoln and 9th Ave) makes Pacific Catch an excellent venue for happy hour meet ups or one on one dates.

I personally prefer the outside patio sitting but those are usually fairly busy during peak hours.

Also I would recommend the sweet potato fries and shimp ceviche.

I think this place will continue to be an important part of the inner sunset scene for years to come because it reeks of good vibes.

excerpts: I like this location more than sunset since there's lots and lots of parking everywhere.
Plus after going here you can always go a block away and go to Arizmendi.
The fried Oyster and other Fried dishes I tasted there
I didn't really care for much.
Some alcohol would help make it taste better.
I also didn't really like their alcoholic drinks much.
sunset.author: Nir B.
sunset.review:
What I like that this place does is give you a stamp card. For every 8 lunches you have you get a free lunch. I don't know of any other seafood place that does this in SF. I am a sucker for the Ahi stuff. I enjoy the sandwich there. I like this location more than sunset since there's lots and lots of parking everywhere. Plus after going here you can always go a block away and go to Arizmendi. 
The fried Oyster and other Fried dishes I tasted there I didn't really care for much. Some alcohol would help make it taste better.
I also didn't really like their alcoholic drinks much.

excerpts: Since I live in Inner Sunset, Pacific Catch is really the only option.
sunset.author: Jen K.
sunset.review:
Ok, I came her again last night.  Despite what my earlier review said.  Some friends from out of town were visiting and wanted seafood.  Since I live in Inner Sunset, Pacific Catch is really the only option.  So, what the hell, give it another try.

OMG, SUCH a better experience.

We had a very friendly waiter who was very helpful with suggestions and attentive but not obtrusive.  The food the second time around was MUCH better as well.  The seafood was fresh, cooked just right and served very quickly.  I had the Salmon Teriyaki bowl and it was huge, nice to bring home leftovers for lunch!  My friend had the thai salmon and really enjoyed her dish as well.  Her two kids had the salmon sandwhich and mahi mahi and both were very happy with their dishes as well.  We hadn't seen each other in years and we were left to sit and talk and catch up after dinner, not rushed out at all (it was a slow night, plenty of open tables).  I'm glad I gave this place another shot.  After my last review I doubt I would, and the manager messaged me to help try and rectify the situation, which I appreciated (although I couldn't help her with any more info to pinpoint my lousy server).  She was eager to not have it happen again, so hopefully everyone got a reminder on how to be a great server.  All I know is that I certainly enjoyed ours last night, so thanks!

excerpts: I'd def go again as a standard in the inner sunset.
sunset.author: Grace G.
sunset.review:
Better than I thought. =P I must admit that I walked in w/ mediocre expectations -- just another Japanese fusion place. And in reality, it pretty much is that, but its also surprisingly tasty! I had a wasabi bowl, which, oddly enough, doesn't include wasabi. (go figure). It was described to me as all the ingredients that go into a sushi roll...but in a bowl. So you have your unagi or ahi tuna w/ the sushi rice, strips of nori, cucumber, etc...I got it w/ the sushi rice and it was very yum. 

If you like sweet drinks, the kumquat mojito is uuuber yums, even if you're not a fan of mojitos. Its just sweet, but you will have to deal w/ all the mint leave and over-excessive foliage in your drink. =P I'd def go again as a standard in the inner sunset.

excerpts: I am reviewing one item on the menu, the Sunset Rolls.
Such a simple name
BUT this roll is perfection in texture and taste and freshness.
Beautiful presentation on top of everything else that will bring me back for more, and more.
Thank you, Pacific Catch, for doing something SO right!
sunset.author: Rona M.
sunset.review: I am reviewing one item on the menu, the Sunset Rolls.  Such a simple name BUT this roll is perfection in texture and taste and freshness.  Beautiful presentation on top of everything else that will bring me back for more, and more.  Thank you, Pacific Catch, for doing something SO right!

excerpts: I really miss The Canvas...but a nice turnout & change for the Sunset.
I'll try Pacific Catch again since my friend was raving about the rice bowls & Japanese dishes.
I guess the good tip here is stay away from the Mexican style dishes from here...too Americanized.
sunset.author: L S.
sunset.review:
Went for a nice dinner out with the hubby. He had the Surf & Turf with asparagus. Nicely cooked & flavored. I had shrimp & fish tacos with black beans. I didn't enjoy it much, but did like the pretzel goldfishes & edamame served at the start of the meal. And then was dessert...we chose the brownie a la mode & uh...won't have it again.

I really miss The Canvas...but a nice turnout & change for the Sunset. I'll try Pacific Catch again since my friend was raving about the rice bowls & Japanese dishes. I guess the good tip here is stay away from the Mexican style dishes from here...too Americanized. The prices a little too high for the food, but presentation counts?!?

I'll visit again. Nice environment & vibe. Cool a$$ servers.

excerpts: I have been here on a number of occasions (i.e. the bigger restaurant in the Sunset -- I have never been to the original hole-in-the-wall place in the Marina) and I remain unconvinced & on-the-fence about the place.
The location is in a well-trafficked area near a main entrance to Golden Gate Park and in the busy 9th & Irving area of the Sunset.
It's a big, comfortable-looking restaurant with a large-ish bar area facing the Park.
The menu has a large selection of seafood dishes (as the restaurant name would suggest) done in a variety of fusion-ish ways.
Some of these are predictable, and in my experience, not that exciting.
I have had the Fish & Chips and the Fish Tacos in the past, and I wasnt very impressed by either.
(Big portions... though on the flip-side, the prices are on the high side.)
However, I was very impressed by some of the more unusual and interesting dishes.
In particular, the different Rice Bowl options are very good.
sunset.author: donal c.
sunset.review:
I have been here on a number of occasions (i.e. the bigger restaurant in the Sunset -- I have never been to the original hole-in-the-wall place in the Marina) and I remain unconvinced & on-the-fence about the place.

The location is in a well-trafficked area near a main entrance to Golden Gate Park and in the busy 9th & Irving area of the Sunset. It's a big, comfortable-looking restaurant with a large-ish bar area facing the Park. The menu has a large selection of seafood dishes (as the restaurant name would suggest) done in a variety of fusion-ish ways. Some of these are predictable, and in my experience, not that exciting. I have had the Fish & Chips and the Fish Tacos in the past, and I wasnt very impressed by either. (Big portions... though on the flip-side, the prices are on the high side.) However, I was very impressed by some of the more unusual and interesting dishes. In particular, the different Rice Bowl options are very good. I have become addicted to the  Hawaiian Poke Rice Bowl & Brown Rice. VERY tasty, and it feels healthy, with its variety of veggies and carbs (though it probably isnt!)

The place itself feels a bit impersonal - especially, the large restaurant area. It has the feel (just a bit...) of a suburban Red Lobster or TGI Friday's. (Not anything like as cheezy -- but there's a sense of it - not a good thing in an area where there are so many other places that do have personality & character.) The bar feels a bit better - tho the quality of the wait-staff & bartenders is hit-and-miss. 

So - definitely ambivalent about the place, and typically, the price-tab for a meal is a bit on the high side  - but Pacific Catch has its upsides. I remain hopeful, but unconvinced about it.

excerpts: Alas, the much-anticipated Pacific Catch has finally reached the Inner Sunset!
sunset.author: Jana H.
sunset.review:
Alas, the much-anticipated Pacific Catch has finally reached the Inner Sunset!  Though The Canvas served up delicious lemon bars and ambiance conducive for a late afternoon catch-up with a close friend, Pacific Catch seems to round off the 9th Ave area perfectly by joining the ranks of cheap eats like Park Chow, Hotei and Pluto's.

Desiring for a guilt-free meal at times, my husband and I used to trek to the Chestnut location to treat ourselves to their ahi-tuna or hawaiian poke salads.  Now, ask anyone close to me, and they will affirm that my palette is adamantly of the anti-salad mode, but Pacific Catch's hawaiian poke salad has converted me.  The salads are HUGE, comprised of a generous helping of rare hawaiian poke atop a bed of mixed greens garnished generously with slices of avocado, a handful of baby tomatoes, a healthy sprig of daikon sprouts, shredded carrots in a joyous, unassuming soy-wasabi vinaigrette.

If you're doubtful that the salad won't quench your appetite, order a side order of their sweet potato fries to push you just over the edge.  These crispy, subtly sweet fries score big on their own, but what knocks them out of the ballpark for me is the sweet chili dipping sauce.  For those who enjoy variety (as my hubby and I do!), they also have a wasabi-aioli dipping sauce too.

Just when we thought Pacific Catch couldn't impress us anymore, today we tried their fried dulce de leche 'spring rolls' for a sweet finish to our already yummy meal.  W-O-W!!  That's all I have to say.  It was a sweet perfection of texture and flavor that honestly, you won't comprehend unless you experience it yourself.  The warmth of the deep fried outside and the contrast with the vanilla ice cream that it's served with is an absolute wonder in the mouth.  And that's not even taking note of the dulce de leche and mascarpone in the middle of the deep fried bliss.  

Don't miss out on this place!  It offers a ton of variety so you're never bored and there's always something new to tempt your tastebuds.

excerpts: One of the nicer, bigger places to eat at in the Sunset
but if you're looking for a date place, I wouldn't go here.
It gets really loud!
That could be due to the number of families
w/ young kids dining there on Mother's Day though.
sunset.author: Miss H.
sunset.review:
Came here without a reservation for Mother's Day dinner. Only a 20 minute wait! Not bad.

Food:
-California Crab & Avocado salad: Pretty good. It tastes like it sounds -- a salad version of a california roll. I probably wouldn't eat the WHOLE thing as a meal though because it's too much of the same thing.
-Korean BBQ Steak: YUM I love beef! This was my choice, so I liked it. If you're looking for the real deal when it comes to Korean BBQ, then obviously it doesn't size up, but the beef was perfection.
-Alaskan 3-course meal w/ halibut skewers, salmon entree, and merengue & berries: They have a special 3-course meal highlighting the cuisine of places around the Pacific, so when I went, it was Alaska. I liked the skewers, especially the sauce. Even though it was battered & fried, it felt really light. The salmon was just ok -- nothing special. Didn't like the liquor-soaked ligonberries. The dessert was PERFECTION! Great balance of textures & flavors.
-Alaskan Stout: I hate dark beers, so of course, I wasn't too fond of this. My parents liked it though.

One of the nicer, bigger places to eat at in the Sunset but if you're looking for a date place, I wouldn't go here. It gets really loud! That could be due to the number of families w/ young kids dining there on Mother's Day though.

excerpts: This is now my current favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset.
sunset.author: Jared D.
sunset.review:
Oh, Pacific Catch, how did I go so long without you in my life? This is now my current favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset.  Despite being right under my nose, it took me something like 2 years before I tried this gem, and now I'm hooked.

The normal menu is brilliant.  I love how they have similar fish/flavor combinations available in different forms depending on if you are in the mood for a salad, a sandwich, or a 'bowl'. The "Wasabi Ahi" sandwich or salad are my usual faves.

The daily specials are really nice too.  Ask about the different "side styles" since they will let you change the "style" if you'd prefer something different.  Periodically, they have a special "regional" 3 course menu.  For example, currently it's Chilean-inspired for Restaurant Week, but I've tried the Vietnamese ones as well.

The service here is amazingly wonderful.  For awhile we kept getting the same waiter who remembered us after our first visit.  We thought it was just him, but as we got other servers we received similarly great service.

The space has a nice modern yet inviting decor.  The main dining room has lots of seating alongside the kitchen, so reservations aren't really needed.  If you make reservations (or if it's slow), you can get slightly nicer and roomier table/booth near the windows.  If they are busy or want a more casual vibe, you can usually grab a table in the bar area.  The bar area is also open later with a bar bites menu and late night happy hour everyday.

Only complainant is that when they opened they painted over the sweet street art that used to cover the entire wall alongside their parking lot! ;)

excerpts: Definitely my go to place in the sunset for happy hour and a quick bite.
Their ceviche is excellent!
Nice and spicy.
Wish they didn't serve it with the yam chips, adds a little too much grease
but that's a picky point.
Happy Hour deals are very good.
Less impressed with their kids meals as far as flavor goes
but my kid is a foodie, if your child likes bland mildly flavored foods, then you're good.
Their poke is very good and probably my favorite meal here.
sunset.author: Halima T.
sunset.review: Love this place. Definitely my go to place in the sunset for happy hour and a quick bite. Their ceviche is excellent!  Nice and spicy. Wish they didn't serve it with the yam chips, adds a little too much grease but that's a picky point.  Happy Hour deals are very good.  Less impressed with their kids meals as far as flavor goes but my kid is a foodie, if your child likes bland mildly flavored foods, then you're good.  Their poke is very good and probably my favorite meal here.

excerpts: All in all, a very nice place to get an early dinner when in the Inner Sunset.
sunset.author: Alured P.
sunset.review: Some of this may not apply once the crab specials are done, so your experience might differ.  Both the crab dumplings and the crab-corn chowder were amazing... so very delicious I could have made a meal out of them alone.  The Tokyo Salmon fish and chips were excellent.... they may have ruined regular fish and chips for me.  The Baja fish tacos were also very good.  Service was also very good and prices are very reasonable.  All in all, a very nice place to get an early dinner when in the Inner Sunset.

excerpts: , it's a nice place to go for something other than the usual inner sunset food.
sunset.author: Sharon O.
sunset.review:
my sister and i shared the hawaiian surf&turf and the fried oysters with sweet potato fries, and boy, were we stuffed! friendly servers, great ambiance, it's a nice place to go for something other than the usual inner sunset food. 

they have late night happy hour every night from 10pm till closing. i passed by on saturday night and the place was packed with people. gotta try their happy hour sometime...

the food was really flavorful and their menu is extensive, ranging from sushi to salads to seafood. 

a bit pricey, but what isn't in san francisco?

excerpts: Pacific Catch has been a great addition to the Inner Sunset neighborhood.
sunset.author: Michael W.
sunset.review: Pacific Catch has been a great addition to the Inner Sunset neighborhood.  The food here is consistently very good---favs are the Pacific Salmon (battered fried salmon and sweet potato fries) and the wasabi bowls (any combo).  Servers are efficient and friendly.  A unique  feature of this Pacific Catch is the size of the building (built on an old x-mas tree lot, d'ya remember?).  It's not often to find an SF restaurant that is not a bit cramped so this place is a treat.  Finally, the martinis are well priced and good sized (have you noticed maritini glasses seem to be shrinking in SF?).

excerpts: (With it's live music night, relatively good food and nice booths/tables to park yourself with your laptop, Canvas was one of my fav spots in the Sunset.
But I remiss...)
Anyway, so I'm headed to Pacific Catch because my SO is part of an acronym friends and family group (aka AF&F) and most of them are devout meat worshipers.
I mean they really, really like their meats and fish.
And don't suggest to me that fish is vegetarian.
Hello!
If it's got a face, moves and /or
you keep it as a pet, it's not vegetarian.
So Pacific Catch has an upscale look and feel to the place.
Nice decor, lighting and a friendly wait staff.
But the menu is not vegetarian friendly.
sunset.author: ITesh J.
sunset.review:
This is a new restaurant in what was Canvas Cafe. (With it's live music night, relatively good food and nice booths/tables to park yourself with your laptop, Canvas was one of my fav spots in the Sunset.  But I remiss...) Anyway, so I'm headed to Pacific Catch because my SO is part of an acronym friends and family group (aka AF&F) and most of them are devout meat worshipers.  I mean they really, really like their meats and fish.  And don't suggest to me that fish is vegetarian.  Hello!  If it's got a face, moves and /or you keep it as a pet, it's not vegetarian.  So Pacific Catch has an upscale look and feel to the place. Nice decor, lighting and a friendly wait staff.  But the menu is not vegetarian friendly.  Lot of choices (sake salmon, calamari, thai coconut shrimp, tuna tataki etc etc...) if you like your meats and fish but not if you're vegetarian.  Most places in SF by now have a section on their menu for vegetarians. Not here. (Btw, I asked the waiter and she didn't have a suggestion off the menu for me as well)  Frustrated, I asked for peanut butter & jelly sandwich and they didn't have that. So I ended up with some starters and sides: wakame seaweed salad (kindda fishy), pineapple fried rice (kindda bland) and sweet potato fries (ok...the fries were good especially with their special dips).  Not very satisfying for $25 (w/ tips) per person bill.

Tip for Pacfic Catch.  Have something vegetarian. Something noodly on your menu. And if you can't do that, at least have peanut butter and jelly sandwich.  Is that asking for too much?

excerpts: So when my friends from out of town came to visit, I took them to one of my favorite places to eat, the INNER SUNSET.
So when they closed one of my favorite coffee shops down
(Canvas)
I already wanted to hate the restaurant that was taking over that space.
Enter Pacific Catch.
My friends love seafood
so I reluctantly came in.
Had my usual soda pop, and friend oysters with rice......
Not Bad.
I was disapointedly impressed.
So with my inner issues resolved with Pacific Catch
I felt free to attack everyone else's food.
Poke, fish and chips, it was all good.
Best hidden secret of this place is that there is a parking lot.....
Luvs it!
sunset.author: Rossi C.
sunset.review: So when my friends from out of town came to visit, I took them to one of my favorite places to eat, the INNER SUNSET.  So when they closed one of my favorite coffee shops down (Canvas) I already wanted to hate the restaurant that was taking over that space.  Enter Pacific Catch.  My friends love seafood so I reluctantly came in.  Had my usual soda pop, and friend oysters with rice......Not Bad.  I was disapointedly impressed.  So with my inner issues resolved with Pacific Catch I felt free to attack everyone else's food.  Poke, fish and chips, it was all good.  Best hidden secret of this place is that there is a parking lot.....Luvs it!

excerpts: with the appetizer coupons we scored at the yelp party in hand, we headed over to the sunset pacific catch for some consistently delicious grub and, as usual, we weren't disappointed.
sunset.author: Andrey C.
sunset.review:
with the appetizer coupons we scored at the yelp party in hand, we headed over to the sunset pacific catch for some consistently delicious grub and, as usual, we weren't disappointed. we tried both the hawaiian poke (a must eat) and the baja shrimp ceviche, which came out in a cool martini glass with tortilla chips... so refreshing and good! i'm usually wary about getting salmon, but the salmon wasabi bowl here was perfect! and you can never go wrong with the rock cod fish and chips...

chef chandon and chef (eek! forgot your name!) even came out to greet us and shoot the breeze about the yelp party the night before... can't believe they actually DONATED all that food that, well, i didn't get to eat (cuz i'm not elite... pshh).

i had actually come to this location earlier this year, and enjoyed one of their lunch-time sandwiches... which were super good as well. only wish i lived closer... i'd probably eat here at least 1x a week if that were the case!

excerpts: This restaurant would be more at home in a Westfield mall than on 9th Ave. in the Sunset.
It's totally corporate, the food is boring, and the fish is not fresh.
Also, I think there was something wrong with their deep fryer, because the fish and chips were soggy.
Next time I want seafood, I'm going to Ebisu.
sunset.author: Ezra Y.
sunset.review: This restaurant would be more at home in a Westfield mall than on 9th Ave. in the Sunset.  It's totally corporate, the food is boring, and the fish is not fresh.  Also, I think there was something wrong with their deep fryer, because the fish and chips were soggy.  Next time I want seafood, I'm going to Ebisu.

excerpts: and I took a long walk around inner sunset and stopped by Pacific catch to have drinks.
A waiter was nice and quick but the drink, my boyfriend ordered, came out with 2 black long hair in it!!!!!!
It was so gross!!!!!
And the waiter took it back and brought a new drink
but he didn't even offer to take the gross-hair-in drink out of our bill.
We just paid and didn't leave tips.
We'll never go back there again.. even just thinking of the drink, still makes me throw up :( :(
sunset.author: Q S.
sunset.review: Sunday afternoon my boyfriend and I took a long walk around inner sunset and stopped by Pacific catch to have drinks. A waiter was nice and quick but the drink, my boyfriend ordered, came out with 2 black long hair in it!!!!!! It was so gross!!!!! And the waiter took it back and brought a new drink but he didn't even offer to take the gross-hair-in drink out of our bill. We just paid and didn't leave tips. We'll never go back there again.. even just thinking of the drink, still makes me throw up :( :(

excerpts: however, i finally found myself back in the inner sunset and in front of pacific catch
so i decided to go in, and was pleasantly surprised.
the menu is much more versatile than i would have expected.
a new country's cuisine is featured each month, and a 4 course set meal is available or you can purchase anything off the set menu a la carte.
i agree that the fried oysters are awesome.
sunset.author: Mary Beth D.
sunset.review:
i had been boycotting this place forever because i was so sad when the canvas gallery closed (remember the canvas gallery? that place rocked!) not to mention that i drive by pacific catch almost every day and the outside now looks like a super cheesy seafood chain. 

however, i finally found myself back in the inner sunset and in front of pacific catch so i decided to go in, and was pleasantly surprised. the menu is much more versatile than i would have expected. a new country's cuisine is featured each month, and a 4 course set meal is available or you can purchase anything off the set menu a la carte.  i agree that the fried oysters are awesome. the sushi rolls aren't the most inventive, but i hadn't expected sushi on the menu at all, so that was cool. 

and the drink menu is pretty frickin impressive. inventive drinks (i got a tequila cosmo, which i've never thought to make) lots of different kinds of beers are available, including a hawaiian beer in a can, and happy hour is from 4-6pm and 10pm to close. you can't beat a deal like that, i would totally go back.

excerpts: Rising sun -
rising sun.author: Angie Y.
rising sun.review:
First off, service was great! Hostess and waiter were both very nice, and the waiter checked up on us regularly. Unfortunately, I come back for food/drinks... good service is a bonus. 

Now onto happy hour... drinks and food. The Mai tai was great; it's not too strong but you can definitely taste the alcohol so you know they're not skimping on it. $7 for a glass or $34 for a pitcher with 5 servings ($1 saving). The food was overall subpar although portions were good--average $5.5-$6.50 / plate. 

Calamari - not crunchy; tasted almost stale (like it's been sitting out a while).
Salmon avocado poke - this was good. Fish tasted fresh. The chips that it came with was thin and crunchy, which I liked, but it tasted greasy. 
Inside out roll - the spicy tuna on the outside wasn't spicy and it was creamier than I liked, like it had too much mayo. 
Rising sun - the shrimp tempura wasn't crunchy on the inside, but I liked the fresh raw tuna on top.

In short, this wouldn't be my pick for happy hour but if my friends suggest it, I wouldn't fight them on it (if they've been here before and know what they're getting themselves into).

excerpts: For the main course, I ate the "Rising Sun" roll and my gf ate the "Let's Get Saucy Roll".
Not bad at all.
rising sun.author: Jeff C.
rising sun.review:
I couldn't decided between 3 and 4 stars, so I'll just go in between... 3.5 but round down to 3.  Now for me, a 3 star place is somewhere where I wasn't disappointed with, it just wouldn't be my VERY first choice in the area.  However, I did enjoy my visit to Pacific Catch for the most part.

I've heard so much about the sweet potato fries that I just had to try them.  And they didn't disappoint!  Great flavor and good texture (crispy outside, soft inside) with two dipping sauces.  Mmmm.  Definitely one of the better sweet potato fries I've eaten.  We also had the poke appetizer, that was a winner too!

For the main course, I ate the "Rising Sun" roll and my gf ate the "Let's Get Saucy Roll".  Not bad at all.  Our friends ordered the seared ahi bowl to share since they weren't very hungry.  It was a nice touch that they served it in two separate bowls for them.

The atmosphere and environment were really nice...  very clean and a pleasant place to eat.  But the issues that irked me was that it is a little bit pricey and the happy hour specials are only at the bar!  They wouldn't give us the specials at our table even though the place was around half full only.  Booooooo....

excerpts: Rising sun sushi!
rising sun.author: Marissa E.
rising sun.review:
Love it, usually just go for the bar foodies and drinks during happy hour.

Poki 
Sweet Potato Fries
Tangerine Beer
Rising sun sushi!

excerpts: We asked for brown rice for the rising sun and the firecracker salmon rolls.
I was not impressed by the rolls because the brown rice didn't stick too well and the rice fell apart.
