sticky ribs.review: Started with the coconut soup with shrimp. Wish the portion  was larger but more to come:) sticky ribs oh baby. Entrees were superb  my friend Christy got the poke salad and since she's Miss Hawaii  everything must be on par from there. She gave it thumbs up. I had the yellowtail dinner. Very fresh tasty. Pictured is the yummy saucy desert

excerpts: the breakdown of the 4 stars: 3 for the korean sticky ribs and 5 for the hawaiian poke half-half bowl for an average of 4. let's start with the bad...the "ribs" were tough, not melting off the bone like i had envisioned.
they looked and tasted more like pork chops than ribs.
the best part of the appetizer was the sweet sticky sauce.
not too salty with lots of flavor.
now to the gooooood...
and it's pretty damn good.
the hawaiian poke over half brown rice and half greens has become my go-to healthy meal now.
like a japanese style bibimbap, it's loaded with seaweed salad, pickled ginger, avocado slices, and big chunks of yummy poke.
are you salivating yet??
sticky ribs.author: Melissa Y.
sticky ribs.review: the breakdown of the 4 stars: 3 for the korean sticky ribs and 5 for the hawaiian poke half-half bowl for an average of 4. let's start with the bad...the "ribs" were tough, not melting off the bone like i had envisioned. they looked and tasted more like pork chops than ribs. the best part of the appetizer was the sweet sticky sauce. not too salty with lots of flavor. now to the gooooood...and it's pretty damn good. the hawaiian poke over half brown rice and half greens has become my go-to healthy meal now. like a japanese style bibimbap, it's loaded with seaweed salad, pickled ginger, avocado slices, and big chunks of yummy poke. are you salivating yet??

excerpts: Some were good tho, the sweet potato fries and the sticky ribs were great but the bowls didn't wow us.
sticky ribs.author: Kevin C.
sticky ribs.review: Had dinner here with two of my friends and my friend's two children under 4. Service was good and the menu had a great selection.  Why only 4 stars? Because the food was decent, not outstanding.  Some were good tho, the sweet potato fries and the sticky ribs were great but the bowls didn't wow us. We also had California rolls for the kids but that tasted like a pre packed sushi box  from a supermarket. other than that we would definitely go there again

excerpts: Along with expanding the choices for their long time staples (rice bowls, fried seafood, fish-centric entrees, sushi rolls, etc.), they also keep a rotation of daily chalkboard specials and added a "raw bar" menu, which features varieties of ceviche, poke, taktaki, platters/towers, and more.

From their appetizers and fish tacos to their fish & chips and daily chalkboard specials, the food at Pacific Catch is generally pretty fresh...except for all of their fried stuff, like their Mixed Catch plate that my buddy likes).
chalkboard specials.author: Mike L.
chalkboard specials.review:
I don't intend for this to sound like a slight, but I always seem to forget about Pacific Catch.  Whether it's because they've been around for so long or because I've b een here so many times, it's gotten to the point now where they just kind of fade into the background for me.  Which might explain why, despite all of those trips here, I've still never written a review for these guys!  Although, I could've sworn I wrote something about them at some point over the years...

While the place is starting to show a bit of its age (though they did convert part of their entry way into an outdoor seating area with a fire pit), Pacific Catch hasn't let its menu get outdated.  Along with expanding the choices for their long time staples (rice bowls, fried seafood, fish-centric entrees, sushi rolls, etc.), they also keep a rotation of daily chalkboard specials and added a "raw bar" menu, which features varieties of ceviche, poke, taktaki, platters/towers, and more.

Given how many times I've been here, I've been able to try a number of things on their menu, so I'd like to think I have a pretty good sense of them overall.  From their appetizers and fish tacos to their fish & chips and daily chalkboard specials, the food at Pacific Catch is generally pretty fresh...except for all of their fried stuff, like their Mixed Catch plate that my buddy likes).  However, whether it's been when I've dined in or when I used to get takeout, I usually end up getting the same thing every time - their JAPANESE WASABI BOWL with Poke ($16.50).

Filled with Seaweed Salad, Avocado, Daikon Salad, Ginger, Sesame Seeds, Shredded Nori, and Soy-Wasabi Sauce, this isn't bad, but lacking compared to what you can get from poke joints.  While their poke (tuna) is generally pretty fresh, everything else is hit or miss.  The seaweed salad and avocado are good, but I'm not a fan of their daikon salad and the sauce is just okay (I personally prefer ponzu-based ones).  What's more, the rice can be a little inconsistent (can be overcooked).

Despite how their food may not strike me like how it used to, I certainly appreciate how steady and consistent Pacific Catch has been.  From my first trip here, to the time we sat at their bar and watched the Giants clinch the 2014 World Series, to this most recent trip, the food hasn't changed much, for better or worse.  Still, it's nice that whenever I do come back, they're (probably) going to be as reliable as ever!

excerpts: For starters, we tried one of their chalkboard specials.
It's a Poke, forgot exactly what's called, but it's calamari poke.
It was so good!
Then I ordered their Island Tacos, for some reason, I went with their 3-taco platter just like what my friend got.
It's pretty awesome that you can mix and match
chalkboard specials.author: Czarina Y.
chalkboard specials.review:
My friends and I decide that every time we decide to eat out, we need to try a new place. My friend suggested this place, we gave it a shot.

For starters, we tried one of their chalkboard specials. It's a Poke, forgot exactly what's called, but it's calamari poke. It was so good! Then I ordered their Island Tacos, for some reason, I went with their 3-taco platter just like what my friend got. It's pretty awesome that you can mix and match so we tried the Traditional Baja, Mahi Mahi and Cabo Shrimp. My friend finished the entire plate plus his side salad. I didn't =( but I ate all the shrimp and fish just not the tortilla. It was good though, next time I will remind myself that I don't have a huge appetite like my friends do and order 2 tacos maybe :P
My other friend who happens to be my boyfriend got the Pan-Asian Rice Bowl. He got the Japanese Wasabi bowl with Grilled Salmon. I personally didn't taste it, but he said it was too rich, although the salmon was still pretty good. 

Server was friendly and attends very well to our needs. Great experience! Can't complain and I will definitely go back. =)

excerpts: For the entree, I had one of the "chalkboard specials," which was a simple grilled opah served with a halved artichoke, brown rice, and a chunky tomato and lemon sauce.
It was very flavorful, and I had enough for lunch the next day.
chalkboard specials.author: brewgirl b.
chalkboard specials.review:
I really liked Canvass, but this seafood place is a surprisingly tasty replacement.  Great cocktails.  I had a wonderful pisco sour, with the egg whites so, so mild.  My friend had the yuzo drop, with Hangar One vodka, the Japanes citrus fruit and a sugared rim--mmmmm.  

Food portions are huge, so expect to take something home at the end of meal.  Loved the crispy oysters appetizer--very crisp and batter-fried with tender oyster meat on the inside.  The firecracker salmon roll, filed with  tempura salmon, chili sauce, avocado, cucumber, daikon sprouts and crispy shallots, was another winner.  There are eight pieces, so definitely a plate to split.  For the entree, I had one of the "chalkboard specials," which was a simple grilled opah served with a halved artichoke, brown rice, and a chunky tomato and lemon sauce.  It was very flavorful, and I had enough for lunch the next day.  Really liked the cold edamame and fish-shapped crackers they serve instead of boring, table bread and butter.  

No room for dessert, so I dont know how good they are.  Wouldnt mind coming back to find out.

excerpts: As entrees, we ordered fish from their chalkboard specials.
I think what makes it cool was that they give you some side dishes as well which sort of fill you up.
At other places like Aqua, you get just a piece of fish for like $30.
The fish was pretty good.
My friend ordered the scallops which was big and juicy as well.
We'll certainly come back again.
chalkboard specials.author: Amy V.
chalkboard specials.review: I ate here the first time last Friday.  I usually go to Park Chow but saw this relatively new restaurant so decided to check it out with my friend.  I was pleasantly surprised.  First, it's kind of a Hawaiian fusion restaurant.  There are not a lot of these restaurants in the city so it's kind of unique for me. The only other place I can remember is Roy's downtown.  Anyhow, we ordered the Hawaiian Poke as appetizer.  You actually get a decent size dish for $8.50 -- big chunks of raw tuna, probably a little TOO big.  As entrees, we ordered fish from their chalkboard specials.  I think what makes it cool was that they give you some side dishes as well which sort of fill you up.  At other places like Aqua, you get just a piece of fish for like $30.  The fish was pretty good.  My friend ordered the scallops which was big and juicy as well.  We'll certainly come back again.

excerpts: So I ended up with some starters and sides: wakame seaweed salad (kindda fishy), pineapple fried rice (kindda bland) and sweet potato fries (ok...
the fries were good especially with their special dips).
wakame seaweed salad.author: ITesh J.
wakame seaweed salad.review:
This is a new restaurant in what was Canvas Cafe. (With it's live music night, relatively good food and nice booths/tables to park yourself with your laptop, Canvas was one of my fav spots in the Sunset.  But I remiss...) Anyway, so I'm headed to Pacific Catch because my SO is part of an acronym friends and family group (aka AF&F) and most of them are devout meat worshipers.  I mean they really, really like their meats and fish.  And don't suggest to me that fish is vegetarian.  Hello!  If it's got a face, moves and /or you keep it as a pet, it's not vegetarian.  So Pacific Catch has an upscale look and feel to the place. Nice decor, lighting and a friendly wait staff.  But the menu is not vegetarian friendly.  Lot of choices (sake salmon, calamari, thai coconut shrimp, tuna tataki etc etc...) if you like your meats and fish but not if you're vegetarian.  Most places in SF by now have a section on their menu for vegetarians. Not here. (Btw, I asked the waiter and she didn't have a suggestion off the menu for me as well)  Frustrated, I asked for peanut butter & jelly sandwich and they didn't have that. So I ended up with some starters and sides: wakame seaweed salad (kindda fishy), pineapple fried rice (kindda bland) and sweet potato fries (ok...the fries were good especially with their special dips).  Not very satisfying for $25 (w/ tips) per person bill.

Tip for Pacfic Catch.  Have something vegetarian. Something noodly on your menu. And if you can't do that, at least have peanut butter and jelly sandwich.  Is that asking for too much?

excerpts: The two tacos could have been a meal on their own, but were served with a side of fries (or salad) and a small bowl of black beans.
side of fries.author: Sherry L.
side of fries.review:
This is a good option for a meal in the sunset area if you are looking for something more commercial. It was bustling on a game night, mostly in the bar area, but we didn't have any issues getting a large table for a party of two. 

We ordered two rice bowls and a two taco platter - way too much food in hindsight, but we enjoyed having all of the options. I found my Japanese wasabi bowl with salmon (grilled, btw) and 1/2 brown rice 1/2 greens to be very filling and I liked all of the toppings it included. The ingredients were fresh and they don't skimp on anything! The name is a bit of a misnomer though, as there was no wasabi that I could taste or see in my bowl. My mom's WestCoast grilled salmon bowl looked equally delicious but with an assortment of other toppings. 

The tacos were quite hefty in serving size as well. The two tacos could have been a meal on their own, but were served with a side of fries (or salad) and a small bowl of black beans. The Traditional Baja taco and the Grilled Steak taco were both excellent choices, depending on your palate and dietary preferences!

excerpts: That came with a side of fries
I felt like take out orders should have more fires although not all food places are the same .
And a small sample of coleslaw I wish I had more of that now
that was so good
and it was fresh
side of fries.author: Kentara W.
side of fries.review: Food was excellent I had the steak  sandwich  which was good. They had some type of aioli sauce which was spicy  however it makes you want to continue eating it. That came with a side of fries  I felt like take out orders should have more fires although not all food places are the same . And a small sample of coleslaw I wish I had more of that now that was so good and it was fresh

excerpts: I ordered the coconut shrimp, it was crispy and hot but the serving was a little small and the side of fries were flavorful but a bit undercooked.
side of fries.author: Garret W.
side of fries.review: Pacific Catch was recommended to me by someone that lives in SF. I ordered the coconut shrimp, it was crispy and hot but the serving was a little small and the side of fries were flavorful but a bit undercooked. My friends ordered the green curry and the salmon salad. They seemed very satisfied as their servings were very large. The service was a bit slow but other than that it was a great place with  lots of customers!

excerpts: We each ordered them with a side of fries--spicy and sweet potato.
Everything was pretty much devoured really quickly, even my boys cleaned up their plates which is really rare.
Either they were just hungry or they loved it, turns out to both.
The only flip-side to it was that there was some damage done to our wallets.
Total cost for a family of four came out to almost $80 including tax.
We always try to eat where we can afford within our means, but today, I guess you can say it was a special treat:)
Otherwise, be prepared to dish out some money for good seafood or save this place for special occasions.
side of fries.author: Dahlia C.
side of fries.review:
After a long hike at Land's End with my family, we were starving. It was a beautiful Sunday afternoon and the nearest place where there are notably tons of great eclectic spots to eat, was in the inner sunset district along Irving and 9th. Right on the corner of 9th and Lincoln is Pacific Catch, you cannot miss it. Parking can be a little difficult to find especially on weekends, but it was just our luck that we found a spot right in front. They say the law of attraction can make things happen & that's exactly what happened as my hubby and I were claiming a close spot beforehand. And on top of that, the meters said free parking, which is normally in service on Sundays. Made us feel like we won the lottery!!

Anyways, we were seated right away since it was mid-afternoon and not so crowded. The boys had kids meals: fish and chips and fish tacos. The mister and I shared the white tuna Poke, served with fried wontons. Then we both ordered mix & match tacos. I chose mahi mahi, shrimp, and steak. Hubby chose baja (fried cod), mahi mahi, and steak as well. We each ordered them with a side of fries--spicy and sweet potato. Everything was pretty much devoured really quickly, even my boys cleaned up their plates which is really rare. Either they were just hungry or they loved it, turns out to both.The only flip-side to it was that there was some damage done to our wallets. Total cost for a family of four came out to almost $80 including tax. We always try to eat where we can afford within our means, but today, I guess you can say it was a special treat:) Otherwise, be prepared to dish out some money for good seafood or save this place for special occasions.

excerpts: This dish came with a side of coleslaw (that wasn't really good) and a side of fries ( I picked the sweet potato fries).
The sweet potato fries was good until it got cold and soggy, I recommend you eating it as soon as you get them!
As for the sandwich, I was disappointed with it.
side of fries.author: Erica T.
side of fries.review:
My friend and I decided to come here for dinner on a Friday night. We decided to sit near the bar area because we would have to wait 15 mins for the next dining table. No biggie for us, I don't mind where I sit.

What I ordered:

Fruit punch (alcoholic cocktail) $9.50: Vodka with various types of fruit juices. This drink was STRONG! My face was red and I was pretty buzzed. I guess if I can feel the alcohol from one drink, it is worth the $9.50 you pay for it because you actually get alcohol in it, none of that watered down drinks at other places.

Thai Coconut Shrimp $13:  7 pieces of jumbo shrimp with coconut shaving batter, deep fried and with the sweet chili sauce.... mMMmm nom nom nom. My friend ordered this appetizer and I was a little hesitant. A lot of restaurants end up giving you small shrimp with crappy battered textured. This was pretty good, you can taste the actual coconut shavings, the batter was light and crispy and the shrimp was bigger than I thought it would be. I was happy with this dish.

California Salmon $12:  This is where I wasn't too happy. This dish came with a side of coleslaw (that wasn't really good) and a side of fries ( I picked the sweet potato fries). The sweet potato fries was good until it got cold and soggy, I recommend you eating it as soon as you get them! As for the sandwich, I was disappointed with it. You get a slice of salmon that you can't even see at all, but can taste it. I swear the slice of the salmon was the thickness of 10 sheets of paper... not the filet that you would expect from a salmon sandwich. The bread was not toasted and so it was cold and not warm and crispy. I think texture is key when making a sandwich, you get the lettuce, tomato, avocado and salmon (all of which have a moist texture -- except the lettuce) and you want the bread to add a different texture... this is just me, I like my bread warm and crispy. As for flavor, it had enough flavor and it was actually tasty, just sad that the main attraction in this sandwich was nowhere to be seen.

Service was great! The lady came by quite often to make sure our water will filled and to make sure we were ok. Overall, the food was ok and the service was great.  I would give 3.5 stars if Yelp let me....

excerpts: We were tempted to also start off with some sweet potato fries, but since many of the dinner meals come with a side of fries, we decided not to.
side of fries.author: Allan L.
side of fries.review:
Pacific Catch sounds like a corny show from the 90s but in reality, it's a mighty fine restaurant. I enjoyed my Pacific Catch experience. We came here on a Saturday night and had a reservation, so they seated us immediately. We got lucky and found a spot in their free parking lot, but parking is incredibly difficult in this area, so give yourself enough time to find a spot.

We started off with the fried calamari. It was a healthy portion, and had a small kick to it. We were tempted to also start off with some sweet potato fries, but since many of the dinner meals come with a side of fries, we decided not to. I ordered the 3 taco plate (mahi mahi, shrimp, and traditional baja) and enjoyed the shrimp taco the best. One of the tacos, I think the traditional baja, lacked flavor and was disappointing. For $15, I was stuffed at the end of the meal and had no room for dessert. The service was excellent and the staff was attentive. I'd come here again.

My tummy gives Pacific Catch...4 Stars!

excerpts: We were so full that we couldn't  even  finish our side of warm edamame.
warm edamame.author: Michelle R.
warm edamame.review:
A very solid place, with good food and great presentation.

It is an all-occasion spot, you can come for a casual Sunday dinner or to celebrate a birthday.  You can see  all ages and all kind of groups of people, from families with babies to ones with  older parents and everyone in between.  Groups of friends, ages from  20 something to seniors.

We really loved the sweet potato fries for an appetizer.  They came with red chili pepper sauce (yumm) and wasabi aioli.

My mahi mahi tacos were really good. They came with avocado and lettuce, a small bowl of beans on the side, and you could have an option of fries or salad with it.  There were 2 tacos on a plate.  I don't like huge portions, so this was plenty.

 My husband had a bowl of grilled mahi mahi with brown rice, roasted pineapple, caramelized onions and shaved coconut.   He really enjoyed it and could barely finish his plate, it was so much food.

We were so full that we couldn't  even  finish our side of warm edamame.

My son had fish and chips.  I tried his fries, the seasoning on them was a really good combination.

Some food, like sweet potato fries, tacos were served on a sheet of a newspaper which happened to be a Hawaiian Tribune from April 1, 1901.  Pretty cool, although I've seen it before (at an Italian Seafood place, on Irving and 9th, not far from this one.)

Cons:  The California roll that my daughter ordered was a bit dry. It also was overpriced at $9.  The wine was overpriced too, at $9 a glass, and it wasn't that much wine in the glass.  Also, they were out of one of Hawaiian Poke tonight - spiced tofu.

Nevertheless, we enjoyed our dinner and definitely will be back.

excerpts: +Warm Edamame $4
warm edamame.author: Julia D.
warm edamame.review:
Yayyyy the only kitchen that is open in the Sunset on Fridays and Saturdays! 12pm woohooo!!!

After Izakaya Sozai completely SCREWED our reservation, we were frustrated AND hungry. Not a good combo. 

So for walkin in around 11:30pm on a friday, they have some pretty good deals on their "Bar Bites" happy hour until midnight...not too shabby.

+Agave Margarita $6
+Warm Edamame $4
++++Peruvian Ceviche
-Thai Coconut Shrimp (they were just okay)
- - Cabo Calamari (soggy, stringy, not impressive)

+Hawaiian Poke - $9.5 Worth it!

Conclusion: If I ever get screwed like that again, and really hungry late at night after a ravenous night of drinkin' it's alright to make an exception.

excerpts:
- Warm Edamame (sea salt is umm good!)
- House-made Miso Soup (dunno who'se "house" it was made in but they make it darn good)
warm edamame.author: Amit S.
warm edamame.review:
ACK! That's Marlin, Nemo and Dory you're serving on my plate, you freak!

... just kidding! 

This place is actually not that bad at all. Even months after they reopened, I could not make myself go in for the simple fact that I was an avid fan of the Canvas Gallery that occupied the space before, and to see it close was truly sad... I am in mourning...

... OK. Sob story over... back to me now...

... checked it out on a nice and sunny Sunday (those rare ones in the Inner Sunset when you can wear shorts, a tank and flip flops) and had a great time.

I recommend:
- Warm Edamame (sea salt is umm good!)
- House-made Miso Soup (dunno who'se "house" it was made in but they make it darn good)
- Hawaiian Poke (my FAV dish here! the tuna on the wonton crisp is just something else... this Hawaiian can poke me any ole time!)
- Cabo Calamari (What? Messican Calamari?? Odd name but all the same pretty good thought a wee bit greasy with the deep frying)
- Fish & Chips (Can't go wrong with this one... actually, you can! good but not as good as Woodhouse Fish Company)
- Teriyaki Bowl ((nice especially with bok choy, sprouts and nori!)
- Macadamia Nut Brownie (DROOL! DRIP!... nuf said!)
- Bloody Mary (Sunday and Bloody Mary's?? Ya betcha!)

Nice place, crowd (tourists, neighbors, folks from other hoods), kid friendly, dog friendly (outside), waiter service outdoors can be a bit iffy until you throw in some 'tude.

excerpts:
Spicy Cabo Calamari - crispy chili & lemon with spicy chipotle sauce
Warm Edamame - Hawaiian Alaea sea salt
Basket of Fries - "signature" sweet potato, traditional or spicy 

and yup
warm edamame.author: Kapo T.
warm edamame.review:
i m not a big asian fusion fan probably because i think asian food is traditional enough and shouldn't be made any different. i've been here 3 times and the food is OK. nothing great. the location is great if you need a snack from walking the GGP or the museums. (but there are other food to eat around there also).  

the only thing that i recommend is the happy hour here. on a nice sunny day, the bar and outside seating is packed.  happy hour is from 4p-6p so get your orders in before 6p.  

here's their HH menu: 
Hawaiian Poke - sushi-grade ahi tuna in a sesame-soy marinade & spicy seasonings with wonton crisps
Asparagus & Shiitake - asparagus tempura & shiitake mushrooms with miso dressing
Spicy Tuna - ahi tuna with sriracha mayo
Thai Coconut Shrimp - Thai sweet-chili sauce
Spicy Cabo Calamari - crispy chili & lemon with spicy chipotle sauce
Warm Edamame - Hawaiian Alaea sea salt
Basket of Fries - "signature" sweet potato, traditional or spicy 

and yup, we ordered 3 of everything on the HH menu to beat the time! get their sweet potato fries, i like that one the best

excerpts: Our Warm Edamame were covered in what looked to be Hawaiian salt, WAY too much of it, even for my salt-loving son, and even the Thai Iced Tea was just not right.

I think if people haven't enjoyed much good quality Pacific Rim cuisine they could enjoy the Coconut Shrimp and other selections, and the portions are fairly large (remember that word "crude" in the last paragraph?).
Probably a better idea is to come here for a couple of beers during Happy Hour and call it a day.
warm edamame.author: Kimberly V.
warm edamame.review:
Strictly gringo.
Good friends, good company, but not for good people who know good food.
It's a great location, so I can't imagine it can fail, especially with the "Happy Hour" 1/2-offs on some of their appetizers, and I would eat here again, possibly, if I were at the De Young or CAS and in a hurry, but it is palatable and little more.
We had Ahi Poke, which I always love for its memories of Kauai, but it was sloppily cut, with quite a bit of stringy "tuna floss" to chew through.  That appeared again in the Spicy Tuna Rolls.  Both the latter and the Rock n Roll were crude creations I could easily have made better at home.  Our Warm Edamame were covered in what looked to be Hawaiian salt, WAY too much of it, even for my salt-loving son, and even the Thai Iced Tea was just not right.
I think if people haven't enjoyed much good quality Pacific Rim cuisine they could enjoy the Coconut Shrimp and other selections, and the portions are fairly large (remember that word "crude" in the last paragraph?).  Probably a better idea is to come here for a couple of beers during Happy Hour and call it a day.

excerpts: Mochi Fondue 5/5
mochi fondue.author: Yu S.
mochi fondue.review:
Came here for SF restaurant week. Food here is delicious!

We had 2-course lunch. They offer two options, and we tries both.

First one had:
Grilled Kanpachi Yellowtail 5/5
Forbidden Black Mango Sticky Rice 3/5 

Second one had:
Kanpachi Tataki 5/5
Kanpachi Citrus Poke tacos 5/5
Mochi Fondue 5/5

excerpts: $7 Mochi Fondue - vanilla, chocolate, coffee mochi balls & chocolate dipping sauce

:
I've tried this out of curiosity, but if you've ever had store-bought mochi ice cream balls, I'd say skip it.
mochi fondue.author: Joy W.
mochi fondue.review:
I've been here several times over the past few years and I've come to the conclusion that it's never a bad time to have some tasty ahi, as long as it tastes fresh. The menu features mainly California seafood dishes with some Asian fusion touches here and there. This corner venue is large and spacious with very high ceilings, but they keep the place pretty cold. There is also some cozy outdoor seating under some heaters, but keep in mind, it is right next to the bus stop. 

They start you off with some complimentary shelled edamame and pretzel goldfish, which is a cute nod to the seafood menu, but I'd still prefer bread. I also think edamame is more enjoyable with the shell on.

$16.50 Japanese Wasabi rice bowl w/ Hawaiian poke - seaweed salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds, shredded nori, soy-wasabi sauce:
The bowl has a decent portion of bite-size chunks of sweet, juicy tuna. The soy-wasabi sauce is mild and not too strong on the wasabi. It is also seasoned with green onions, chives, and sesame seeds. Everything tastes fresh including the pale slivers of creamy avocado and crunchy, crisp seaweed salad. Be sure to get a little bit of everything in each bite, otherwise you're left with a lots of rice at the bottom of the bowl. 

$15.50 Ahi Tuna Salad w/ seared ahi, greens & romaine, avocado, cucumber, daikon sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds, soy-wasabi vinaigrette:
When I want something lighter, I'll go for the salad. The ingredients are pretty much the same, but with lettuce instead of rice. But with a salad, I go for the seared tuna instead of poke, because it creates the illusion of a meatier salad. Again, try to eat a little of everything together, otherwise you're left with a ton of greens, or as my friend calls it, 'rabbit food.'

A lot of people like the sweet potato fries. They're alright, but sweet potato fries are becoming a ubiquitous offering across the board.

Happy hour deals are pretty good if you are in the area in the afternoons. Poke is about $8.

$9 Baja Shrimp Ceviche - lime, serrano chili, avocado, cilantro, tortilla chips:
These bite-size shrimp are springy, meaty and seasoned well. The verde sauce is on the runny side and is quite spicy. I could eat this on its own without tortilla chips too, but the thin, crunchy chips make a nice vehicle.

$12.50 Hawaiian Poke with wonton chips - original ahi tuna, sesame-soy marinade, spicy seasonings:
A small bowl of juicy ahi cubes covered in sesame seeds and micro greens are accompanied with some fried wontons.

$7 Mochi Fondue - vanilla, chocolate, coffee mochi balls & chocolate dipping sauce:
I've tried this out of curiosity, but if you've ever had store-bought mochi ice cream balls, I'd say skip it. The taste is pretty similar with the addition of a little bowl of chocolate sauce on the side for dipping.

The tasty rice bowls are still my go-to items to order here. If I were in the area, I'd come back to try some of the other menu items too.

excerpts: but we still had room for some Mochi Fondue!!
mochi fondue.author: Katerina Y.
mochi fondue.review:
I drive by this place every, single day. so it eventually made it on to my "must try" list.

 I finally went in yesterday and I honestly regret waiting so long. Everything my friend and I ordered was so delicious and not to mention our waitress was so attentive and delightful!

We ordered a Blood Orange Cocktail and a Kiwi Flash. If it wasn't a Monday night, we honestly wouldn't have stopped at just one each!lol

We started off with a Fire Cracker Salmon roll, which was delicious! 

My friend ordered the Mahi Mahi Hawaiin teriyaki bowl which looked, smelled, and tasted oh so good!

I ordered the 3 taco platter. One Mahi Mahi, one Cabo Shrimp, and lastly a Pacific steak taco. Yes, yes, and YES!! 

The portions were huge so we were full almost immediately but we still had room for some Mochi Fondue!! 

Overall, great location, delicious food, heated outdoor seating, can't go wrong!

excerpts: If you check-in for the first time at this restaurant on Foursquare, you get a free dessert, so I ordered the mochi fondue, which we liked.
It comes with chocolate dipping sauce.
This is a fun restaurant with an interesting menu.
The dishes you can get at other restaurants.
Most of it isn't that new to the eye or mouth, but overall it's a nice dining experience, and you will probably and hopefully leave satisfied.
mochi fondue.author: Denise C.
mochi fondue.review: This Pacific Catch caught my eye, and I finally got to eat here today for the first time with my uncle and his wife. They treated me to a dinner here. I picked something from the menu ahead of time and it was the shrimp tacos. I thought they were good. The others got dishes from the special menu, which were ribs and mahi mahi. Pacific Catch has big dishes with large portions. The dishes look hearty. I like the interior of the restaurant. If you check-in for the first time at this restaurant on Foursquare, you get a free dessert, so I ordered the mochi fondue, which we liked. It comes with chocolate dipping sauce. This is a fun restaurant with an interesting menu. The dishes you can get at other restaurants. Most of it isn't that new to the eye or mouth, but overall it's a nice dining experience, and you will probably and hopefully leave satisfied.

excerpts: Mochi Fondue:
Nothing special.
Just 3 mochi balls cut in half and a little bowl of tasty melty chocolate to dip it in.
There was way too much chocolate in the bowl though and I felt bad for wasting it.
mochi fondue.author: Tiffany V.
mochi fondue.review:
I think the text my best friend sent me yesterday morning sums up my feelings about Pacific Catch, "wtf wtfff why are you always at pacific catch crazy woman" Haha. 

I didn't even realize how much I loved this place until I kept finding myself there. It wasn't even until the third time did I realize they had a parking lot next to the restaurant! How handy! Such a rare find in San Francisco. 

Fish & Chips: Everyone loves these but I don't think its their best thing there. You should definitely get 4 pieces though since its $14 and 2 pieces is already $10. The pieces of fish aren't that big. I love the sauces it comes with but the Jalapeno Tartar sauce was never spicy to me. I think the coleslaw side is far too small as well but I love their sweet potato fries (the only reason I wanted to come in the first place haha)

California Roll Salad: I love this salad! Although I had it at every meal and I got kind of sick of it at the end. The salad is huge and you'll probably have a hard time finishing it. It comes with a ton of avocado and a even bigger mound of real crab. It really does taste like a california roll! I think its around $13. 

Hawaiian Poke Brown Rice Bowl: I never would've thought of ordering this if it wasn't for Yelp! I'm eating it right now as I type. I had a ton leftover because it wasn't the best thing to eat yesterday morning hungover! By far my favorite thing from Pacific Catch. You can also get it with white rice or 1/2 rice & 1/2 greens. 

Mochi Fondue: Nothing special. Just 3 mochi balls cut in half and a little bowl of tasty melty chocolate to dip it in. There was way too much chocolate in the bowl though and I felt bad for wasting it. I don't think its worth the money since it isn't very creative and you could just make the same thing yourself for far less. 

There is never a wait when I go. My friend and I were about to get dinner at the Presidio location until we drove by it noticed how tiny and packed it was. We just drove all the way to the 9th street location. This location is huge. Service has always been nice as well. I probably wouldn't go on a first date here though as it is a little bit commercial and there are tons of better first date restaurants in the area.

excerpts: Oh i guess he made the executive decision for us to not get some of that mochi fondue because he never asked if we wanted dessert or anything else.
mochi fondue.author: Carmen A.
mochi fondue.review: Mehh not impressed. The service was awful, and i can see why this location's ratings are lower than the one in the marina. We sat down and it took about 15 minutes before our server came by- who just dropped off some edamame beans and didnt even ask if we wanted a drink to start with. Another 15 minutes passed by...no water no server. He finally came back and asked if we were ready to order. After reading the raving reviews about the salmon poke, i decided to order that with half rice and half salad. "That doesnt come with rice or salad. You have to get the rice bowl." His whole demeanour was just unpleasant and why didnt he ask me if i had any questions about the menu? 20 minutes later he brings the food out and finally the water. Wow if i wanted this kind of service, i wouldve went to eat a chinese hole in the wall restaurant. Or maybe i should have just ordered take out. He never even came by to ask how we were doing or how the food was tasting. The last time we saw him was when he dropped off the check. Oh i guess he made the executive decision for us to not get some of that mochi fondue because he never asked if we wanted dessert or anything else.

excerpts: End a date or outing with mochi fondue and you're good to go.
mochi fondue.author: Colleen M.
mochi fondue.review:
I'm a dedicated advocate of Pacific Catch, as they seem to serve some of the freshest seafood in San Francisco. 

Their Asian fusion food is pretty well executed; the poke wasabi bowl is one of my favorites! Try the mahi mahi tacos - so good. The sake sake roll is better with brown rice, and comes in eight large pieces. End a date or outing with mochi fondue and you're good to go. 

Service has been quick and courteous every time I've been there but it is true that the tables could use a little more cleaning. I don't care though, I'm definitely coming back!

excerpts: Mochi Fondue - A must get!!
mochi fondue.author: Heidi C.
mochi fondue.review:
This review is for both the Marina district and 9th Ave locations.

9TH AVE -- accommodating for a huge party (takes reservations)
MARINA -- the whole restaurant seats maybe 20 at a time. VERY SMALL (does NOT take reservations)
Btw, parking at both locations suck but the 9th Ave location has a small parking lot in back which maybe parks about 8 cars at most.

Thai Iced Tea - YUM
Hawaiian Poke - YUM (chunks are a bit too big though...)
Hawaiian Poke Roll - Was okay
Ceivche - Too limey, not enough chips
Sweet Potato Fries - YUMMM
Catch of the Day - YUM
Teriyaki bowls - TOO SWEET, sickkk
Any Tacos - Mediocre (go to Nick's Crispy Tacos instead)
Mochi Fondue - A must get!!

And that is about all the food I've tried between the two locations. The place is cute, service is good and you just have to come and try this restaurant at least once in your life.

(Photos uploaded)

excerpts: Portions are filling and BFF's hubby tried the Mochi Fondue.
It was mochi balls filled with ice cream (you can buy these at Safeway nowadays), cut into quarters and served with a ramekin of hot chocolate dipping sauce.
It was OK, $5.95.
The other odd thing the waiter did was he gave BFF & her hubby their iced teas and an additional glass of ice for "refills".
In the end, the ice all melted into water and he had to go get them a fresh glass of iced tea with fresh ice.
Go figure.
mochi fondue.author: Ry T.
mochi fondue.review:
For the 2nd time, our friends tried to take us to a restaurant in the neighborhood  and it was closed.  So, we ended up by chance at Pacific Catch.  Our waiter was horribly slow.  It took him forever to take our orders.  We were all speculating that he was a laid off from a previous job as he didn't seem to have a handle on things.  Hubby even witnessed a younger waitress go up and punch in her orders while our waiter was still prodding along with his order on the computer.

The signature miso is to be avoided, $2.95.  We liked the Cabo Calamari which was fried and spicy, $8.95.  My fried oyster basket, $13.95 was too oily and the oysters were not firm.  Hubby and BFF's hubby had the Ahi 3 ways, $17.95, which they both liked.  Portions are filling and BFF's hubby tried the Mochi Fondue.  It was mochi balls filled with ice cream (you can buy these at Safeway nowadays), cut into quarters and served with a ramekin of hot chocolate dipping sauce.  It was OK, $5.95.  The other odd thing the waiter did was he gave BFF & her hubby their iced teas and an additional glass of ice for "refills".  In the end, the ice all melted into water and he had to go get them a fresh glass of iced tea with fresh ice.  Go figure.

excerpts: This time around, it was the passion fruit cheese cake, and next time I'm sure the mochi fondue will be how we finish.
mochi fondue.author: Nish N.
mochi fondue.review:
As with many folks, I was sad to see Canvas Gallery go. When I found out that Pacific Catch was replacing it, I was a little worried about how it would work in the neighborhood. I'm a fan of the Chestnut Street location but that space is much smaller and seems to fit right into its Marina trappings.

So this past Sunday, we went to this new location around 6pm for an early dinner. The place was pretty busy already and we had to wait about 10 minutes for a table (in the sizable bar area). Maybe it was the time of day, but everywhere we turned was some sort of family, be it a clan of six or new parents with their stroller and youngin' in tow, like us.

Our hostess and waitress were both really friendly and attentive. The menu is a mix of Asian and Seafood, so you'll find sushi mixed in with fish tacos and other seafood dishes, with an emphasis on tuna. I went big and tried the Ahi Three Ways - each variation was fresh with enough character to make the meal a culinary adventure. At $18.95, this might have been the most expensive dish on the menu, but it came with rice, seaweed salad and cucumber salad, so full worth it.

Desserts were intriguing enough that we had to try at least one. This time around, it was the passion fruit cheese cake, and next time I'm sure the mochi fondue will be how we finish. 

Being a new Dad, Pacific Catch is a great restaurant to have around. This location is spacious enough to bring little people, and as mentioned above the staff are more than accommodating (although no diaper changing station in the bathroom). 

They have a full bar, too, so might be a curious place to have a happy hour or something. 

Parking tip: they still have the adjacent lot for customer parking, so if you're lucky and/or early you can snag one of the seven spaces.

excerpts: Then we shared the mochi fondue which was nice contrast between the hot and the cold.
Cold ice cream wrapped in the soft skin of rice flour dipped in hot smooth chocolate.
mochi fondue.author: Leah E.
mochi fondue.review:
My sweetie wanted to give this place 5 stars. No,  he is not a Yelper but he vicariously Yelps through me.  His Yelp is as valid as mine since we are in this together.  

So, we had a nice delicious date night at Pacific Catch on 9th Street. Initially I planned on taking a nice walk at the Botanical Garden at Golden Gate Park to induce some nature in sweetie's system but it closes at 5 pm which meant it will be too early for dinner at Pacific Catch. So, we slept in anyway on that day and didn't make it to the City until almost 7 PM.  

Found parking at GG Park as soon as we entered the park. Crossed Lincoln holding hands and informed the hostess that we had a 7:30 reservation at 6:50 PM. Got seated right away.  I felt sad!!!! This used to be Canvas Cafe where my very, very dear friend Russell used to perform.  I remembered the good old days when he used to bring down the house!!!!! 

Anyway, sweetie and I got a welcome appetizer of Asian pretzel and edamame. We barely had time to eat it when our appetizer of fried oysters arrived. It was actually very good!!! The oysters were fresh and light.  (Our waiter was very prompt and attentive.)  I really wanted to order the famous rice bowls but I opted for ahi tuna 3 ways!!!! And 3 ways I was pleased.  Sweetie got the beef with prawns.  I don't know what it was called because I was busy concentrating on my tuna.  He said his was delicious except it was not enough. (Disclaimer:  my sweetie is a hefty eater. Pacific Catch's portions are adequate for normal human eaters like me who is Asian, petite but can pack  it in once in a while if the food is yummy!)  

Then we shared the mochi fondue which was nice contrast between the hot and the cold. Cold ice cream wrapped in the soft skin of rice flour dipped in hot smooth chocolate. The flavor just burst in my mouth.   

Overall, the experience was great.  I still could not give it 5 stars, though, even though the venue was hip and welcoming. Maybe because it should have stayed as Canvas Cafe where my dear, dear friend could have been still playing and bringing down the house. Maybe someday.... I will learn to forgive Pacific Catch eventhough I know it was not his fault. But I will definitely go back to his arms again......

We finished the evening with me showing sweetie my old hangout places like Tart to Tart   (that's for another Yelp review) and staying up until 2 PM watching "Eyes Wide Shut."  Yup, I was right all along. Nicole Kidman said the "F" word at the end of the movie.

excerpts: Gotta come back to try their Mojito & Mochi Fondue!!
mochi fondue.author: Serena W.
mochi fondue.review:
Arrived here expecting just sushi. Their menu only consisted of about 5-7(?) plain-nothing-out-of-the-original sushi rolls. Then me and my friend realized Pacific Catch was a Japanese-Mexican fusion restaurant, but we decided to give it a try anyways since we were drooling over the food on the table next to us. 

We started off with the Spicy Cabo Calamari, which was really soft in texture, definitely not crispy because the breaded exterior would fall off whenever we tried to pick at one; not spicy at all, it lacked much taste until i doused the heck out of it with the dipping sauce. Then we also figured out they also added a few other concocsions that should have just been left outta the fryer.....like the fried lemon I accidently ate.....twice. 

My friend ordered the Mixed Catch Basket. There wasn't anything special about this, except the fact that her side of Sweet Potato Fries were YUMMY!!

I ordered the Ahi Tuna Wasabi Bowl, topped with (of course) ahi tuna, wakame salad, avocado, ginger and cucumber. The sushi rice was flavored with a wasabi sauce, which was somewhat mild, but SO GOOD!! It's basically like sushi, but bigger and broken down into all its components. 

We also ordered two drinks, a Mai Tai & forgot the name of the other one, but both were pretty strong!! I like! I like!

Gotta come back to try their Mojito & Mochi Fondue!!

4 stars for their strong drinks, my Ahi Tuna Wasabi bowl and my friend's sweet potato fries!


[UPDATED: 4.26.2008]

Came here again with another friend around 8ish. Considering it was a Friday, there was a 30 min. wait for the tables inside, so we decided to dine outside, which turned out really nice...although it was butt-freezing cold at first. Thank god they had the protective sheet to block off most of the wind. 

Tried the Ahi Poke Wasabi bowl this time and it was delicious! Although I did like my Ahi Tuna from my last dining here, I would recommend the Ahi Poke over that. My Lemon Grass Mojito was refreshing as well. My friend's Gin & Tonic was pretty stiff.

Service was still attentive, friendly, consistent and quick. The bar was open till 1AM that day, but too bad we couldn't stay for another round of  drinks considering my friend had the Asian glow by the time he finished his Gin & Tonic. -sigh-

excerpts: The mochi fondue was a little bit different than we envisioned.
We thought there will actually be a "fondue" instead of just a container of hot fudge that we dip the mochi in.
I guess it's a more economical version of fondue...
mochi fondue.author: Cindy L.
mochi fondue.review:
I had high hopes for this place. I heard so many great things about their original restaurant down at Marina so always wanted to try this place.

I was surprised it felt very corporate, I had been by the Marina location and it looked more homey. But my biggest complaint was about the food of course. I think a salt monkey made our food. We got the White Tuna Tataki | seared white tuna served with crab & daikon salad $9.95. It was REALLY bad. Both the tuna & the crab were incredibly salty. I also ordered a lemongrass mojito, it was not an easy drink so I switched to my friend's papaya cooler. Not great but okay. Service was okay. The mochi fondue was a little bit different than we envisioned. We thought there will actually be a "fondue" instead of just a container of hot fudge that we dip the mochi in. I guess it's a more economical version of fondue... The hot fudge was warm by the time it got to our table, it was a little bit hard to dip.

I am surprised to see so many great reviews on yelp, we must've gotten the b team that day. We all wished we had went to park chow or hotei instead. Much cheaper and much more fulfilling. 

Damn you iPhone commercial, you lied to me!!!

excerpts: the mochi fondue and the fried dulce de leche spring rolls.
Both were scrumptious!
mochi fondue.author: BrElla4eva H.
mochi fondue.review:
I'd really give this place 3 1/2 stars...4 stars for food, 3 stars for the service. I actually really like this restaurant. The place is pretty casual, but fun. A good spot to get together with a small group of friends for a reasonably priced dinner. The food was delicious, but the service was mediocre. I think our server was new to the job so I felt bad for him. . We ordered the hawaiian poke to start off but didn't end up actually getting it till a little bit after our server came out with our entrees. But better late than never because it was ooh so good. Very fresh and flavorful. After contemplating about the many enticing choices on the menu, I opted for the island tacos for my main entree. One grilled mahi mahi and one cabo shrimp with a side of sweet potato fries. Definite thumbs up! 

I do need to mention a strange but funny incident we had while dining here. As we were all finishing up our food, one of my friends was drinking waster out of his glass...when all of a sudden I see a big splash. At first I thought he dropped his glass of water but it turned out that the bottom of his glass broke and all the ice and water spilled out! And let me just tell you...it broke just on the bottom of the glass in almost a perfect, complete circle! How weird is that!?! Luckily he already finished his meal. We, of course, complained to our server and he was able to get his meal for free. He mentioned that it probably happened because the glass was hot when they poured in cold water.

Now for dessert...always my favorite part! The four of us shared 2 different plates....the mochi fondue and the fried dulce de leche spring rolls. Both were scrumptious! I never thought of dipping mochi ice cream balls in hot chocolate sauce but it is dee-lish!

YES, I'd come back to this place and YES, I recommend it!

excerpts: We split a mochi fondue for dessert and I almost died because it was INSANE.
I would not hesitate to kill any of you for some more of that stuff.
mochi fondue.author: Steve C.
mochi fondue.review:
Sweet Jesus this place is awesome. 

We started with calarmari, and it was easily among the most delicious I've had. The aoili that came with it was great, and complemented the calamari well. 

I had shrimp tacos, which again were delicious. I got the three taco plate which was a little too much, but I was starving. The two taco plate is plenty though. I subbed in pineapple fried rice for the sweet potato fries, even though I've heard those are amazing. The rice was really delicious too. I can't remember what my fiancee got, probably because I was face down in my plate.  

We split a mochi fondue for dessert and I almost died because it was INSANE. I would not hesitate to kill any of you for some more of that stuff. Holy crap. 

Add in a pretty nice bottle of wine, and we were still out of there for around a hundred bucks, including the tip. 

My fiancee really, REALLY misses Hawaii often, and this is one of the places I can take her in San Francisco that makes it hurt a little less. The food is really fresh and the fish is amazing, and it's similar to what you would get on the islands. The staff are all very friendly and knowledgeable, and according to our waitress, a lot of them are from Hawaii as well. 

We made a reservation about an hour in advance (Friday night), but when we arrived twenty minutes early, we found an open table in the bar area, so we just grabbed that.

excerpts: For dessert, we had the Mochi Fondue -- not worth it.
mochi fondue.author: Alyson C.
mochi fondue.review:
Tasty Drinks! Their Guava Mint drink was a bit too grainy for me, but I guess that's what you expect out of 100% Guava Puree. However, the Citrus Ginger drink was reallllly good. I will go back for that.

Wasabi Bowls are great as are the sweet potato fries with different dipping sauces. 

For dessert, we had the Mochi Fondue -- not worth it.

The bartender was a sweetheart but our waiter had an "i'm a jerk" attitude. 

I'll definitely go back for the drinks and the poke wasabi bowl with Brown Rice.

excerpts: We shared the Mochi Fondue and some kind of brownie a la mode which was really delicious.
The service was good, and there was a really cute bus boy.
mochi fondue.author: Tiffany T.
mochi fondue.review: I was just here the other day for a friend's birthday, and it was the perfect place to have it - loud, colorful environment. It was pretty busy but they do take reservations. Their menu is rather unique - they have an interesting variety ranging from sushi rolls to tacos. I ordered the Spicy Ahi Tuna Sandwich with sweet potato fries (which were so delicious). I liked the sandwich but I have to say the tuna wasn't very flavorful. I also mooched off my friends' Teriyaki Bowls and Wasabi Bowls..pretty good! We shared the Mochi Fondue and some kind of brownie a la mode which was really delicious. The service was good, and there was a really cute bus boy. :)

excerpts: Lastly, a very special treat are the Fried Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls.
Yea.
Wow.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.author: Irina S.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.review:
Why have I not reviewed this place earlier? I love it here. I am a regular here; the servers recognize me, stay and chat. It's great. Sure, like with every place one can have a bad experience, but the great experiences and delicious food (well priced too)  outweigh any hiccup that might occur. 

My favorite entree is the veggie special salad with grilled salmon. I have even been known to add the korean steak to it. It's just perfect. 

Recently, I tried their salmon club special. WTF? That was just awesome! 

I also love me some thai iced tea! They make it super tasty and are generous with the refills. The lemongrass iced is great too, but please don't forget about the full bar! 

Lastly, a very special treat are the Fried Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls. Yea. Wow. Seriously, WOW!

I haven't mentioned their appetizers yet, but I feel like I should. The ceviche and fried oyster appetizers, and their hawaiian poke are really tasty. The spicy fries make a good side or just a yummy starter. 

Ok. I have to control myself. But this place is really good to come to just when you want a quick dinner, to catch up with a friend, or with a group. 

p.s. they have opentable to you get points for making reservations, and just recently started using the punchh app. Double perks for eating here!!!! Yes please.

excerpts: just for the Fried Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls (with vanilla ice cream & caramel).
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.author: Chanel M.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.review:
The food here is  blah  BUT i have been back 3 or 4x just for the Fried Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls (with vanilla ice cream & caramel). Once I ordered 2 plates of the Dulce de Leche (shhhhhhh!)

Very kid friendly

excerpts: The fried Dulce de Leche spring rolls at first didn't sound appealing to everyone, but we devoured two orders without an effort.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.author: Ian C.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.review:
Originally, I was looking for their location in the Marina, but we were near Golden Gate Park and the tiny but small parking lot had a few open spots so I figured why not.  With multiple locations, the differences in ratings didn't really seem logical.

My family enjoyed the quick service as we were hungry.  The waiter recommended the coconut shrimp for an appetizer and I'll pass that recommendation along.  The fish tacos and sweet potato fries were the common entrees that got praise.  

The only universal entree that got high marks was the dessert.  The fried Dulce de Leche spring rolls at first didn't sound appealing to everyone, but we devoured two orders without an effort.  

4 out of 5 stars, and next time I am hungry and nearby, I'll definitely stop in even if the parking lot is full.

excerpts: But what made me an immediate fan was their fried dulce de leche spring rolls.
I drool at the thought of them, they are that delicious.
The springrolls are crunchy on the outside, warm and gooey on the inside
and here's the kicker, a really yummy scoop of ice cream with a caramel drizzle.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.author: Hedieh G.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.review:
First and foremost, I am not a big seafood fan. After years of my boyfriend trying to get me to go, I finally decided to give them a shot. I started off small, I got their 3 tacos; two chicken and one mahi mahi. All I have to say is that the mahi mahi is far better than the chicken! But what made me an immediate fan was their fried dulce de leche spring rolls. I drool at the thought of them, they are that delicious. The springrolls are crunchy on the outside, warm and gooey on the inside and here's the kicker, a really yummy scoop of ice cream with a caramel drizzle. This thing is a heart attack on a plate, but a heart attack that I'm willing to suffer. 

My second visit I decided that since I had a great experience with their seafood the first time, that I would try experimenting something new. I ordered the seared ahi macadamia, the best ahi I've ever had. For those of you who don't like ahi because of it's aftertaste or "fishy" taste, this dish does not have anything like that. The ahi has a yummy mango thai citrus salad that really compliments the ahi and is delicious!

The bar scene can be really fun, it's nice to stop by, have an appetizer and beer and watch the local games. 

As far of prices, for a party of 2 with 2-3 drinks total, one appetizer, 2 entrees, dessert and coffee with run you close to $80, so for a full course meal it's not that pricey!

excerpts: the mochi fondue and the fried dulce de leche spring rolls.
Both were scrumptious!
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.author: BrElla4eva H.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.review:

excerpts: we ended the evening with the fried dulce de leche spring rolls which were delish.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.author: Anh V.
fried dulce de leche spring rolls.review:
hmmm, i do love their pomegranate martinis...

the mood is open and casual.  it's unassuming and friendly to families and big groups with choices of seating at the bar, tables and chairs or comfy booths.  

well, since i was not on a liquid diet yet, i had to sample their menu.

thanks to yelpers, i did read up a bit on what to order.

the grilled artichoke was good but yes, do order the sweet potato fries.  i couldn't choose between the two dipping sauces so i compromised on dipping into both.  
the hawaiian poke sashimi was a close second to the fries.

for entrees, i do recommend the korean bbq skirt steak and  the unagi wasabi bowl - we added grilled fresh salmon to it.
i had the giant scallops which had a jerk chicken like seasoning.  so if you aren't into kicky spices, then this is not the dish for you.  the menu is pretty extensive so there is something for everyone.

we ended the evening with the fried dulce de leche spring rolls which were delish.  next time, i'll have to come back and order the passion mango cheesecake.

parking is tough in the neighborhood but there is a lot a block away.  frankly, i rather pony up for the parking and be sipping on their yummy martinis than circling the block.

excerpts:
But it came with pineapple rice which was yum.  

for desert we had the macadamia nut brownie sundae, with toasted almonds and fudge.
macadamia nut brownie sundae.author: Jo M.
macadamia nut brownie sundae.review:
i got the mixed basket of fish, coconut shrimp, and oysters, with sweet potato french fries.  It was delicious.  Bubs got the hawaiian mahi mahi which was a bit too grilled and smokey for our taste.  But it came with pineapple rice which was yum.  

for desert we had the macadamia nut brownie sundae, with toasted almonds and fudge.  that was incredibly delicious and worth the trip alone!  

the atmosphere is laid back but trendy-ish.  the waiter looked like ellen degeneris and was super nice!

excerpts: We also had the Macadamia Nut Brownie Sundae.
macadamia nut brownie sundae.author: Anita C.
macadamia nut brownie sundae.review:
Went back today with my family for birthday dinners. My sister and I wanted to have and try several things, so we shared A LOT of food. (In our defense, we were going to share with the others in our family, too.)

My sister and I chose:

-Sake Sake Sushi (still very very good. tastes so fresh and yummy. not overdone. had avocado inside with salmon and roe on the outside)
-Rising Sun Sushi (this was okay for me. just may not be a huge fan of the tempura inside. this one had tempura inside with tuna on the outside)
-Mixed Catch Basket with SWEET POTATO FRIES (the fries came with diff sauce, but it tasted good dipped in this other seafood sauce from another dish we had, and also good dipped in this sweet sauce that came with our mixed catch basket. Mixed Catch Basket came with 2 pieces of fish, 4 coconut shrimp, and 3 oyster. My sister and I agreed the oysters were the best. Breaded on the outside and when you bite into, it's soft, not quite slimy, and very good!! We could have done without the so-so fish, and the coconut shrimp)
Last but not least, we also had:
-today's special appetizer - seafood in sauce(i love sauce) with a piece of very crispy bread that was grilled and tasted excellent dipped in the seafoody sauce, and it was topped with some spicy mustard that gave some surprising zing)

Our family also shared:
-Hawaiian Poke (very good. many pieces of poke with little chips to eat with it, though the poke was a little salty)
-Baja Shrimp Ceviche (this was great. tortilla chips with the sour sauce tasted good. and there were many large shrimp we kept discovering beneath the sauce too)

Other family members had:
-Pineapple fried rice - apparently not very good
-Shrimp taco - tasted ok
-sweet tea - basically just sweetened tea
-spicy fries - not too special
-shrimp tempura roll - nothing special. the tempura just didn't do much for me

AND, because my family had 3 birthdays, they comped 3 desserts for us! We got two Mochi Fondues, that come with the ice cream mochis in chocolate, vanilla, and coffee flavors to be dipped in warm chocolate sauce. I had the vanilla and that tasted pretty good. We also had the Macadamia Nut Brownie Sundae. I had a bite, and it was good, but just too sweet for my taste.

Also, the service was interesting. They kept collecting our chopsticks, and once even collected plates they gave my sister and I to use to share our food. We hadn't even used our chopsticks (2nd set) and plates yet! So our food came, and we're like...where are our plates AND our chopsticks! So I was onto my 3rd pair of chopsticks. After that, every time they came by, I held onto my chopsticks. Can you be overserviced?

But I like the appetizers and the sushi and sweet potato fries, so indeed I would return. Oh, and those oysters, too!! So that helps me forget about some of the negatives and give Pacific Catch another 4 stars!

Maybe sometime I can just come for happy hour between 4-6pm, and get the things I like, and not make it a full on meal. :-)

excerpts: We had the chocolate macadamia nut brownie
sundae (my least favorite part of the meal...
pretty dry and not very moist-
but it was free).
Overall the food and service was good.
I'd recommend this place for asian fusion or seafood if in the area.
Nice place for small groups or a date.
macadamia nut brownie.author: Miss H K.
macadamia nut brownie.review:
4 1/2 years later...and I return!
Came here today to celebrate my mom's bday for lunch. Had no problem making a reservation on Opentable. 
This location is larger than some of the other PC's I've seen and has a nice, modern and casual atmosphere. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive and our dining experience was very nice overall.
We started with the Korean sticky ribs (yummy and finger licking good)! I had the chicken and steak island tacos after for my meal. The tacos were good (better flavor than I remember from last time) and were filling. Also had a Foursquare newbie check in special for a free dessert. We had the chocolate macadamia nut brownie sundae (my least favorite part of the meal...pretty dry and not very moist-but it was free).
Overall the food and service was good. I'd recommend this place for asian fusion or seafood if in the area. Nice place for small groups or a date.

excerpts: Finished the night off with warm peach  with a side of vanilla ice cream and cobbler and macadamia nut brownie.
macadamia nut brownie.author: Richard G.
macadamia nut brownie.review:
Came for dinner sunday night after roaming through Golden Gate park and the Academy of science.  Parking is a bore.

Table for four without reservations at 6:00, scored and got at table.  The place is nice.  

On the table is fish pretzel crackers and soybeans, nice touch.

I had the wakame salad and seared Ahi,over rice done just right.  My friends had the grilled shirmp on mashed potatoes.  Had bear republic ipa on draft was a nice touch.   Finished the night off with warm peach  with a side of vanilla ice cream and cobbler and macadamia nut brownie.

food ****
service*****
decor****
nice solid ****
I left happy.  great place after a day in the park

excerpts:
- Teriyaki Bowl ((nice especially with bok choy, sprouts and nori!)
- Macadamia Nut Brownie
(DROOL!
DRIP!
nuf said!)
- Bloody Mary (Sunday and Bloody Mary's??
macadamia nut brownie.author: Amit S.
macadamia nut brownie.review:
ACK! That's Marlin, Nemo and Dory you're serving on my plate, you freak!

... just kidding! 

This place is actually not that bad at all. Even months after they reopened, I could not make myself go in for the simple fact that I was an avid fan of the Canvas Gallery that occupied the space before, and to see it close was truly sad... I am in mourning...

... OK. Sob story over... back to me now...

... checked it out on a nice and sunny Sunday (those rare ones in the Inner Sunset when you can wear shorts, a tank and flip flops) and had a great time.

I recommend:
- Warm Edamame (sea salt is umm good!)
- House-made Miso Soup (dunno who'se "house" it was made in but they make it darn good)
- Hawaiian Poke (my FAV dish here! the tuna on the wonton crisp is just something else... this Hawaiian can poke me any ole time!)
- Cabo Calamari (What? Messican Calamari?? Odd name but all the same pretty good thought a wee bit greasy with the deep frying)
- Fish & Chips (Can't go wrong with this one... actually, you can! good but not as good as Woodhouse Fish Company)
- Teriyaki Bowl ((nice especially with bok choy, sprouts and nori!)
- Macadamia Nut Brownie (DROOL! DRIP!... nuf said!)
- Bloody Mary (Sunday and Bloody Mary's?? Ya betcha!)

Nice place, crowd (tourists, neighbors, folks from other hoods), kid friendly, dog friendly (outside), waiter service outdoors can be a bit iffy until you throw in some 'tude.

excerpts: We also shared a macadamia nut brownie with ice cream.
macadamia nut brownie.author: Candice B.
macadamia nut brownie.review:
Although like many others, I was sad to see Canvas go, I was also super curious to see what Pacific Catch did with the space.  Since I had a $20 Opentable cheque to use and some friends actually said good things about the new restaurant, I decided to finally give it a try.  Oh and also, nothing seems to be open on Easter Sunday for dinner and we desperately needed to take a friend out for his birthday. 

We had a reservation for 6:30 and one of us was very late, but the hostess and waitress gave us no grief and didn't make us feel guilty at all.  That's a giant plus for me.  It didn't seem like a lot of people made reservations, as our table was the only visible one with the sign "reservation" on it.  

The decor, well, I get it, it's Hawaiian themed.  The color is a bit loud for me and made the space look much smaller than its actual size.  I am glad they retained the high ceiling that I loved when it was Canvas, and we were all in awe that we were sitting where the middle bar used to be.  One thing I really didn't like was the carpet.  It was just ugly.  I don't see why they couldn't do some sort of chic hardwood floor.  And the noise level---it sounded like Happy Hour with a hundred suits packed in some Financial District bar at 5.  

Our waitress was prompt and friendly and efficient.  Our dishes arrived timely.  Among the three of us, we had a basket of sweet potato fries, which was enormous (I mean, it doesn't look like much but sweet potatoes can be dense!)  I don't think anyone can mess up on sweet potato fries, so I was happy.  The sauces were pretty good, but I prefer to eat them without anything.  

I had an unsweetened iced tea, which reminded me of the iced tea from the Grove.  Meaning, it's good---fruity aroma but not actually really sweet.  My boyfriend had a glass of sake.   Our friend had a mojito, which looked really good. 

We wanted to get some grilled corn but apparently they ran out, cuz it was a nice day and therefore everyone ordered corn (our waitress' explanation).  But she came back and told us the kitchen managed to find a piece so they will throw that in our dish.  Free corn?  I was thrilled.  But it was just okay.  I imagined it to be that famous Mexican grilled corn from Cafe Habana in New York, but nope, just your ordinary slightly charred, buttery, hard corn.  Kinda disappointing.

For entree, I had the ahi poke wasabi bowl.  I am not a huge wasabi fan, but I do enjoy wasabi noodles from the House and thought it might be a subtle flavor like that.  It basically came as a giant bowl with every ingredient you can find in a tuna roll, but deconstructed, and enlarged.  I didn't think the rice was flavored enough to be called "sushi rice."  But the ahi poke was delicious and the soy-wasabi sauce was pungent and flavorful.  Did I mention it's giant?  After my indulgence on sweet potato fries and a piece of corn, I could only finish a quarter of my rice bowl.  I think it'll be good as left over. 

The other two had the specials, sturgeon and some other fish---I can't remember!  Both fish dishes looked just alright to me that I didn't even feel tempted to try them, but they both claimed that the dishes were good.  So I will take their word for it.  

We also shared a macadamia nut brownie with ice cream.  It was nice and sweet, and comes in a good portion for sharing.  

The restaurant was packed around 6:30 but by the time we left at 9, it was practically empty.  Sorta surprising to me that people ate so early.  I was glad that no one pressured us to leave long after we ate everything and paid and sat around.  But then again, it wasn't like they needed the table or anything. 

I would go back for the fries.  And possibly go for their Happy Hour special which seems to be a good deal.  $3 beers and little munchies to go along.

excerpts:
But it came with pineapple rice which was yum.  

for desert we had the macadamia nut brownie sundae, with toasted almonds and fudge.
macadamia nut brownie.author: Jo M.
macadamia nut brownie.review:
i got the mixed basket of fish, coconut shrimp, and oysters, with sweet potato french fries.  It was delicious.  Bubs got the hawaiian mahi mahi which was a bit too grilled and smokey for our taste.  But it came with pineapple rice which was yum.  

for desert we had the macadamia nut brownie sundae, with toasted almonds and fudge.  that was incredibly delicious and worth the trip alone!  

the atmosphere is laid back but trendy-ish.  the waiter looked like ellen degeneris and was super nice!

excerpts: We also had the Macadamia Nut Brownie Sundae.
macadamia nut brownie.author: Anita C.
macadamia nut brownie.review:
Went back today with my family for birthday dinners. My sister and I wanted to have and try several things, so we shared A LOT of food. (In our defense, we were going to share with the others in our family, too.)

My sister and I chose:

-Sake Sake Sushi (still very very good. tastes so fresh and yummy. not overdone. had avocado inside with salmon and roe on the outside)
-Rising Sun Sushi (this was okay for me. just may not be a huge fan of the tempura inside. this one had tempura inside with tuna on the outside)
-Mixed Catch Basket with SWEET POTATO FRIES (the fries came with diff sauce, but it tasted good dipped in this other seafood sauce from another dish we had, and also good dipped in this sweet sauce that came with our mixed catch basket. Mixed Catch Basket came with 2 pieces of fish, 4 coconut shrimp, and 3 oyster. My sister and I agreed the oysters were the best. Breaded on the outside and when you bite into, it's soft, not quite slimy, and very good!! We could have done without the so-so fish, and the coconut shrimp)
Last but not least, we also had:
-today's special appetizer - seafood in sauce(i love sauce) with a piece of very crispy bread that was grilled and tasted excellent dipped in the seafoody sauce, and it was topped with some spicy mustard that gave some surprising zing)

Our family also shared:
-Hawaiian Poke (very good. many pieces of poke with little chips to eat with it, though the poke was a little salty)
-Baja Shrimp Ceviche (this was great. tortilla chips with the sour sauce tasted good. and there were many large shrimp we kept discovering beneath the sauce too)

Other family members had:
-Pineapple fried rice - apparently not very good
-Shrimp taco - tasted ok
-sweet tea - basically just sweetened tea
-spicy fries - not too special
-shrimp tempura roll - nothing special. the tempura just didn't do much for me

AND, because my family had 3 birthdays, they comped 3 desserts for us! We got two Mochi Fondues, that come with the ice cream mochis in chocolate, vanilla, and coffee flavors to be dipped in warm chocolate sauce. I had the vanilla and that tasted pretty good. We also had the Macadamia Nut Brownie Sundae. I had a bite, and it was good, but just too sweet for my taste.

Also, the service was interesting. They kept collecting our chopsticks, and once even collected plates they gave my sister and I to use to share our food. We hadn't even used our chopsticks (2nd set) and plates yet! So our food came, and we're like...where are our plates AND our chopsticks! So I was onto my 3rd pair of chopsticks. After that, every time they came by, I held onto my chopsticks. Can you be overserviced?

But I like the appetizers and the sushi and sweet potato fries, so indeed I would return. Oh, and those oysters, too!! So that helps me forget about some of the negatives and give Pacific Catch another 4 stars!

Maybe sometime I can just come for happy hour between 4-6pm, and get the things I like, and not make it a full on meal. :-)
